output: Mr. President, dear colleagues, I apologize once again for my delay.
This year marks the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue.
The involvement of everyone and the perception that education, knowledge, and the blending of different cultures with one another is crucial is already an accepted fact.
For this reason, multiple initiatives associated with this year have been carried out by the different areas of action and intervention.
In this context, the Erasmus Worlds programme also plays its part, and the new regulation is already in place in this new perspective.

The Erasmus Mundus programme constitutes an important contribution to the creation of centres of excellence in the EU, which will in some way help to stem the brain drain to the European Union formula, and also plays a significant role in the

in promoting European values among nationals from third countries who come here to study and who find in the old continent an unparalleled cultural and linguistic diversity that acts as an attractive and distinct pole from models existing in the rest of the world.
However, dialogue and interculturality have seemed quite resilient.

The problem of visas for Erasmus students in the world and the frequent difficulties in obtaining and renewing them lead to them often living in a semi-clandestine situation in the European Union, as they attend master's programs, but with tourist visas and sometimes expired ones.
I consider it of utmost relevance and urgency to seek a solution that allows for solidarity, transparency, and efficiency in the issuance of visas for these students.
Knowledge of the language, which allows for cultural awareness and mutual interaction, beyond the strictly academic domain, is also crucial, which is why we ensure this premise is met absolutely.
Finally, a word of thanks to Mrs Dessa ArnÃªs for the way she conducted this entire process and for the balanced report she produced.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, authorisation for the granting of State aid for the modernisation and renewal of the fishing fleets in the outermost regions should only be possible until the end of 2009 or should be valid indefinitely.
The specific nature of fishing activity in these regions justifies that these aids can be granted beyond 2009, without the marine environment being minimally harmed.
State aid for the modernisation and renewal of fleets in the outermost regions for an indefinite period does not mean permanent and eternal aid.
would be immediately discontinued if studies and evaluation by the Scientific Council and Regional Advisory Councils demonstrated such a need.
This is the solution that would best suit the very specific reality of fishing in the outermost regions.

The same reasons that justify an exclusive fishing reserve up to 100 miles for fishermen in each of the ORs also justify a differentiated treatment with regard to aid for the modernisation and renewal of the fleet.
Fortunately, the best solutions were found in the Committee on Fisheries, which can address the specific characteristics of fishing in the outermost regions.

Thank you very much, Mr President. Mr President, Commissioner Almunia, Mr President of the Eurogroup, I want to congratulate not only the rapporteurs, but also the Commission for taking the initiative to produce this text, the assessment of the 10 years of Economic and Monetary Union.
It is a strategic text and this analysis was fundamental.
The euro, as has been said here today, is an undeniable success.

From Lisbon and Helsinki, from Dublin and Bratislava, the Euro has shown signs of resilience and solidity, even during the severe turbulence we have witnessed. And it is clear that the borders of this club need to be expanded.
But the current times are putting the solidity of the European project to the test on a daily basis in many other dimensions.
The euro, as I said, is a central instrument of the financial system's operation.

However, the Commission's own text clearly points to the fundamental conclusion that neither the growth of the real economy nor convergence, in social or spatial terms, has kept pace with this success.
On the contrary, the Commission clearly concludes that the disparities have worsened violently during the decade of the single currency's operation.
This divergence affects regions of my country in particular, especially Northern Portugal, but also other regions of member countries.

The impacts of the single monetary policy, particularly due to the very high exchange rate in practice, have affected more those regions that are most exposed to international competition and the most export-oriented regions.
Today, the crisis that resulted from the deregulation of financial markets is violently affecting the real economy and further exacerbating the situation for many citizens and regions.

These regions, those exposed to international competition, those dependent on small and medium-sized enterprises, those where access to credit is most important, are today falling victim to this process and are even threatening depression.
Commissioner, President of the Eurogroup, the success of the Euro depends on the trust that European citizens place in it.
The most powerful European countries have already begun a process of relaunching their national economies.
We have the particular case of initiatives concerning the automotive industry.
But Europe is more than that.
it must be much more than the more or less coordinated sum of national policies.
The time has come to transform the Euro into a central tool of Europe, supporting a robust currency, but also a robust real economy. And to ensure that the functioning of the Euro is accompanied by
of mechanisms that ensure the central objective of achieving social and regional convergence, because it is at the heart, at the core of the European project.
The debate on the coordination of economic policies in the euro area today has a reinforced and unquestionable impact and relevance.
But coordinating national policies is not enough.
More is needed.

Having a Lisbon strategy that is a sum of national initiatives and a stability and growth pact that differentially tightens the belt on the different countries that use it and to which it must submit, are limitations to which is added the limited budget we have.
Crises generate opportunities.
The Monetary Union can only be sustained by a convergence of well-being of the member countries that integrate it, regardless of their citizens, regardless of where they were born.
What other way would we have to mobilize citizens for the single currency?
The Commission must live up to its own diagnosis, which is why we eagerly await the concrete proposals that the Commission will bring to this plenary on November 26 and present to European citizens.

It is essential that this crisis marks the beginning of a new phase of the Union in which the consolidation and strength of the financial system are accompanied by genuine prosperity based on cohesion and economic citizenship.

Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. This oral question presented to the European Commission by Gerardo Galeota on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development of this Parliament is fully justified and relevant.

In fact, it is necessary to clarify the reasons why the Council is blocking the reform of the Solidarity Fund, as it is unable to reach an agreement on a common position that would allow the legislative process to continue.
the reasons that may underlie the Council's position are hardly discernible, except perhaps for petty financial reasons.
Does the Council not want a more agile and immediate response to natural disasters that occur?

I do not want the Council to ensure that this type of swift response is given to other types of catastrophes, such as serious industrial accidents, terrorist attacks, or serious public health situations.

It is important that these questions have a clear answer, just as it is also important to clarify what the European Commission thinks about this situation and whether it intends to take any measures aimed at unblocking the legislative process.
The value of solidarity must also be fully realized in this area.
Citizens would not understand at all if they were not.
I just want to say that I wanted to protest against the statement made by Mrs. Luling, which seeks to condition the vote of the deputies in this House, and this conditioning does not make sense.

The interpretation you are making is an interpretation that we do not share and it is only in this sense that I would like to ask my colleagues who know what they are dealing with, who know that we are defending other interests, which are the interests of public health and the interest of citizens and the interest of countries, to actually vote in favor of the report. Thank you very much.
Mr President, Commissioner, for the past two months the political and media agenda has been dominated by the financial and economic crisis.
The referendum in Ireland or the difficulties in the Czech Republic over the Lisbon Treaty barely have any coverage in the media.

Do you not think that, now, the Commission's information and communication strategy should be reinforced with the need and urgency of the Lisbon Treaty coming into force, also as a political response to face and overcome the crisis we are living through?
Mr President-in-Office, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the powers of the world have the international financial system in their hands at this time.
was looking for a hand-made detail and it was about time.
And so, perhaps it is time for us to resolve, right now, another problem that we have been hearing about for decades.
For decades we have been hearing this song of the ignoble plundering of resources, how often, as now again in the Congo, over the blood of the populations.

And I believe it is also time to pursue these companies, to pursue this ignoble trade, to freeze the accounts through which the shameful profits from this exploitation of mineral resources at the expense of the blood and suffering of the populations circulate and are deposited.
I don't understand why these companies aren't listed in the same way that we already have a blacklist of terrorist organizations.
And I don't understand why the international community is not able to pursue these businessmen who, in fact, are not businessmen, but authentic bandits who jeopardize regional and world security.
I encourage the French Presidency and the Commission to lead an international initiative in this direction. Thank you very much.
We have heard it said here several times today that a crisis usually creates an opportunity, and that is indeed the case.
And if we want to seize the opportunity that is open to us, the agenda is easy to understand.
First of all, we are aware, at the level of the European Union, of the need to introduce mechanisms of transparency, regulation, and supervision in financial markets.
And it is not necessary for your Commissioner Macrivi to launch more consultations, nor is it necessary for the Presidency to analyze and invoke more studies and
more proposals. Just look at the proposals that were made in a timely manner by the socialists and many of which were eventually taken up by this Parliament.
Secondly, internationally, Europe cannot be in the international arena in a passive manner.
It must be an active agent in building the new international order. It must be the defender of a new architecture that does not leave black holes in the system, such as the current tax havens.
Thirdly, we heard the President of the Commission say here today that there is reluctance in coordinating strategies at the level of the different states.
It is true that if we had not heard from many members of the Commission for so long that the markets regulate themselves, that the state should stay out.
if financial markets had no impact on growth or employment, perhaps there would be a more active and more effective spirit of solidarity at the level of the different countries.
But today the proposal we have in hand is a proposal that is nothing more than a first step. If we compare it with the program of China and the United States, on the other hand, it is not.
it does not define clearly enough what the objective is and the objective has to be employment and thirdly because a European programme cannot be a sum of national agendas.
Today is the time for us to show the citizens of Europe that Europe is a network of economic rights that protect them in times of crisis, in terms of
solidarity, a growth program, and support for small and medium-sized enterprises that are currently not receiving the results of the interventions made at the banking level.
The real economy is what it is, and we are here as Europeans to show citizens that Europe is here, above all, because of them. Thank you very much.
Mr President, dear colleagues, it is with particular satisfaction that I stand before you to present the work that has been done in conjunction with all of you on this own-initiative report.
For me and for all those who collaborated in the unfolding of this process, we can say that we did our job.

To everyone, in particular to the fellow shadow rapporteurs from the different political groups who have made great efforts to reach compromises for the future, to the always available regional development staff, especially to Miguel Telcremades and Elisa da Farra,

To the PSE staff, Lila and Petros, and the European Commission, who, always represented by the many different directorates-general that such a comprehensive report requires, have continuously and closely followed the work and made great efforts to ensure its successful completion.
To my office and, in particular, to Joana Benzinho, my heartfelt thanks on behalf of a more harmonious and structured development for the coastal regions and tourism in the European Union.
The 27 member states of the European Union together have more than 89,000 kilometers of coastline.
It presents a variety of very particular characteristics that, according to their location, are demarcated either by cosmopolitanism, if we speak of cities like Lisbon, Copenhagen or Stockholm,

due to the difficulties of being peripheral or ultra-peripheral regions, with problems of connections to major cities or with accelerated desertification contexts, such as the Algarve, Liguria, the Canary Islands or Madeira.
One way or another, everyone identifies with the notion of coast and coastal zone and experiences the advantages and disadvantages associated with them on a daily basis.
According to available data, by 2010, about 75% of humanity will live in coastal areas.
According to the circuits and relationships between them, we define the 50 km in a straight line that go from the coastline to the inland areas.
Yes, regions rather than maritime zones detached from the integrated vision that these matters so desperately need and that our ancestors would also subscribe to.
This is where all these people will concentrate in search of opportunities and economic synergies, and in many cases, their only expectation is that these will revolve around tourism.
Thus, the evident need for a pragmatic and integrated view of the impact of tourism on coastal areas took hold of our minds and led us to get to work.

In the current context of financial crisis, where the impact on the real economy becomes increasingly insurmountable, tourism emerges as a sector with enormous potential to be directly or indirectly affected in a brutal manner.

Regions that are overwhelmingly or entirely dependent on tourism for their development see their activity threatened and look to the future with distrust. This is especially true because tourism is not currently a competence of the European Union.
However, coordinated measures can and should be taken, and the spirit in which the Lisbon Treaty was imbued reflects this very trend.
However, waiting until the treaty comes into force to start taking action is waiting for the phase when we will be crying over spilt milk.
The current political activity of tourism and the fragile reality of the regions that depend on it require urgent and effective action from us.

The fact that these are areas structurally dependent on tourism as a promoter of employment. Although it is often seasonal employment, this labor-intensive activity cannot be overlooked in a context of pressure on urban areas and unemployment.

That is why this report that we are presenting to you now, which was already of the utmost importance and urgency when the Committee on Regional Development of this House decided to promote it, now assumes that it should be seen as a priority for the European Commission and the European Council from now on.

Priority, yes, to the numerous initiatives that it incorporates, as well as to those that it explicitly supports and that have already been promoted by other institutions, along with the measures adopted in the emergency plan.

of the Commission, of which I highlight the review of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in which the issues associated with this sector, which is the shock it is currently subject to, must obviously be covered.

It is crucial to ensure the development of new segments of the economy in these coastal areas, ensuring their social and environmental sustainability and promoting the real integration of different sectoral policies, such as the maritime sector, transport,

energy cohesion instruments on the ground. The new quality product policy that the CAP reform incorporates with the announcement of the Elchec report and the new tourist products in these coastal areas take into account their crucial contribution to the European economy.
The implementation of an appropriate and holistic vision for this policy should soon become a reality in the European Union.

And to conclude, Mr President, only with a clear articulation of these instruments and rapid and effective action involving all partners and stakeholders already on the ground, can we ensure that we will have a sustainable and future-oriented tourism and coastal sector in the European Union. Thank you very much.
Mr Commissioner, Madam Minister, E-Justice is an important step in access to law, justice and courts.
I want to congratulate the initiative, commend the rapporteur and the French presidency.

Ejecetice was one of the projects under discussion, and it fell to Portugal, during its presidency, to lead the development and implementation of the pilot project that will allow all citizens to access services from other member states in a simpler, cheaper, more comfortable way, and in their own language.
This multilingual portal should be designed to serve citizens and businesses seeking legal support and basic legal advice on legal and cross-border issues.
E-Justice must be coordinated and managed by a responsible unit, which will also coordinate the contributions of the various Member States and their articulation with this responsible unit.
E-Justice will serve the citizen and strengthen our democracy.
I welcome the launch of the portal in December 2009. Thank you very much.
Mr President, Mr Barrot, colleagues, I congratulate the work of Carlos Coelho, of the Seda Martin Ruri and the other Seda members.
In December 2004, the Council adopted regulations establishing standards for security features and biometric data in passports and travel documents issued by member states.
Now we have needed to take new steps towards combating the kidnapping and trafficking of children.
The use of passports by children, in accordance with the principle of one person, one passport, can be a fundamental means of winning this difficult and important fight.
In my country, Portugal, the collection of fingerprints from children as young as 6 years old is already a long-standing practice, which perhaps is why it does not cause me any objection.
As a defender of the European cause, I believe that, on this matter, it is important to have harmonization.
It is reassuring to know that Member States, such as Portugal, which have long set the minimum age for collecting fingerprints at six years old, will not have to amend their national legislation.
I must emphasize that the security of passports, which is being strengthened today, is not limited to the existence of a passport.

The passport, in itself, corresponds to an increase in the level of security, which ranges from the presentation of the necessary documents for the issuance of passports, followed by the collection of biometric data, to the verification and matching at border control posts.
This report is another step towards affirming the rights of the individual and ensuring their safety.
Mr President, first of all I would like to salute the rapporteur Alexander Lamsdorff and the shadow rapporteurs, with particular emphasis on Barbara Weiler.
Dear colleagues, I believe it is essential that we move towards the integration of national defense markets and even the strategic coordination of their productions.

We must move forward, effectively, with the necessary specificities and precautions in order to apply the essential rules of the internal market to the defense industries, increasing transparency in the tenders that are organized and in the contracts that are signed involving the Member States of the European Union.
But at the same time we have to help develop the conditions that allow for greater competitiveness of European equipment and products in world markets.

Commissioner Macrivi, it seems to me important that this directive can ensure progress in the legal framework concerning public contracts in the fields of defence and security, moving forward in the construction of the international market.

within and obviously respecting the interests and rights of the Member States, especially in the field of security and, in particular, those that manufacture weapons, ammunition, and security equipment, such as my own country.

Mr President, I would also like to highlight the provisions that allow small and medium-sized enterprises easier access to this market, particularly through the improvement of subcontracting rules and the prospect of thus making progress with greater impact and depth in the decision.

In order to create a genuine European market in the defence industries, which could also contribute to strengthening research and development not only in the defence industries, but also in a range of European industries that benefit from the development of the defence industries.
To conclude, I think it is worth mentioning the obvious link between the defense industry and the Union's foreign policies.
But I would like to quote regarding the recent tenth intervention, translating a classic Roman saying, if you want peace, prepare for war.

The European Union, as it is almost a peaceful superpower, we call these industries defense industries and not war industries, because we want peace and not war. And that is why we also need defense industries.
Mr. Vice President Barrou, I agree with your dissatisfaction.
In fact, we have to be dissatisfied with the set of measures that are vast.
The truth is that irregular immigration continues to Europe, human trafficking continues, there are areas where there is a lot of immigration,
migration, particularly the Mediterranean route to Italy. France has made progress with a number of important bilateral cooperation agreements, but other member states have not followed suit.
The Commission must continue without losing enthusiasm in this policy of cooperation and aid to the Member States.
Mr President, Madam Commissioner, I shall try to put the questions in a very concise form.
First point, the issue of the European Union's special monitoring mechanism for the tests that ended, as mentioned here, on December 31, 2008.
What is lacking, Madam Commissioner, is the timely and routine publication of statistical data on imports, exports, and prices, similar to what happens in the United States.
Without this data, the European Union is unable to react against any unfair practices, and the Commission itself is unable to define its strategy.
I drew his attention to this, as other colleagues have already done.
Secondly, producing within the European Union increasingly requires compliance with safety standards, social standards, and environmental standards.
The RITS, for example, is a recent initiative that creates even more constraints for us.
It is important that the Commission has a clear strategy that is noticeable and monitorable so that imported products have identical requirements.
In what way are these aspects being properly safeguarded in the ongoing free trade agreements?
And as for Meidin, can Meidin actually help resolve this issue?
Third point. The European Union has launched an Economic Recovery Plan to combat the current crisis.
What role will trade policy play in this context?

At this point, what is the Commission preparing to do when a number of other countries, such as China, are beginning to proliferate the imposition of non-tariff barriers to prevent our European imports from accessing Chinese markets?

What does the proposal entail regarding the update or adjustment of the globalisation fund, as well as the support available in the structural funds frameworks to improve the immediate situation of the European textile industry?
Last question, finally, will the crisis we are going through finally make the Commission sensitive to the devastating impact on the European economy of an overvalued euro?
How can the Commissioner, to conclude, sensitize her colleagues and the entities dealing with European monetary policy towards rebalancing? Thank you very much.
It is clear to us that we should applaud Obama's decision, the decision to close Guantanamo, the ban on torture and illegal interrogations, and the suspension of military trials.
However, dear colleague who is no longer present, Portugal and the Portuguese socialist government have no feelings of guilt.
The Portuguese Socialist Government did not collaborate with the Bush Administration, quite the contrary.

It was precisely now, with the Portuguese administration, with the Portuguese government, with the initiative of Minister LuÃ­s Amado, that the possibility and the duty of the European Union and democratic countries to welcome and receive the detainees without a proven guilt in Guantanamo was triggered.

This is what is truly important, this is what should be highlighted as an example to be followed by the remaining member states of the European Union. How important it is that tomorrow the resolution is approved by all the parties that make up this Chamber so that in unity the decision can have more strength.
Mr President, I am very grateful to my colleague Mrs Napolitano for her excellent report.

14 years after Barcelona and 5 years after the first Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, we have the Union for the Mediterranean, with economic power, with parliamentary power, with civil society, with the heads of government deciding together.
All with a desire to do more and better in a territory where 720 million citizens represent potential for development and peace for the world.
Focusing only on the economic and business side is a clear mistake.

Responding to growth crises naturally requires a political response, but responding to humanitarian crises, emergency situations, and military crises like the one experienced at the end of 2008 and the beginning of 2009 is crucial.
Politicians and citizens have to provide answers to the world's problems.
The world demanded answers, and months later, we, citizens and politicians alike, particularly on a platform like the Union for the Mediterranean, are still slow to react.

I hope that, at the very least, this moment has served to learn and move forward. Because only those who make mistakes learn. But moving forward in the acceleration of the reaction is absolutely crucial.
The interest in approving this directive proposal lies essentially in how it can contribute to boosting economic activity at the local level and support actions at the social level.
The application of a reduced rate is of great importance in the field of housing, both in construction and renovation, allowing Member States that adopt it to reduce the cost to the end user.

Local service provision, particularly by small businesses, can also benefit from this reduction in VAT rates, by holding on to and generating more and better jobs through the promotion of consumption of goods and services, thereby stimulating the economy itself.

The restoration activity, which is fundamental for the proper functioning of local economies and the growth of tourism itself, can thus benefit greatly at the local level with this reduction in VAT taxation.
These services, dear colleagues, should not circulate within the European internal market, which will help to reduce the reservations of some Member States already noted at the Council level.
Therefore, I cannot agree with the extension of this reduced rate to equipment, regardless of the protest.

The prudent manner in which this proposal should be handled in the European Parliament should not provide an excuse for governments that have some reservations about the European Commission's proposal to actually use the right of veto that European legislation still allows in fiscal matters.
And so here it is prudent to reject amendments without much sense that only make the acceptance of the text more difficult.
As already mentioned here, not only is the perfect the enemy of the good, but also he who wants everything, loses everything.
This proposed directive is important not only for strengthening local economies, but it also corresponds to the ambitions repeatedly expressed by several Member States.
We therefore support the Commission's proposal, as it was presented. This, in fact, was the sense of the vote, as it is the agreement of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection.

I commend the work of the rapporteurs and call for the approval of this proposal in the exact terms in which it came from the Commission and was voted on in the Parliamentary Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Thank you very much.
I have a word to disagree with my colleague Edith Estrela, and that is what motivated me to speak, when she caricatured the intentions of the Czech presidency.
No one wants to send women home. The problem is that there are women who want or would like to stay at home.
There are even associations that seek to defend them. Women who are ignored, scorned, discriminated against, because they want to dedicate themselves to their families and we don't listen to them.
And this is a matter of freedom, it is a matter of freedom of choice, which the left so loves to invoke, but which they forget about here.
It is about respecting or not the freedom of organization of couples.
It is about being able to provide those who want to do so with a better quality of life, better fatherhood, and better motherhood.
This is what our society also needs to do.
We are not going there, we will not solve the problems of birth rates and people's happiness with prejudices.
We resolve with policies adjusted to reality and to the spontaneous desires of the people.
Let's not go down the road of an obsession with the state and the market.
Let's start with a fair look at the family.
Commissioner, dear colleagues, the difficult situation at Qimonda was exacerbated by the emergence of the financial and economic crisis.
The Portuguese Government has done everything it deems appropriate and useful to help resolve the situation.
And we would like the Bavarian government to also demonstrate a strong sense of responsibility in this area.
Saving the Munich facilities will have a decisive impact on the Vila do Conde and Dresden units.

The Portuguese minister himself, Manuel Pinho, stated the great interest in making this enterprise viable, which is so important for Portugal and for Europe, mentioning that Quimonda can be a globally competitive company.
President, the efforts of the Portuguese Government towards a solution that ensures the viability of the company will be maintained.
We hope that the German governments, at both the federal and state levels, will make a genuine effort to resolve this problem.
As for me, I would like to reiterate the strategic importance of maintaining this type of industry within European territory.
may no national or state executive make the mistake of allowing this company to close facilities and eliminate jobs within the territory of the Union.
Dear colleagues, we understand the need to help restructure the major automotive industry groups, but the Union's funds and the European Commission's energies cannot be exhausted in these aids.

Dear Commissioner, we appeal to Commissioner Vladimir Spidla, with whom we share bonds of work and political solidarity, and to President Barroso, who will never forget that he is our compatriot and of a significant portion of Quimonda workers, to engage the Commission in supporting Quimonda, overcoming possible communication failures.

We should point out, before concluding, that the Portuguese President, Cavaco Silva, recently stated in Germany that there was new hope regarding Quimonda and also mentioned the importance, as already highlighted by colleagues, of the economic sector in which Quimonda operates.
We must therefore take into account that the Portuguese Government has expressed its willingness to support Quimonda with whatever is necessary, given the country's economic size.
Ladies and gentlemen, let's help save Quimonda, time is of the essence.

Mr President, Commissioner, we have been talking about the Lisbon Strategy for years, and the times we are living in are perhaps not the right ones to talk about the Lisbon Strategy, but we definitely need a strategy.
a strategy that responds to the difficulties and challenges that the present crisis places before us.
And that is what we expect from the Commission too.

It is essential that the Commission does not stray from this issue and instead has the capacity to coordinate actions with the governments of Portugal and the governments of Germany and the LÃ¤nder of Germany.

It is essential to keep in mind that this is an industry, as has already been mentioned here, that is of interest to Europe, due to its quality and value, the research it develops, and the environmental quality that is also associated with it. And it is essential that the Commission does not step away.
I endorse the invitation made by my colleague Peneda for the Commissioner and the Commission to visit Portugal.

It is essential that the Commission bear in mind that, at this time, Europeans are looking to Europe and expect answers from the European authorities. They need to feel that the European authorities are close by.

European citizens do not understand a Europe that washes its hands. Instead, they want a Europe that has the courage to roll up its sleeves and get to work, helping them overcome their difficulties. Thank you very much.

Mr President, thank you very much. I would also like to add my voice to the tributes to Mr Jamonet, but I asked to speak in order to congratulate the President on the statement he made on the occasion of the European Day in Memory of the Victims of Terrorism.
It was on the basis of my proposal that we adopted this approach five years ago, which the Council enshrined in a meeting on 25 March following the tragic attacks in Madrid.
but my intervention was an appeal.
Parliament has always been faithful to the celebration of this date, but unfortunately this date has not yet had, among the European institutions and the Member States, the prominence it should have.
I believe that the celebration of this date is one of the most important tools we have to honor the victims, as the President did, but also to raise a level of public awareness.
I know there are some celebrations in Madrid today, but not much else.
And therefore, the appeal I make to the Commission, to the Czech Presidency, is that all Member States celebrate this date with dignity in the future. Thank you very much.
and gentlemen, my dear colleagues, the crisis is deeper than we expected and unemployment will be higher than we predicted.
There are good reasons to assume that the planned European stimulus is not enough. But it is clear, even at this point, that it is taking too long to reach the citizens.
The Parliament's position is strong and clear. It has been and I hope it will continue to be.
Our goal is to maintain employment and create new jobs with cohesion, with solidarity, both territorial and social.
And at this time of crisis, citizens cannot be satisfied with a Europe that does not respond to them, with a Europe that is powerless in the face of the problems they are experiencing.
What is Parliament going to ask the Commission?

It naturally asks, through these reports, that it coordinate national interventions. It asks it to use all the means currently at its disposal to intervene and gives it all the conditions, as a budgetary entity, for this to happen.

asks him to launch a clear European initiative for employment. And tells him that it is important to have an agenda with a timetable to implement measures to regulate the financial market, as well as to channel credit into the real economy.
But what is being asked of the Council?
The Council is asked, above all, to rediscover the political will that is at the heart of the construction of the European project.
The European Union is competition, but it is also cohesion and solidarity.
And there can be no single market without this guarantee. Solidarity and cohesion.
This is what we all delegated, at the European level, the national autonomies that we had before joining this project. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, anyone who visits sub-Saharan Africa easily recognises the enormous weakness of their health systems in most countries and the extremely negative impact that this weakness has on the lives and health of the populations that these services are supposed to serve.
The indicators continuously disseminated at international level do not cease to confirm it.
And to that extent, the notion that simple gestures and practices that are not very elaborate, not even particularly expensive, could be enough to save many lives is absolutely disturbing.

European financial support can be crucial in this regard. And we must always keep in mind how cooperation in the health sector is truly strategic and directly affects not only one of the millennium goals, but many of the millennium goals.

Now, the Court of Auditors considered that, and I quote, "Community funding in favor of the health sector has not increased since the year 2000 in proportion to its total development aid, despite the commitments made by the Commission regarding the Millennium Goals and the health crisis in sub-Saharan Africa."
End of quote.

And it acknowledged, I quote again, that the Commission contributed significantly through its funding to establish the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but did not give the same attention to strengthening health systems, which was supposed to be one of its priorities.
End of quote.

According to the Court, this happened, I quote again, because the Commission lacked sufficient experience in health matters to ensure that the funding for classroom aid granted to this sector was used in the best possible way.
End of quote.
This is therefore a strong challenge that the Court of Auditors is launching directly at the European Commission, and one that I support.
For our part, I want to reiterate that same challenge, now sustained by the objectivity of these data and this evaluation.
Health services are already part of, but should increasingly be part of, our development aid priorities, and are deserving of an increase in their funding.

Optimizing the way aid is delivered, bearing in mind the seemingly antagonistic needs of coordination in its management and proximity to the beneficiary populations, is providing a service that can save many lives.
The European Commission cannot fail to respond positively to this challenge, and it is in this sense that I urge it.
A moment ago, our colleague Bois gave us a moving speech here and was able to put faces, human faces, on the dry coldness of these figures from the Court of Auditors.
The challenge for us, Madam Commissioner, is for our cooperation to be able to put a look of joy and hope on those same faces.
And for that, Madam Commissioner, it is essential that the numbers in the health sector in our cooperation be different.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, once again, for sad reasons, we are discussing here the situation in Guinea-Bissau, which is truly distressing.
It is a country that has been living in chronic instability for many years, which attempted a path towards democracy in the early 1990s.

Nothing has gone well; there has been a coup d'Ã©tat, a small internal war, and they are experiencing great political and military instability, deep tensions and rivalries, and now recently also the very worrying presence, increasingly evident to all observers, of drug trafficking interests.
We strongly condemn these attacks, the bombing death of the Chief of Staff, Tagumena UÃ©, and also the particularly barbaric, not to say savage, murder of President Nino Vieira.
Regardless of their past, we express our solidarity to their families, to the people of Guinea-Bissau, and we regret and strongly condemn these attacks.
We wish for a return to normalcy. And the lesson I have learned, and would like to emphasize in the resolution, is that impunity is not a remedy.
In the past, regarding the murder of Assumane ManÃ© and General VerÃ­ssimo Seabra, how is it that a blind eye was turned so that the guilty parties were not found and brought to justice?
It is evident that this is not a solution.
Therefore, we must make it clear to the State of Guinea-Bissau that those responsible must be found, the guilty must be brought to justice, and we must provide all the necessary help.

I would also like to draw attention, in conclusion, to the concern we have seen regarding the presence of drug trafficking throughout the region, the risk it already poses to the European Union, and the shocking presence, due to its evidence, in Guinea-Bissau.
I would also like to appeal for us to strengthen our relationship with Cape Verde in this context.

We have established a special partnership with Cape Verde. Cape Verde has very close relations with Guinea, a great deal of knowledge, but it is also very vulnerable. And this is also essential for our own European security.
Therefore, the intensification of the special partnership with Cape Verde is also very important in this context. Thank you very much.
Madam President, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank everyone for the work that has been celebrated.

The three lines defined in the green paper, concentration, interconnection, and cooperation, can provide solutions to some obstacles to the harmonious development of the Union, particularly the negative effects associated with the

concentration of economic activity, inequalities in access to markets and services resulting from distance, and divisions imposed by borders between Member States, particularly the most disadvantaged ones, but also between regions.
We must therefore promote the improvement of synergies between these policies with effective methods of evaluating their territorial impact.

That is why I have always advocated for the definition of additional qualitative indicators with the aim of improving the design and implementation of corresponding policies on the ground, taking into account the different territorial specificities.
For now, GDP remains the only eligibility criterion for receiving support from the structural funds.

However, this definition of additional indicators and the conduct of territorial assessments should not lead to more bureaucracy or further delays, but rather to the simplification, implementation of new policies, and support actions for territorial cohesion.
The fifth interim report and the final one, Mr. President, makes a specific reference to the transition regions located between the convergence regions and the competitiveness and employment regions.
It is important to note that these regions need to have a clearer status, with more security and stability for their development. Thank you very much.

Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, in the context of this major debate on territorial cohesion and the future of economic and social cohesion policy, I could not fail to mention the very specific problems of the outermost regions.

Regions that, due to the combination and persistence of a series of geographical factors, reveal a high level of economic and social vulnerability, particularly felt in the context of a severe international crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing.
I would therefore like to appeal to the European Commission and especially to Commissioner Huebner to pay very particular attention to the effects of the current crisis on the outermost regions.

An assessment of these effects in each of the outermost regions, particularly in tourism, construction, and the rise in unemployment, would be important to enable a specific European response for these regions.

I therefore challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis for the outermost regions, which goes beyond the measures already announced under the economic and social cohesion policy for all European regions.
A specific European response to the crisis for the outermost regions.

Mr President, dear colleagues, in response to the global financial crisis, the European Economy Partnership Plan states that cohesion policy contributes significantly to public investment by Member States and regions, and should act as a means of recovery from the current crisis.
It specifically suggests the adoption of actions in priority areas of the Lisbon strategy, in order to achieve growth and employment.
All the instruments deployed aim to achieve this purpose and accelerate the attainment of results.

In this sense, the expansion of the scope of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund and the acceleration of the European Social Fund have a particular responsibility to respond to the multiple situations of social and economic emergency that require support.
I am certain, today as in the past, that their action will be all the more effective the more complementary their actions and spheres of influence are.

However, as no new funds or new lines of action on the ground have been foreseen, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund is used to its full potential in the fight against unemployment and the rapid increase in competitive pressure in the European economy, resulting from the current financial crisis and economic slowdown.

I would like to emphasize that the Committee of the Regions has repeatedly identified simplification as essential for improving the management and implementation of structural funds, as the European Commission is now proposing.

We were urged to act quickly, however, on this matter. And when adopting this regulatory package, we took this into account. And this cause has never shied away from taking on its political responsibilities.

Therefore, despite the many views that the particularity of the moment raises, for the sake of ensuring the swiftness of the process and the real benefit to citizens that the proposal aims for, we refrain from presenting new proposals and amendments for now.

However, we would like to warn about the need to initiate, from now on, a process of evaluation of this fund, with a view to a complementary review to be carried out as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Madam President, the crisis, among other aspects, has highlighted the strong imbalances between the countries of the eurozone, perhaps the main one.

conclusion of the report on the Economic and Monetary Union, on the 10th, but above all, the extreme vulnerability of the countries that, while belonging to the European Union, do not belong to the Eurozone.

This is why strengthening the resources available at European level to support balance of payments crisis situations is absolutely essential. And this is why we welcome the increase from 12 to 25 million euros and then to 50 million euros in necessary resources.
However, it is more important to address the root causes of the problems and not just their most obvious manifestations.
Today, the enlarged Europe and the eurozone must reinterpret the meaning of European solidarity and the objectives of cohesion and real convergence.
It is necessary to view the capacity of European horizontal policies in this light, but it is also necessary to revisit new financing instruments, such as Eurobonds.
Financial assistance for the balance of payments is necessary, but it is far from sufficient to ensure the sustainability of the European project and the European single currency.
Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office, we are in an unprecedented crisis.

It was not, in fact, the time for us to discuss internally how to organize ourselves. Therefore, my wish is that the Lisbon Treaty be quickly ratified so that we can face the world stage, united and in solidarity as Europeans.

As for the economic crisis, in the report I authored and which this Parliament approved by a majority, it was acknowledged that the recovery plan, meanwhile presented by the Commission, was not sufficient.
Today we are certain that it is not enough.
A crisis that began in the financial sector extends to the real economy, then to employment, and finally becomes a social issue.
It is not sufficient and it is out of focus.

Every crisis contains an opportunity. This is the Commission's opportunity to respond to the real problems of Europeans, through serious financial regulation, not the lightest and most fragmented possible.

possible, as it is currently underway. Not made up of individualistic national plans, but of a genuine European initiative. Not through scattered means, but by focusing on the real challenge that I employ.

In every crisis there is an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission and for Europe to respond to the real problems of European citizens. And I hope that this will happen through a new approach to the relaunch plan. Thank you very much.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would just like to express, not only on behalf of the EPP, as has already been done by many Members, but particularly on behalf of the Portuguese EPP Members, our great satisfaction with the result of the referendum in Ireland.
We believe that this clearly reinforces the prospects for development and evolution of the European Union, creating conditions for a new stage.

We naturally wanted to pay tribute to all those who contributed to the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular the Commission and the Vice-President of the Commission present here, and also, of course, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union, which

it has played a very important role here and that is why we also want to say, it is with pleasure that we note that despite all these vicissitudes and while we are still waiting with anticipation for the position of the Czech Republic, it will be with great joy that the Portuguese will see the name of their capital linked

We are at a decisive step in the evolution of the European Union and I would like to say that we can also count on this perspective with another flag, which will always be a flag of the Portuguese MEPs of the EPP, which is the flag of the National Parliaments.
We argue that the Lisbon Treaty takes a decisive step towards incorporating the presence of National Parliaments into European democracy as well.

And that is why we believe that this dimension, which is the most important dimension of democracy, which is the representative dimension, and not, as we sometimes hear in this Chamber, the referendary dimension, that is what is

The fundamental and essential element of democracy is representation, not direct voting; therefore, the Lisbon Treaty is a major step towards increasing the participation of national representative democracies in the European process.
That is why we are very pleased with this decision by the Irish people.

Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, dear colleagues. A brief intervention to welcome the historic and broad result of the referendum in Ireland and to highlight the decisive role that Fine Gael and its leader and future Prime Minister of Ireland, Enda Kenny, played in taking the lead in this process.
A process in which the need to bring the European Union much closer to its citizens became very apparent.
They are, we are all, the main recipients of all the Union's actions.
It is essential that everyone is aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has on our lives on a daily basis.
Europe is our living space.
What is good for Europe is good for each Member State, it is good for its citizens.
This is certainly the case with the Lisbon Treaty.
With this treaty, it becomes much more evident that one can simultaneously be a proud and committed national citizen and a staunch defender of the European project.

And the European Union, having concluded a debate that lasted too long about its organisation and functioning, will be able to focus much more and with new, much more effective instruments on the real problems facing Europeans: competitiveness, growth and employment.
I conclude, Mr. President, Madam Minister, with a proposal for future generations.

Given the information deficit regarding the values, competences, objectives, and functioning of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of compulsory education in each Member State, a new mandatory European studies course.
In an objective, truthful and concrete way, young Europeans will effectively learn about our principles, who we are, what we do and where we want to go.

It is through knowledge, from a young age, that they will understand, throughout their lives, the potential and enormous usefulness of the European identity of this unique project of voluntary sharing of sovereignty on a continental scale.

Thank you, Mr President. Mr President of the Commission, I begin by congratulating you in this first debate on what this new instrument of political control means for the advancement and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.
It is European citizens, through their representatives, who stand to gain.

Given the latest developments, the Irish referendum, the ratification by Poland and the recent statements by the President of the Republic, Cheque, I would like to know your assessment of the process of bringing the Lisbon Treaty into force.
there have been efforts on the part of the Commission President
and what is your prediction for a possible entry into force date of the treaty, and, on the other hand, to know if at this moment and based on this prediction, the Commission

Some transition procedures have already been carried out for the treaties, from the Treaty of Nice to the Treaty of Lisbon, or is it still in a phase, let's say, of expectation, therefore in a phase of wait and see.

Mr. President of the Commission, having heard this, I would like to know the following. At this stage, when everyone is waiting for the formation of the Commission, what is the President's perspective?
the question is whether we will now have a Commission in office until that final ratification by the Czech Republic, or whether the procedures for appointing the new Commissioners will be advanced.

It is essential that the primary objective of the creation of the European External Action Service materializes the efforts of the European institutions. Ensure the creation of an effective service, capable of articulating, formulating and implementing a European response to the current international challenges.
it must also represent more than the parts that constitute it. It must be added value in relation to the current efforts of the Member States and the European Union.
In this sense, it seems essential to me that what makes the specificity of the Union is at the center of this new reality. And that specificity is the Community method.
That is why I give my full support to the BROC report, which advocates for and safeguards a close relationship between the Commission and the future service.

Creating this purpose highlights two aspects: the importance of close coordination between the President of the Commission and the High Representative, who is also Vice-President of the Commission, to ensure effectiveness and proper functioning.
Finally, there is a need for an alliance between Parliament and the Commission to combat the impending intergovernmental drift that could compromise the effective functioning of the service.
Parliament must therefore be vigilant and ensure that the European External Action Service will be a centre of excellence representing the best skills in terms of foreign policy.
Thank you, Mr. President, thank you, Commissioner. I would like to begin by emphasizing the importance of this issue raised by Mr. Goularantes, because it is a matter of the most basic justice.

We all know perfectly well that in a situation of an A flu pandemic, it will be the countries of the South that will suffer the most from this problem and from the consequences of the virus's proliferation, not the countries of the North.

And every year we passively witness the death of millions of citizens as a result of pandemics that have either been eradicated or have treatments available in the Northern countries. An immense list: malaria, dengue, yellow fever, tuberculosis.
we have no limits to this list and we passively watch this problem unfold.

We effectively use the countries of the South as free suppliers of samples of new virus strains so that we can improve treatment in the countries of the North, but we still have no effective response to these problems. And so, to the questions that have been raised, I would just like to add a few more.
We want to effectively treat this problem as a public health issue or as a business.
Because if it is a public health problem, we have to ensure equal access to treatment in all regions of the world, and for that, efforts have to be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to ask, and I hope this is not the case, if we are waiting for vaccine stocks in Europe to become so overcrowded,
that the side effects prove to be so negative in this plan, so that we then have an act of generosity and suddenly start sending necessary vaccines to the countries of the South.

And finally, I just wanted to ask if the European Union, if we Europeans and the Commission, are comfortable with a system or a model where northern countries deal with pandemics through a prevention model, and in the southern countries it is treated as palliatives or only with leftovers.

Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I want to express my full support regarding the issue raised by Mr. Roel and, above all, highlight the underlying issue, the fundamental political issue at hand, which precisely concerns the joint programming of research.

What happened with the joint programming on neurodegenerative diseases and particularly on Alzheimer's was that halfway through the process the rules were changed, we stopped having a report and started having a resolution, so our capacity for co-decision on this matter was eliminated, we stopped being deputies and became consultants.
And so, I would like to know whether at least what we recommend will be taken into consideration or not.
The programming of research activities, in whatever field, is a political choice, not a technical one. And in this sense, the role of Parliament must be valued and reinforced.
It seems to me that setting priorities that are political means that they must be scrutinized, that they must be transparent, and that they must be democratic.
What happened with the process regarding the joint decision and joint programming of Alzheimer's research is a process that should not be repeated, and if it happens again,

Please repeat that they should notify us in advance. I therefore hope that the last thing that could happen to us is that the decisions and recommendations that Parliament has presented on this matter are not taken into account.
Mr. Deputy, last month the regions of Europe were particularly prominent.
The European Week dedicated to regions and cities has built the position of regions as a fundamental part of the solution in the European response to global challenges.
This was concluded, leaving no room for doubt, by President DurÃ£o Barroso, Commissioner Samesky, and the hundreds of debates that took place.

At a more specific level, the important meeting of the Conference of Presidents of the Uto-Poriferean Regions of Europe, which for the first time included the participation of Members of the European Parliament, marked a milestone in regional policy in favor of European construction.
Global challenges and European responses constitute a great opportunity for a new strategy for ASRUP.

These regions, such as the Azores, in addition to the permanent constraints that everyone is accustomed to hearing about, present a set of potentialities that offer clear opportunities to achieve our progress and give Europe a clear advantage in new areas essential to responding to global challenges.

And that is why I said that the President of the Commission puts a clear end to the palace coup that the Commission's no paper indicates was being prepared while we were getting European deputies and citizens to advocate for the ratification of the Lisbon Treaty and its importance in defending the cohesion of the European territory.

I would first of all like to commend the rapporteurs, particularly Mr Martin and also Mr Corbett, and say that as a member of the PPE, I basically agree with the proposed changes to the rules of procedure.
I would essentially like to emphasize the point that I think is important here and that has not yet been brought up this evening, which is the point of the National Parliaments.

The democratic strengthening of the European Parliament undoubtedly results from this regulation and the Treaty of Lisbon, but European democracy also results from the connection to the National Parliaments.
And what this regulation, this proposal is now doing is precisely to create these two democratic legitimacies, to strengthen democracy.

On the one hand, democracy resulting from the instruments of the European Parliament, its control instruments, its legislative capacity, and on the other hand, the democratic collaboration of the National Parliaments through different instruments.
And that's why I'm here, so to speak, totally in tune with the proposals made.
I do not agree with my colleague Mr Duff when he says that we should postpone the introduction of mechanisms for relations with the National Parliaments.
I swear that we can do this right now in the light of the Treaty of Lisbon and that this is very important.
I would also like to say that I support the proposal of my colleagues Sayer and Brock regarding representation in COSAC and, finally, that I am
I fully agree with the comments made here by my colleague Broc and other colleagues about the primacy of Parliament and its Members over Parliament's services.
Thank you very much, Mr President, Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I congratulate my fellow rapporteur on the work done on this report and on her speech just now.
This new microfinance instrument will allow for the granting of microcredit to small businesses and to people who have lost their jobs and want to create their own business and their own job.
This is very important at a time when the economic crisis is expected to result in the loss of 3.5 million jobs in the European Union alone.

As a consequence of the economic slowdown, banks have stopped granting loans for job creation and business start-ups, and access to credit is more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.
Now, this new microfinance means will counteract the current trend of restricting access to credit, making it easier to obtain the necessary funds for launching new businesses and creating new jobs.
The European Commission's proposal aims to reallocate 100 million euros from the Progress Programme Budget to this financing instrument.
We cannot agree with this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is also a social crisis.
Thus, reallocating resources from progress that targets the most vulnerable groups is not at all the most appropriate solution.
For this reason, it supports the creation of a separate budget line to finance this instrument, as well as an increase in the allocation to 150 million euros.

We also agree with the need to clarify in the legislation itself that the target group is vulnerable groups who have difficulty entering or re-entering the labor market and who face the threat of social exclusion.
Therefore, the reference to specific groups should be suppressed.
Finally, we emphasize that it is essential that people who have financial support also have adequate training. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr President. I would like to start by congratulating the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, Prime Minister Reinfeldt, both on behalf of the EPP and on behalf of the Portuguese EPP delegation.
Our assessment of the Swedish presidency is one of almost complete success, essentially in four key areas.
First, in the institutional area, the Swedish Presidency's contribution to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, and to the very successful election of the President of the Commission.
was, in particular, extremely professional in dealing with all ratification issues and was in line with what is expected, the best practices of the European Union.
Naturally, for a country like Portugal, which played a decisive role in the approval of the Lisbon Treaty, this contribution from the Swedish presidency is invaluable.
A second point is the climate agenda, where the Commission's work was also naturally very important.
We must say that, from my point of view and from the point of view of many EPP deputies, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has been most successful.
it is there at the very forefront of the global fight and that is due to the efforts of both the Swedish presidency and, in particular, the presidency of the Commission
we also consider this balance to be very positive.

A third point is the issue of financial regulation, which, especially with this last Council, took a step that we consider decisive and which could have a very significant impact on the exit from the crisis.
And therefore, I would also like to congratulate you on this achievement of having reached an agreement in this area.
And finally, I would like to say a word about an area that personally means a lot to me, which is the Stockholm Programme and, therefore, the area of security, justice and freedom.

I believe that those of us who have followed both the Temper process and, in particular, the Daia process afterwards, consider this Stockholm Programme absolutely essential, and I would like to congratulate the Swedish Presidency and Prime Minister Reinfeldt for this.

Thank you very much, Mr President. The recognition of professional qualifications was consolidated into a single legislative act, as is known, from 15 directives, which led to various practical problems in application in the different Member States.

The difficulties are known and the Commission should identify the critical points and carry out an analysis of the problematic areas that arise in the application of this important internal market provision.
Protectionism, which manifests itself at various levels, constitutes an obstacle not only to the free movement of people, but also to the internal market.
we must try to identify the unclear points so that the effectiveness of the directive is not undermined by mistrust.
The Union is not being asked to do what the Member States should do, but there is an effort to be made to facilitate this, which helps to break down professional corporatism.
An improvement in the application of this Directive should involve promoting the recognition of qualifications in the Solvit network and the EURES network by encouraging
common platforms, implementation of effective contact points and, not least, it should provide an articulation of this Directive with the Services Directive. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner, and Honorable Members. It is urgent that we promote a debate about the Community Budget and how we can contribute to its sustainability and transparency in the future.

The post-2013 financial framework must be built on the basis of solidarity and territorial cohesion, values that are crucial for regions like Madeira, which face permanent difficulties and therefore require ongoing support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I believe should always be present when thinking about and building cohesion policy.

The Commission has repeatedly mentioned several aspects that I consider essential, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency, and a more results-oriented approach in the definition and implementation of this policy.
But there are issues that give me some concern, especially considering the needs of the outermost regions.
In this matter, allow me three brief notes. First, the current approach in terms of regions should prevail over alternative guidelines, such as value-added sectors, for example.

A reorientation like this could undermine Objective 2, which currently benefits about two-thirds of European regions, and could potentially be counterproductive in regions with very specific economic profiles and competitive advantages. Secondly, I believe that maintaining the proximity criterion in cohesion policy is vital.

structural fund allocation and management should continue to be prioritised from a regional perspective, rather than a national or even centralised European perspective. Thirdly, and last but not least, I would like to recall and emphasise Article 349.
The Lisbon Treaty provides for special treatment of the outermost regions with regard to access to structural funds, precisely because of their economic and social situation.
exacerbated by perennial conditionings and unique characteristics, which manifest themselves in those constant difficulties and therefore require the requested permanent aid. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. In the face of urgency, what we witnessed in Copenhagen was several steps backward.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than others, but it also created more divisions. And as a result, what happened was that we ended up with a situation of every man for himself, where each state can define its own goals and, on top of that, in a voluntary regime.
It should be noted that having a 2-degree Celsius target or funding goals without any clarification cannot serve as a consolation for us either.
And so what I think is that we have to act in terms of the future. And acting in terms of the future is to stop moving from rhetoric to action.
The European Union has always wanted to be a leader, it has always stated so.
But when we arrived in Copenhagen, he ended up hesitating, neither defining nor defending the goals he stated here as his own and which he would not abandon.

And so, what I ask is whether we will be any more just in the future, whether we will continue to allow the poorest to pay the heaviest bill at the cost of this failure and the decisions made by some over others.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I wanted to denounce here what is happening in Portugal at the moment, where it is clear that the media
A government plan to control newspapers, to control television stations, to control radio stations has come to light, which jeopardizes freedom of expression.
This week, a well-known journalist, MÃ¡rio Crespo, had one of his columns censored, also at the suggestion or apparent suggestion of the Prime Minister.

In light of this, Prime Minister JosÃ© SÃ³crates must provide substantial explanations to the country. He must explain that he is not dominating, restricting, or censoring freedom of expression in Portugal.

At this rate, Portugal is no longer a state governed by the rule of law, but a formal state governed by the rule of law, where the Prime Minister confines himself to formalities, procedures, and formalism, and does not want to provide substantial explanations.
For Portugal, we want a material State of Law.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. The Green Paper for the reform of the common fisheries policy, for which my colleague from the Azores, Maria do CÃ©u PatrÃ£o Neves, is the rapporteur, is a unique opportunity for a debate on a sector that is of great importance for the balanced development of local communities in the outermost regions.

Madara is following the ongoing discussion with particular interest and believes it is imperative to propose a differentiation between artisanal and industrial fleets, which should benefit from different fishing regimes.
It is essential to defend a principle of positive discrimination in terms of limiting access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone only to local artisanal fleets.
In Madeira, support for the modernization of vessels is a priority, as is management that ensures the conservation of a comprehensive group of species in the long term.
Only in this way will we be able to avoid situations that are unsustainable for economic, environmental, and social balance.
Finally, let us hope that fisheries in the outermost regions receive permanent support, not time-limited aid.
This ERDF report aims to extend the eligibility of housing interventions in favor of marginalized communities in our Member States.
Until now, this support has only applied to marginalized communities living in urban areas of the new member states.
That is, since the vast majority of these types of communities live in rural areas and in shelters, these communities could not benefit from support to replace poor-quality housing.
It is, in essence, about how to kill a vaccine and give Member States and their regions greater possibilities in the policy of mitigating the specific difficulties of these communities.
Health and equal treatment for all Member States, because marginalized communities with support and integration needs deserve our concern, regardless of the Member State they belong to.

By concluding at first reading this important report on the fight against poverty and for human dignity, we are also ensuring its rapid implementation within the framework of the economic partnership plan, providing a timely response to the crisis that affects us.

Thank you very much, Mr President. Commissioner, allow me to begin by highlighting the role of the rapporteur, Mr Vandistel Roy, for his work in seeking consensus on this matter and also for his willingness to incorporate other contributions into his report.
Tomorrow we will vote on amendments to the ERDF Regulation that are of particular importance for the so-called old Member States and also for Portugal.

These changes will allow the use of the ERDF in the housing sector to be extended in favor of marginalized communities, since currently this fund can only be allocated to urban development operations.

The amendments that I proposed together with other colleagues and which were approved by a large majority in the Committee on Regional Development will allow the old Member States, and not just the new ones, as the original proposal provided, to also benefit from this possibility of funding.

With this, I tried to prevent the opening of a precedent that I consider dangerous and that would exclude all the former Member States from this and, probably, from other additional uses of Community aid.
That would not make any sense, since housing problems, especially among marginalized communities, exist in both new and old member states.
I take this opportunity to reiterate that the seniority of EU membership should not be a criterion for the allocation of structural funds and that this criterion should be definitively abandoned.

The negotiation of the post-2013 cohesion policy must be based on solidarity, aiming at territorial cohesion, and should be oriented towards rewarding rather than punishing regions that have shown exemplary use of Community aid.
I wanted at this point to essentially underline to the Commission and to the President of the Commission the way they have worked with this Parliament over these months of investiture.
There is no executive body in the world with legislative initiative capacity that is subject to its President presenting a program before Parliament, and holding a hearing with all the groups.

parliamentarians to a vote by an absolute majority, to bring here all the commissioners to be heard one by one with their own agenda, with three to four hours of direct questions, of questions with answers.
to someone who agreed to negotiate a framework agreement with Parliament, in which they agreed, first of all, to justify and expand Parliament's powers in the area of legislative initiative.

which accepted the principle of full access to information, both in legislative and political action and in international negotiations, which accepted taking into account Parliament's opinion on the commissioners, on the reshuffling of the commissioners.

This means, once and for all and from my point of view, that the Commission has demonstrated, from July to the present, that it is willing to have a close relationship with Parliament and that, in doing so, it

has made it clear, evident, and unequivocal that the strategic alliance of the Lisbon Treaty for the Community method that my colleague SÃ¡rio Zewoski spoke of is the alliance between Parliament and the Commission.
And that is why the Commission and the Framework Agreement deserve the full support of the EPP.
Five years after the Orange Revolution, Ukrainians seem to look back on this period as a missed opportunity.
And it's not just the fault of their political elites.
It is certain that they consumed themselves too much in wars of power and influence.
As many reforms were not implemented, many did not go beyond the paper.
It is inconceivable that in any democracy electoral laws should be changed between the two rounds of an election.
does not dignify those who proposed them, those who voted for them, or those who promulgated them.
and translates the intentions that are not praiseworthy or recommendable in its genesis.
And there is much that needs to change regarding the lack of independence of the judiciary, which is subject to too much influence not only from political power but also from economic agents.
Without a free and independent judiciary, there is no rule of law, human rights are not guaranteed, there is no foreign investment, there is no progress.
But the blame for this disenchantment also lies very much with this Parliament and, essentially, with many Member States.
