I would like us to imagine, for a few seconds, that we are in the shoes of a citizen of a European country that, due to the vicissitudes of history, is not yet a member of the European Union.
what we would expect from the Union.
Solidarity.

But many chancelleries, with the sole concern of not annoying and displeasing Moscow, have used and abused the permanent internal struggles in Kiev to avoid stating, in an unequivocal way, that Ukraine is an independent and sovereign country.

As such, if this is the freely expressed will of the majority of its people and provided that it meets the established criteria, Ukraine may aspire to become a member of the European Union in the future.

I would like to emphasize that in island regions, air transport is sometimes the only possibility of access and that the operating conditions are conditioned by the size of their passenger and cargo flows.

If there are regions in Soares where the abundance of these flows is appealing to many air operators, attracting competition and low transport prices, thus improving accessibility, there are others, such as the Azores, where these flows are still limited and not attractive to operators' interest.

As a result, air fares are higher, constituting an obstacle to population mobility and a limiting factor in attracting tourists that would allow this enormous potential for development and diversification of its economic base to flourish and consolidate.
This framework is particularly penalizing in times of crisis like the one we are going through.

This is why temporary support is crucial to encourage an increase in flows so that the market can start to function, while also sharing these regions of high tourist potential with the objectives of the trans-European networks in bringing the peripheries of Europe closer together.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I speak today in this Chamber with a voice choked by the dismay of someone who personally lived through and witnessed the tragedy that struck Madeira last Saturday.
My words are, of course, to join in the feeling of grief and mourning that has affected the families of the 42 fatalities, to whom I pay my respects and honor their losses.

The true extent of this catastrophe is yet to be revealed, as search and rescue teams, who have been working tirelessly since Saturday in a Herculean effort that I commend, are only now beginning to reach the most isolated populations.
and it is feared that the number of victims may increase.

The scene is one of large-scale destruction, with extensive material damage to access roads, highways, and completely devastated areas, as well as to essential services such as water supply and electricity.
There are about 600 displaced people who have lost their homes and personal belongings.
The economic and social impact of this catastrophe prevents people from resuming a normal course of life.
But we must now look forward.
I also need to convey a message of solidarity, hope, and trust to people.
Help is needed. And it is in this chapter that the European Union and Parliament in particular have a say. They are crucial in the process of mobilizing the Solidarity Fund.
And when we are called upon to intervene, we have to do it quickly, because we cannot ask people to wait, especially when they need us the most.
I appeal to the Commission and its President, Dr. Barroso, especially to the Commissioner for Regional Development, Johan Assane, and I welcome their initiative to visit Madeira as soon as possible.
Asking him to also be the bearer of this message of hope, of help and support for reconstruction. Because now is the time to rebuild what nature, unfortunately, once again took from us.
But I am sure we will do it. Because, as the Madeiran anthem taught me, the people of Madeira are humble, stoic and brave.
It is the people who have tilled the land between the hard rock. They are the heroes of labor in the rugged mountains.
Through wood it will honor its history and on the path of work it will fight and achieve its well-being and glory.
We begin today's plenary session with a minute of silence.

And it was a minute of silence with two meanings: one of solidarity with the victims of this catastrophe that devastated Madeira and their families, and a sense of tribute to all the workers who have been providing assistance to these victims tirelessly.
But the minute of silence should make us reflect and should also lead to a reflection that goes beyond what we are doing here.
What we saw in Madeira is a phenomenon that will tend to repeat itself more and more.
Climate change causes extreme phenomena to recur, and we must have responses to them.
We cannot prevent natural disasters, but we should not be condemned to always have to suffer their dramatic effects on people's lives.
That is why we must fight for planning and zoning policies that are oriented towards the public good.

But I want to emphasize, Mr. President, that what is most important and what brought us here is that the European Commission, the European Parliament, and the European institutions must have the capacity to respond urgently to an emergency situation. And for that, we need the necessary financial resources and the necessary speed.
A tribute of solidarity to the families and friends of the victims of Saturday's tragic events on Madeira Island.
As an Azorean, as a Portuguese and as a European, I cannot help but appeal to Parliament and the Union to show their active solidarity with the Autonomous Region of Madeira and its people.
It is in the regions that the Union's presence needs to be felt, and it is precisely in these moments when its solidarity is most needed that it is also most important for it to be felt.

I also want to express my solidarity with the pain of the people of Madeira and insistently ask the European institutions, and in particular the Commission, to unlock all available resources, all means at their disposal, to provide this aid.
I would also like to emphasize that when there is a disaster of this kind, it is much more difficult to address its consequences when it occurs in poor countries and poor regions.

But in the case of wood, we must also take into account that the economic base of wood is directly affected by the fact that, depending on tourism, it has a double consequence when its natural beauty, its access, and its quality of life are all destroyed.

Therefore, there is indeed a different situation when we have problems of this severity in poor countries and poor regions, and in particular in mountainous and tourist regions, as is the case with Madeira.
Therefore, it is absolutely essential that all the adaptations that were planned and requested, and that were mentioned here regarding the Solidarity Fund, do not wait any longer.

they must come into effect immediately, because unfortunately, due to climate change and these processes, they will be repeated, especially in the poorest regions of Europe, which are those that experience torrential rainfall in terms of water and extreme drought during the summer. Thank you very much once again, Mr. President.
Commissioner and Council, we are talking here about reinventing the energy system on a European scale through investment in low-carbon technologies.
I think it is one of the very important challenges, as is mentioned in the communication that is made.
and it is one of the challenges we have to address centrally. But there is no clarification here, hence the importance of raising these questions and asking for clarification.
It seems that not only the clarification of funding is lacking, but also the political clarification is missing.
There is talk of energy efficiency, carbon capture, nuclear, biofuels, solar energy, and even of energy efficiency as the cheapest way to reduce emissions.
it surprises me that there are other, much cheaper ways to reduce carbon emissions that are not even mentioned in this communication, such as, for example, reducing greenhouse gas consumption.
microgeneration, distribution and different forms of distribution and different projects that do not have to go through large structures, and access to energy.
I think that would certainly contribute to more financial clarity to make the plan cheaper.

And therefore, within this political clarification and within this financial clarification, there is still a need to talk about what I believe to be an absolutely important point, which is the emphasis that is constantly placed on public-private partnerships as if they were the solution to everything.
When we ask where the money comes from, they tell us from the Commission that it comes from where it is.
I confess that I am no longer enlightened by being told that the money will come from somewhere without being told exactly where it is.

And therefore, with this reliance on public-private partnerships, which is systematically made when we talk about low-carbon technologies, we are left with one certainty. We don't know where the money comes from, and knowing that they are public or private partnerships, we know in advance who will pay.
Taxpayers will pay for it at the beginning, and consumers, who also happen to be taxpayers, will pay for it in the end.

And we know that those who pay the least are the parties, it is the private institutions and organizations that make the investment, are remunerated for it, but in the end they end up monopolizing the profits.
And without this clarification, it seems to me that once again we are systematically passing on the bill for the change in the European energy model to future generations.

Thank you, Mr. President. The European Union recently celebrated an agreement with Latin American countries within the framework of the World Trade Organization, in which it committed to substantially and progressively reduce tariffs on banana imports from those countries.

I would like to draw your attention to the fact that such an agreement has directly negative effects on European banana producers, particularly on banana producers in Madeira, Portugal, but also, and even more intensely, on those in the Canary Islands, Spain.

I would like to remind you that the situation of producers in these regions is already seriously hampered by the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and the size of their farms, which leads them to face permanent difficulties that penalize their development.

It is therefore urgent to take measures in defense of banana, timber and canary producers, taking into account the serious and immediate impact that the new Geneva Agreement will have on the European import market and, consequently, on the production and marketing of bananas from these outermost regions.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I would like to begin by
I would like to congratulate the Member who supported you, even in your forced absence, and highlight the way you managed to draw up this important report, facilitating the main objective.
I would also like to congratulate Ms. Creel for the presentation she gave us.
This main objective is, without further ado, to simplify procedures and accelerate the implementation of programs funded by the Cohesion Fund, the Structural Funds, and the Regional Development Fund.
In the context of the current financial, economic and social crisis, the pressure on national financial resources has been increasing.
This pressure will decrease with better use of community funding, with these resources reaching the beneficiaries most affected by the economic downturn more quickly.
More than 20 million Europeans are unemployed, which is 4 million more than a year ago. And, unfortunately, the trend is to increase.

This situation requires ensuring the proper execution of cohesion programs, as they represent the most powerful and relevant lever of aid to the real economy, particularly in small and medium-sized enterprises and employment.
SMEs are the driving force of the European economy and the key players in sustainable growth and job creation in terms of both quantity and quality.

The continuation of simplification and clarification of the rules governing cohesion policy will undoubtedly have a positive impact on the pace of programme implementation, particularly because it will
national, regional and local authorities, the possibility of using clearer and less bureaucratic rules that will allow more flexibility in adapting programmes to new challenges. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Of course this crisis was an unforeseen crisis and of course the precautionary principle had to take priority.
But there are lessons to be learned, and the first is that for five days, no sufficiently strong and politically responsible European voice was heard.
And that voice was missed when it came to defending passengers' interests, clarifying their rights, seeking transport alternatives, and coordinating solutions.

A second conclusion is that the way out of the crisis cannot appear, in the eyes of the average citizen, to be a power struggle between those who want to avoid losses and those who want to defend the precautionary principle.
There must be clear transparency and clear objectivity regarding the conditions under which one exits a situation of full coverage of the European space.
And that is why the improvement of scientific tests and coordination at the level...

Thank you, Mr. President. I also want to begin by congratulating my colleague Tikal on her work and persistence on this very important dossier, and for her efforts to improve the energy performance of buildings and to create a more sustainable Europe.
Energy consumption in the European Union, as we know, is far above what is acceptable, which is why moving forward with proposals of this nature is so important.
It is high time we had an ambitious policy in European terms and that we added to this ambitious policy complementary measures, especially in the crisis situation in which we live.
The construction sector is considered one of the markets with the greatest potential in terms of energy savings, but that's not all.
And that's not all, and that's why it's an excellent sector for the implementation of public policies. And it's in this sense that I would like to conclude, Mr. President.
We must therefore seize this opportunity that is given to invest in improving the energy efficiency of buildings and their potential for creating millions of jobs in the coming years.
and it is not only about new buildings, but also about the rehabilitation and recovery of existing buildings that are degraded or inadequate.

Let us therefore use this legislation as a fundamental contribution to the revival of the European economy and we cannot continue to waste the investment that can and should be strategic for recovery from the crisis. Let us hope that there will be investment from the Commission and that the Member States will know how to take advantage of that investment. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Mr Mandas on the work he has done on this report, and also to thank the colleagues who have collaborated with him on this dossier.

In fact, the mere fact that this proposal simplifies and improves the existing regulatory framework, bringing together all existing legislation, three basic directives on the naming and labeling of textile products, in a single regulation, is an important fact in itself.

But beyond that, this proposal will have a positive impact on private agents and public authorities and will also allow for the framing of new developed fibers, thus encouraging innovation in the textile and clothing sector.
This revision will also enhance the transparency of the process of adding new fibers to the list of harmonized fiber names.
There seems to be no doubt that the agents involved will benefit from this regulation.
Let's see, the textile industry will benefit from a reduction in administrative costs and the possibility of marketing new fibers earlier.
For their part, the authorities of the Member States will not need to transpose the amendments into national legislation, which will enable a significant cost saving for these Member States.
And consumers will have the assurance that the fibers designated meet specific characteristics, while also benefiting from the fact that the new fibers reach the market sooner.
It is important for the European industry to introduce these new fibers as a way to promote innovation, while also increasing the level of information provided to consumers.
In the current context of a globalized world, with emerging economies and increasingly expanded markets, in which millions of products produced by millions of companies circulate,
The focus on innovation and the speed at which this innovation reaches consumers is absolutely crucial for companies, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
that the application of this regulation may increase its competitiveness.
These small and medium-sized enterprises will certainly benefit from this new regulation, gaining market share and, in this way, will contribute to increased employment in Europe.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Madam Minister, Sir Commissioner. The shortage of organs for transplantation is a major problem.

It has been mentioned here several times, and it is a major problem that raises issues related to public health, as well as associated issues such as the strengthening of the parallel market and organ trafficking, which does nothing to enhance our health systems or our citizens.

And so we have to fight this crime and fight it through legislation of proposals like the ones we are discussing here. It is a way, it seems to me, more than important and more than relevant and that is why I want to focus on the dimensions and the most important issues raised by these two proposals.
Because the system we have so far, not having these two proposals, is a system of enormous inequalities.
inequalities between member states, inequalities between existing systems, inequalities in access to organs, inequalities between citizens that to me seem like we cannot endure and
Therefore, it is important to emphasize that these inequalities are decreasing. And these proposals aim to combat precisely that.
I think a European system that still maintains some specific features of some countries so that they are not forced to have more restrictive systems is the answer to this problem.
And the work that has been developed by the rapporteurs, Mr. NicolÃ¡s Ic and Mr. Perello Rodrigues, are works of extreme importance and contribution to this problem that we face.
If we are talking about proposals that are based on and supported by issues such as donation, volunteering, free services, confidentiality, and data protection,

Traceability, responsibility, and here I think it is important, on the side of Parliament, that it goes as far as the patient's recovery and not just as far as donation, and cooperation between Member States, I think we are on the right track.
I must just point out, however, and in relation to donations between living individuals, I am pleased with the inclusion and the expansion, this expansion made with rights.

Obviously, ensuring all rights and conditions is important, but it is crucial to go beyond the restricted cycle of the conventional family, because otherwise, it would just be another way of having other forms of equality.

Therefore, promoting the DAD and the Main Transplant Fund and protecting patient data and safety seem to me to be more than sufficient reasons for us all to come together tomorrow and vote in favor of these two proposals of extreme importance to humanity.

President, Minister and Commissioner, the ability to replace deteriorated human organs with organs from another person, preventing their rejection, is one of the great successes of contemporary medicine.

European benchmarking reveals that medium-sized countries like Portugal perform very well in such comparisons, and larger countries like Spain are now recognized as organizational leaders and promoters of best practices.
some principles and practices to safeguard.

First, the reinforcement of scientific knowledge and information that will lead more donors to donate while still alive and to generalize post-mortem donation. Second, the prohibition of the commercialization of the drug.

not only within the Member States but also outside them, preventing transplant tourism and combating organ trafficking. Thirdly, proactive promotion of donation in hospitals, as a way to overcome the shortage.

Finally, Madam President, ensuring equal access to transplantation for all those who need it and qualify for it according to harmonized clinical criteria, in compliance with the principle of universal access to health, the paradigm of the Social Europe, of which we are proud.
I congratulate the rapporteurs on the work they have done.
I would like to emphasize that it is with great satisfaction that the European People's Party and the Portuguese Members of the Party
The European public is about to witness the beginning of this accession process, of the European Union's accession to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We, after all, a country like Portugal, which has always been at the forefront of human rights, with the abolition of slavery in Portugal as early as 1761, with its pioneering role in the abolition of the death penalty, can obviously only be interested and supportive of this accession process.

I would, however, like to draw attention to the fact that it is very important for the European Parliament to follow every step of the European Union's accession negotiations to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We consider this aspect, from a technical, legal and political point of view, to be fundamental because Parliament is also a home of human rights and a place where human rights are of great importance. And I would just like to make a point that we consider to be very important.

For us, Members of the European Parliament, who are in contact with many states outside the European Union, it is very important, it is a very good sign that we give to the members of the Council of Europe the entry of the European Union, to the members of the Council of Europe who are not members of the European Union.
For these members of the Council of Europe, this is a sign of the European Union's increased commitment to their situation and to the levels of democracy and respect for fundamental rights.

Madam President and Commissioner, Social Housing is an economic service of general interest with an important role in the market, creating positive externalities for the benefit of the whole of society.
According to Protocol 26, annexed to the Lisbon Treaty, it is the responsibility of national, regional and local authorities to implement and organise these types of services.
Hence, the restriction of the target audience to families with incomes below 33 thousand euros is hard to understand.

This is a measurement of poverty that is made in absolute and purely financial terms, which does not take into account the diversity of the 27 member states, and is reduced to a simple argument of solvency.
Now, social housing addresses cultural and social issues, proximity to the workplace, the important redefinition of women's role in the market, and the mobility of workers in the European space.
The struggle that the European Union is waging to emerge from the current crisis involves economic growth, which entails an increase in immigration and ethnic minorities.
economic and cultural, and by the need for their integration, even with the associated risks of ghettoization that we must combat with a fair balance.
Is the Commission not encroaching on the area of competence of the Member States?

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, allow me, Madam President, to point out that we are debating the first report of the Committee on Agriculture, subject to the new ordinary legislative procedure provided for by the Treaty of Lisbon.
This is a historic moment that, if this House confirms the voting sense I propose, will begin in the best way this new period of shared competence in agricultural matters in the European Union.
I speak precisely with Algezi's representative about its outermost regions in a practical demonstration of the will to build a Union that is strengthened by cohesion
in the spirit of active solidarity, with respect for the specificities and differences of its parts, as the only viable path for building our common European project.

I also speak about introducing fundamental regulations to make the already century-old sugar industry viable in the Azores, the region I come from, which is why I am particularly pleased, thereby contributing to a
healthy agricultural diversification in a region where the dairy sector occupies, as we know, a unique dimension on a national scale, irreplaceable, which we must sustain and consolidate.

Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for Jealousy and the senior officials of the Commission with whom we have worked and negotiated for the openness and flexibility they have shown.
The Spanish Presidency of the Council also made every effort to ensure that our shared desire to reach an agreement at first reading became a reality.

This thanks is, of course, extendable to the shadow rapporteurs of the other political groups, as well as to the excellent staff of the Secretariat of the Committee on Agriculture of this Parliament, whose collaboration allowed us to reach a result that I consider very positive.

I would also like to emphasize the decisive contribution played by the Agricultural Federation of the Azores and the Regional and National Governments in the way they got involved and committed to finding a solution for Azores sugar.

The presentation of the proposed Council regulation on October 2 in the Committee on Agriculture took place at a time when there were no prospects for the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, which was still awaiting ratification by all member states.
In this context, the initial idea of the Commission and the Council was that the proposal would be approved in a simplified process, without any changes, to take effect from January 1, 2010.

With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon and despite the prevailing opinion at the time from other political groups, as well as from the Council and the Commission, that the proposal should remain in a simplified procedure, because they believed that

the proposal did not require any changes and should come into force quickly. Although I shared this opinion, I and the Socialist and Democrat group understood that Parliament should already have expressed its opinion under the Lisbon Treaty, assuming its role as co-legislator.

We did so at the right time because new possibilities opened up from there, first with the contribution of the Regional Development Commission and the opinion of my colleague Nuno Teixeira, whom I would also like to thank for his

I would like to congratulate and thank you for the cooperation you have always provided throughout this process and for my report introducing the new possibilities for sugar in the Azores, as well as for the contribution and support of my colleagues on the Committee on Agriculture.

I would like to say, finally, in this first speech, that, despite the amendments proposed by the Committee on Regional Development and voted on in the Committee on Agriculture, which I supported, we were unable to get them accepted in the compromise reached in the trialogue.

It was essential to obtain a commitment at first reading, thus safeguarding the improvements already achieved and the need for entry into force, in order not to compromise its retroactivity since January of this year.
However, since the Commission is already preparing a document to review POSEI, we will certainly have the opportunity to debate them again soon.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. We are facing an acceleration of a global change that has devastating consequences for our economic, political and social systems and, consequently, for all our citizens.
Today we have witnessed an unprecedented weakening of the response capacity of states.
The European Union must therefore identify common causes and allies and act clearly and united on the world stage.
Extraordinary situations require lucidity in joint action.

If we do not take the necessary measures of rigor and collective accountability, Europe will be doomed to marginalization and impoverishment. And only a strong Europe, respectful of its common rules, will be able to adequately respond to the new times.
Weak and indebted states do not have the capacity to protect their citizens.

Because, having achieved this, we need to be able to regain the citizens' trust, win the battles of stability, budgetary discipline, job creation, stability of the Monetary Union, globalization and strategic choices.
This is at the risk of our future being compromised.
And the future is won by betting on social cohesion, ensuring peace, and building a new model based on the values of freedom, social justice, and responsibility.
Thus, the 2020 Strategy and the Europe 2020 integrated guidelines are essential instruments for a new cycle of growth and employment in Europe.
For proper implementation and achievement, it is necessary to define quantifiable and clear objectives in employment, education, and poverty reduction.

It is also crucial for the success of the strategy that everything is done to facilitate the transposition by the Member States of their national objectives and to ensure the correct implementation of this strategy. Thank you very much.
When the Economic and Monetary Union turned 10, the Commission considered the Euro the Union's most successful project.
Today we would find it difficult to affirm this without limitations, because the crisis has shown that the Economic and Monetary Union is an unfinished project.
Minimal life-saving measures were taken in an emergency climate, but let us not be mistaken. The conditions of pressure, the direct interests of the main...
Member countries. The painful nature of the decisions, their slowness, have weakened the image of the euro and the European Union in the eyes of citizens and the world.
Facts must be faced.
The European Union and the Euro are an integration process, they are not merely inter-country cooperation.
They are an unfinished process that at this moment is either being reinforced or is at serious risk of disappearing.
There are three issues that need to be addressed. First, it is important to consolidate the instruments that have been launched in this climate of emergency. A monetary fund must be created.

In Europe, we need to move forward with Eurobonds, we need to move forward with the European supervisory and regulatory architecture, and we need to move forward with a European dimension in the management of banking crises.
Second, it is important to realize that there is no strong currency if the economy is weak. The 1% growth predicted for the European Union is unsustainable in terms of...
both in terms of its demographic composition and in terms of combating unemployment. The 2020 Strategy is nothing more than a set of good ideas if it does not have the means to implement them.

Third dimension, Mr. Commissioner Olli Rehn, fiscal consolidation is important, but it cannot coexist with growing divergences among the member states that make up the Union. The convergence policy must be urgently revisited. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Several colleagues here from the PPF have already provided a very comprehensive overview of the situation.
I believe that it is now necessary to demand and make a reference to the role of the Nation States.
In fact, national governments also have a role to play here in imposing requirements within their own states.
and the conditions for the single currency to be strengthened and for this project of monetary and economic integration to be carried forward.
And here I would like to say that our party, the party linked to the EPP, which is the PSD in Portugal, is supporting the government in the austerity measures, because we believe

the mistakes that the Socialist Government has made in Portugal over these 15 years, which unfortunately are now visible to everyone, need to be corrected and will have the support of the PSD to be corrected.

But if we are supporting austerity measures, we also criticize the Portuguese government. And it is a good example for other analogous cases, because it is not reducing spending. And what is crucial is not just...

The solution is not to increase taxes to reduce the deficit, but to reduce spending. It is to demand that the government has the courage to take measures that reduce spending, alleviate the deficit, and relieve the public debt.
This applies to Portugal and to other States that are today in a difficult situation. And we, as European parliamentarians, have the responsibility to also do so in our own countries.
An apology for the measures necessary for the euro to emerge strengthened and for this space of integration and this dream, which is a dream of the EPP and a dream of all of us, to become a reality.
That is why we criticize those governments that do not have the courage to take the necessary measures in their states.

Dear colleagues, I would like to begin by saying that the report on the evaluation of the results of the 2006-2010 roadmap for equality between men and women, and which aims to influence strategies on this matter for the future, could, in our opinion, have been more assertive and less controversial.

In fact, the way to approach various ethically sensitive issues, particularly the issue of women's sexual and reproductive health, should have been different if the goal was truly to achieve the greatest possible consensus.

That being said, I would like to emphasize that during times of so-called normal economic growth, concern for women's rights, particularly regarding the disparity between the situation of men and women at work, in society, and in the family, is significant. However, these problems are profoundly exacerbated by economic and social crises like the one we are currently experiencing.
Hence the need for a reinforced strategic commitment from the Member States, at the level of local and regional authorities and Community institutions, with regard to protection.

In line with what President Dou and colleague Werner Langen have said, it is essential that there is an Economic Government of the Union, but that this Economic Government is centered in the Commission.
This is the first point I wanted to emphasize. And having said that, I would like to say that we should not only, as we have done all morning here today, focus our debate on immediate issues,
also in those that are in the 2020 Strategy. And I would particularly emphasize the issue of education and training of the young, the issue of innovation, research and development.

Because these are the niches that will allow Europe to be competitive in the global space. And today I must say that, unfortunately, the European educational model has failed. And it has failed because, when compared to the model of emerging countries,

Like India, like China, like Brazil, it is now a less demanding and less rigorous model. And for this reason, I also ask that in the boldness of this idea of innovation, development, research and education, there be rigor and demand in the context of European educational systems.
Only with this rigor and demand do we prepare our young people to compete in the global market.

We cannot just think about this year's crisis or the next two or three years; we have to think about the strategy for Europe over the next 10 to 20 years, and that depends on a rigorous and demanding education system.
Mr. Commissioner, never before has the European project, built with so much effort over the past 50 years, been so threatened.

The frustration of European citizens is enormous. The financial system that was supposed to serve them has destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment projects, their jobs, in short, their future.
As for the necessary strengthening of the entire financial services market, banking, insurance, securities, the way forward is clear and lies in the architecture we are discussing here today.
We do indeed need a strong European supervisory architecture, covering all products and actors, equipped with methodologies and instruments of
effective intervention that is capable of responding to the reality of the market, which, especially in the European context, does not recognize national borders.

Risk cannot and should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and prevents the accumulation of bubbles whose explosion affects the entire system and spreads to the real economy.

But if, despite these defenses, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to have mechanisms in place to limit contagion, especially with regard to the banking system, because it is vital for the functioning of the economy and the custodian of citizens' savings.

Here, precisely in the powers and competences of the banking authority, lies the capacity to implement a new strategy on the management of cross-border crises in the banking sector, a topic addressed in my report.
It is not in our hands to prevent the bankruptcy of banks, but rather to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation is carried out in a
in an orderly manner, limiting the side effects on the rest of the system and, above all, preventing the taxpayer from having to pay for the costs of the crises they generate.

A set of new devices is needed for this. It is necessary to adopt rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments and terminology common to all parties involved in restructuring, reorganization or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, particularly bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to assign supervisors with extended powers of intervention.
it is necessary to draw up clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that allow for the initiation of interventions in an institution in difficulty.
Contingency plans need to be prepared.
This whole process for 27 member states takes time.
However, about 50 banks out of the 12,000 operating in Europe account for 70% of the assets.
Now, this means a huge concentration of risk, but also an opportunity to intervene on them as a priority.

There are therefore conditions in place to propose a special and urgent process for identifying banks that, due to their cross-border nature and size, and their relationships with other banks, have a potential systemic impact on the financial system.
Now, these banks can expect special supervision from the new European Banking Authority, although operating within the College of National Supervisors,
It is possible and urgent that they, due to the risk they generate, start making contributions to a fund that finances potential interventions.
that are necessary and it is important that the banking authority creates a specialized unit that coordinates interventions in case of difficulties in these banks.
Overall, the proposed elements ensure that interventions in transnational banks of a systemic nature are consistent and coherent across the
different countries and, above all, that a principle so dear to Europe is upheld, that the costs of pollution caused by these banks are borne by the polluter themselves.
This proposal fits perfectly with what we are discussing, especially regarding the powers of the banking authority. I would even say that it is the most evident test of its effectiveness.
In the case of the vote in the Economic and Monetary Committee, there was an overwhelming majority in support of this proposal, 87% of the votes.
We also have here in the plenary the massive vote of this institution, in the sense that, by massively supporting this proposal, which is visionary, which is realistic, but which is pragmatic, we...
let us take action that is urgent and necessary to rekindle the hope of Europeans in Europe, in its financial system and, in particular, in the banking system. Thank you very much.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the main environmental and social problems on the planet and every year we lose 13 million hectares of forest, thus contributing to 20% of the globe's carbon emissions and posing a huge threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is undeniable and, as such, it is largely responsible for the occurrence of extreme weather events and floods, or even for the desertification of vast areas of the planet.
Forest loss puts all of humanity at risk, but this risk and impact is not shared equally among us.
Communities with fewer resources and those that depend most on the forest and nature to survive are the most affected.
Deforestation concerns our collective existence, the scarcity of natural resources, their distribution, the rights of local and indigenous communities, and social justice.
The main cause of deforestation is illegal logging, which accounts for 20 to 40% of the world's industrial wood production.
Therefore, we are also talking about the transfer of wealth from the producing countries to the consuming countries of that same wood.
This illegal practice endangers the sustainable exploitation of timber and the companies that do it.
Pretty words are not enough.
This Parliament must adopt strong and consistent measures in this fight.
This report takes a very significant step in that direction by defining the prohibition of the timber trade.
Good intentions are not enough either.
Effective means are necessary, namely sanctions that in this case could be of three types.

First, fines that actually remove the economic benefit from the illegal practice, increased for repeat offenders. Second, confiscation of the wood from the products in question. And third, immediate suspension of the authorization to carry out a commercial activity.

And this is because anyone who exploits or markets a natural resource must be socially responsible. And this is also why anyone who places wood or wood products on the European Union market for the first time must be required to take due diligence to ensure that the wood is legally exploited.
That is why all the following operators must provide basic information about this wood, including its origin and destination.
The population must also have the right, and I will end here, Mr. President, the right to access information about who complies and who does not. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Madam President. We have discussed here today another situation of human rights violation, that of the imprisonment of Syrian activist Aytan Almaleh, an 80-year-old lawyer, accused of allegedly spreading false, exaggerated news that weakens the national feelings of his country.

In addition to the violation of numerous international treaties and conventions, the imprisonment of this human rights defender is also contrary to the country's own legislation, which stipulates that military courts should not have jurisdiction to try civilians.

The decision that was made in relation to this man and in relation to other Syrian prisoners detained for similar reasons, the various detentions, the restrictions on freedom of movement and the arbitrary measures taken

According to Syrian authorities, these practices contradict Syria's important role in the entire region and do not reflect the efforts that have been made in this country to improve the social situation.
I repeat, today we are discussing yet another situation of human rights violation.
It is impossible to separate it from the various discussions we have had here this week.
I would like to highlight two of them. The first is the rejection of the death sentence by stoning imposed on Sakineh Ashtiani.
Many voices have come together and there have already been some results.

A Europe without economic, social and territorial cohesion is not a Union.

Dependency was reduced, equality and job creation were increased.

For the celebration, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the objective of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Lisbon Treaty, embodies the value of European solidarity and the commitment of the Member States and the Union to reduce the disparities existing between the various regions.
However, it is not enough to simply express the objectives to be achieved in the text of the treaties.
There are regions of the Union that have permanent constraints that strongly condition their economic and social development.

This is why it is necessary to implement specific programs that effectively and genuinely overcome the backwardness of these regions, by promoting an adaptation of their development model to their potential and resources, and contributing to the achievement of the EU 2020 strategy objectives.
This incentive for these regions should result not only from regional policy measures, through its structural adjustment instruments, such as the Cohesion Fund and the four structural funds, but
it also involves a different use of the various sectoral policies, which have a significant territorial impact in each region and can therefore have a stimulating effect on their economies.
For the determination of European assistance to these regions, it is certain that we must maintain GDP as the main indicator of eligibility.

However, taking into account their natural disadvantages, it becomes pertinent to resort to other measurable criteria, capable of providing a more realistic picture of their level of development, such as the unemployment rate, population density, or education level.
Only in this way will it be possible to have a more complete picture of the complex reality of the most disadvantaged regions.

They refer to this end the case of the outermost regions, whose status was recognized by the new treaty and which are a group of regions in the European Union that have specific characteristics and also deserve special treatment.
The outermost regions, united by their particular characteristics, also differ in their levels of development.

Complementary GDP indicators should also be used for these, capable of providing a more complete description of their specific reality and thus contributing to a more accurate determination of their level of development. Thank you very much.

First of all, with regard to these two reports, I would like to commend and publicly acknowledge, as I have already done in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, the remarkable work carried out by the
colleagues Lena, Suoboda, Ror Berendt, Diana Wallis and Rebecca Harms, who were part of the team of MEPs who negotiated this framework agreement with the Commission.

and the first framework agreement that has a direct basis, an express basis in the treaties, more precisely in Article 295 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
I wanted to say that this agreement actually creates a relationship of great transparency and great dynamism, even a certain intimacy in the relationship between the
Parliament and the Commission and essentially represents a compromise, a balance between the vision of the two institutions on the new role that each of them has after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I believe that the work of our negotiating team was, in fact, very positive, because it managed to translate, in this framework agreement, the new competences and the strengthening of powers resulting from the Treaty of Lisbon.
This applies to the legislative procedure and to programming or planning, namely, for example, just to give two examples, in the involvement of Parliament in the
the Commission's work programme or, for example, on issues related to the use of soft law in areas where Parliament has legislative powers on behalf of the Commission.

In a second line, the very important aspect is the strengthening of the Parliament's control and scrutiny powers. Whether in detailing, specifying the rules for electing the President and the Body of Commissioners, or, for example,

regarding the Parliament's presence in matters such as the reshuffling or the possible removal of a commissioner, or, for example, the hearing of the directors of regulatory agencies, as well as the monitoring of international negotiations.
In all these dimensions, there was indeed a consecration of powers, which are powers that result from the Lisbon Treaty.
Access to information is also very important, particularly access to classified information.
And, furthermore, the exchange of information and the exchange of views between the officials of the Parliament and the officials of the Commission.

For example, we know that today it is already possible for the Commissioner responsible for institutional affairs and the President of the Commission to participate in the relevant parts of the Conference of Presidents,

Or, for example, that there are various platforms for dialogue between the Conference of Presidents, the Conference of Committee Chairs, the President of Parliament, the President of the Commission, and the College of Commissioners, all of which are expressed.
The Commission's presence in Parliament was also strengthened, particularly through the implementation of Question Hour not only for the Commission President, but also for the Commissioners.
I would therefore say that, in deep respect for the Treaty of Lisbon and its new balance of power, and in deep respect for the idea of separation of powers,
We have here a clarifying agreement that updates, brings to life, and makes applicable the Treaty of Lisbon.

Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating Commissioner Barnier for presenting this important document.

As you have diagnosed, the impact of the crisis we are experiencing is being felt in all sectors of society and our economy, causing our citizens to feel discouraged and distrustful of the single market.
But it is precisely this single market that is one of the assets Europe has to combat the current crisis.
That is why we warmly welcome this communication, which represents a new ambition for single market policies, allowing us to regain confidence in our social market economy model.
In the current situation, the European Union must pay particular attention to its 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises.

We also highlight the Commission's proposal to evaluate the Small Business Act by the end of 2010, in order to make life easier for these companies, particularly in terms of bureaucratic and tax simplification, as well as in promoting social responsibility.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. We are here today to discuss what has been presented as one of the European Commission's top priorities, which is innovation policy.
it finally takes shape, particularly through the European partnerships for innovation and with this pilot project that we are discussing here today on active and healthy ageing.
However, there are many aspects that still need to be defined, particularly in terms of clarification, in terms of defining future projects, and in terms of priorities.
Who, in the end, will define the priorities and based on what criteria?
I think these answers are owed to us.
But I would like to leave some concrete notes, and in particular regarding this first project on active and healthy aging that was presented to us.

And these notes are, from the outset, a positive note because it seems positive to me that they focus on a sector of the population that is particularly vulnerable, in an increasingly aged and increasingly disadvantaged Europe.

But I would like, however, to add even more questions to these questions, because it seems contradictory to me that a project is presented in this area when at the same time we do not have a place to support this innovation.
How are we going to sustain it?
What is the basis?

Is there any viable innovation in a context like the one we are witnessing, where there is a persistent and systematic attack on the welfare state, a reduction in access to healthcare, systematic cuts in services provided, and continued disinvestment in this area?
The title of the presentation that was given, a union of innovation, more jobs, improved lives, better society, is ambitious.

I would even say that I would have no problem in subscribing to it personally, but let's face it, it is contradictory to what has been the practice in the Member States, with cuts and austerity measures.

I think that there is only sustainable innovation if there are rigorous, sustainable and demanding public policies. If it is not a match that goes out, there is little left and we have little to answer to these populations. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, we welcome the Commission's efforts to put research and innovation at the top of the political agenda.

How to ensure accountability within a complex structure,

President, let's be clear, the solidarity mechanism for sovereign debt did not work, nor does it work. The price of Greek debt has not fallen, Ireland is in...

The economic meltdown and contagion were not contained. The process that was created was created too late, is intergovernmental, and should have existed in another format from the beginning of the euro's creation.
The President of the Commission is now proposing a consolidation of this system.
But in the third of the instruments proposed for use, it suggests private sector involvement.
We had already heard this proposal from Chancellor Merkel, and it was as a result of this premature and inopportune announcement that the markets went into overdrive.
Parliament will fully utilize its powers and with the utmost responsibility and spirit of cooperation in the co-decision process that accompanies the legislative package.
legislative on economic governance, but it will not do so by sacrificing haste, speed, and putting quality in second place.

Therefore, let us be clear, Parliament will participate actively, but such a serious matter as the solution to sovereign debt cannot be decided on the margins and in disregard of European citizens and their representatives. The two elements go together.
Finally, we Europeans need a clear European vision at this time of crisis.
A European mechanism for consolidating sovereign debt is needed. Eurobonds need to be issued, and the eurozone needs to be sustainably protected through European systems, not intergovernmental ones.
We need to strengthen the European budget. We cannot continue with 1% of the European budget level, and we need to put growth and real convergence at the center of European political priorities.
It is this agenda that the Commission and the new President must defend.
And the President of the Commission cannot be an emanation of the Ecofin Council.
This is what we need to present to European citizens.
Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, I naturally wanted to say that the EPP's position is clear. It is a position that
that the resolution of this crisis, this serious crisis that Europe and the European Union are experiencing, can only be achieved through a deepening of economic governance and the Community method.

For us, there is no doubt that only with more community method, only with an economic government, only with the appropriate instruments of a true single currency in the euro area, is it possible to confront and attack this crisis.
But this means that each of the institutions, the Council, the Commission and Parliament, must take responsibility before the Europeans.

the Community method of introducing economic governance, of giving the single currency the conditions necessary for it to triumph in the context of the European crisis.

That is what we are counting on, and on your clear adherence to the European ideal, President Wanderlund.

Today, more than ever, the achievement of economic, social, and territorial cohesion is essential for asserting the European Union's competitiveness on a global scale.

Member States to invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of the Structural Funds, on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives. Another aspect I consider crucial is the request for a simpler architecture for post-2013 funds, not as a consequence of the economic crisis, but rather as a general principle of the future cohesion policy, in order to facilitate the absorption of funds.
The underlying concern of the Lisbon Treaty was to bring Europe closer to its citizens.
Let us then not only do this, but also make your life easier by avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that deter your participation.
Only in this way will we be able to achieve the goal of true territorial cohesion
Only in this way will we see the disparities within the European Union reduced, which today are markedly contrasting and with a huge gap between rich and poor regions.
More participation also means more responsibility. And it is this responsibility that must be assumed and shared by all, doing more and better in order to have a stronger and more competitive Europe.

The NATO Summit was held in Lisbon, and therefore allow me to say a few words about what happened in my country regarding this summit.
At that time, the Portuguese authorities banned European citizens from entering the country for a single reason: these citizens were carrying critical texts about the Alliance.
In those days, the least we can say is that an arbitrary regime, a veritable thought police, was in force in Portugal.
Such a special regime that led the Portuguese government to buy riot control equipment worth 5 million euros, which didn't even arrive in time for the summit.
And these are the priorities, after all, of a government facing a huge social crisis.
In the Europe we dream of, freedom of expression is a fundamental value.
The Europe we dream of does not bow down to military organizations that write their history in blood.
From the NATO summit came the legitimization of its military intervention across the planet.
The subordination of the European Union to the military strategy and interests of the United States also emerged.
Thirdly, the militarization of access to energy sources was consolidated.
Finally, military defense was established for the development model that generates environmental imbalances and exacerbates the social crisis.

What I mean by this, Madam President, is that in my view, with this summit, we have lost in terms of democracy, we have lost in terms of freedom, and we have lost so that some can profit from the war.

And now I give the floor to Mr. Rangel, you have a minute and a half. Thank you, Mr. President. The first point I wanted to make clear here and that it is important for us to reinforce in this Parliament is that...
Contrary to what one sometimes reads in the press and in the statements of some European leaders, the euro, as a currency, has been crucial in responding to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would be in a very difficult situation, with the currencies of the most fragile countries greatly devalued and with a possible German mark appreciating in value, which would be impossible to sustain for the German economy and the European economy.

And that is why the euro has been a factor of stability especially not only for the countries that are in the euro zone, but also for the currencies of the countries that did not want to join the euro zone.

And for that very reason, because we have to defend this community that has managed to respond to the crisis like no other and as, moreover, we will see in the future, for example, what will happen to the dollar and the United States of America, we will see how the euro actually has advantages...

We now have the responsibility on this Council to do everything to defend the Euro. To do this, in particular, we need to create a stabilization fund that follows the Community method and is capable of introducing responsibility in the countries.

agriculture, require the involvement of other areas, such as competition, internal market and financial regulation, as well as others, also require their treatment in other extra-Community forums, such as the G20 or the WTO.

they expect concrete and appropriate actions from us. I hope, Mr Commissioner, that you will then put it into practice and that the Commission, which has the initiative, which unfortunately this Parliament does not have, will put it into practice.

solidarity with the millions of Egyptian citizens who are in Cairo and throughout the country, fed up with hunger, fed up with oppression, fed up with unemployment.

Thank you, Mr. President. The price of food has reached an all-time high and is increasing for the 7th consecutive time.
And there are several factors that can explain this increase, the first of which is a short-term factor,
it has to do with the coincidence of bad weather conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina,
But there are two factors that are structural, they are of a structuring nature, and that is why I am bringing up these two factors here.
The first has to do with the fact that some producers and consumers of food who were exporters have become importers, as is the case with China.
And the second has to do with the fact that the weight of some large multinational companies can make prices play in their favor.
And the example of cereals is a very clear illustration of this. It is dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation therefore puts farmers in a state of great uncertainty about food prices.
Europe must therefore return to what it stopped doing some time ago, namely protecting its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone resorts to forms of protection and where multinationals manipulate the express, we cannot continue to be naive. Thank you very much.
I would like to congratulate my colleague, the rapporteur Marisa Matias, and commend all those who collaborated with her.
Unfortunately, over the past few years, we have witnessed an increase in counterfeit medicines in Europe.
According to data from the European Union, one and a half million boxes of counterfeit medicines are sold annually through the legal supply chain.
This is a criminal activity that poses a serious threat to European patients and the European industry.
The objective of this Directive is to prevent the introduction of falsified medicinal products into the supply chain and thus protect public health.

I would like to highlight the following key points in the opinion I drafted: the introduction of the definition of counterfeit medicines, clearly emphasizing consumer protection, the application of secondary devices,

ensuring the security of prescription medicines, the accountability of all parties involved in the distribution chain, and finally, the implementation by Member States of effective sanctions to deter this criminal activity.

Mr President, Commissioner, it is not worth repeating that the current moment is the most serious test of the euro's survival and, therefore, of Europe's.
The Polimata report opens up constructive solutions and so I also want to congratulate our colleague Pelas Ideias Clansa.

The gravity of the moment does not stem from the fact that the eurozone as a whole has an excessive deficit or external debt. It stems rather from the fact that the economies that compose it diverge persistently and seriously under the impact of the common policy.
And we lack the instruments that would allow for convergence between these economies, that would allow Europe to regain balance, that would allow Europe to grow.

Let's be clear, the eurozone and the European Union cannot survive with the current degree of integration and the diversity of the economies that make it up with a budget of 1% of the collective wealth.
In practice, after the crisis, the only solution we were able to build was the austerity recipe. And it is the workers and businesses who are paying for it today.
the deficits generated by the speculative crisis in the financial sector, the rescue of which involved committing 26% of the European Union's wealth.

The tax burden must be redistributed in a way that harms workers and businesses less and is shared more equitably by the financial sectors, particularly speculative ones.
And, Commissioner, I think it is not up to the Commission at this moment to refuse or ignore the clear message that this Parliament is politically giving you.
The public consultation cannot exclude the analysis of the tax on financial transactions; on the contrary, it must be analyzed with the highest priority.

The prevention of natural and man-made disasters is of enormous importance and of growing importance, and the European Commission systematically presents us with a number of procedural intentions and a timetable.
But there is a very complicated problem, as has already been mentioned.
The Solidarity Fund is an instrument that typically responds to these situations, but it responds in a very, very long time, nine months to a year, and this after the catastrophe.

As has already been mentioned, and I will repeat and we will repeat ad nauseam for as long as necessary, there is the case of Madeira. A year ago, it suffered a huge catastrophe, and it has still not received any support.
And I ask this, and I emphasize this question, is it not time for the Commission to review the procedure of the fund itself and the funding model itself?
How can we maintain a reserve fund to deal with situations that are becoming increasingly chronic?
We don't know where it will happen, but we know it will happen and climate change is here to prove it.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I begin by congratulating my colleague Mr. Schwab for the negotiating persistence that led to this important compromise, and I also commend all those who collaborated with him on this report.

We want not only to ensure a high level of protection for European consumers, but also that European companies, regardless of their size, can provide goods and services to consumers in the 27 Member States without unnecessary legal obstacles.

This new directive will put an end to the legislative fragmentation that has been hindering our companies' participation in the cross-border market and will give an important boost to the internal market.
I highlight the new provisions regarding the information to be provided to the consumer, requiring that this information be clear, understandable, and provided in a timely manner.
It is also important to note that, in terms of compliance with information requirements, the burden of proof now falls on the trader.
As for contracts concluded at a distance, especially those concluded by telephone or internet, their rules should be defined and the consumer protected by simple and effective mechanisms.

We are certain that at the end of the institutional negotiations, the new directive will contribute to making the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as required in a global economy. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr President of the Council and Mr President of the Commission. First of all, I naturally wanted to congratulate you on the results of the Council meeting on 24-25 March, particularly on the consolidation of the semester.

European, but much more than that, whether through the institutionalization of the European stability mechanism, or the, shall we say, Euro Plus Pact, which already came from the Eurozone Summit on March 11.
I believe these are very positive results for Europe and it is a shame that this process was not fully completed on 24-25 March.
I believe that if we had given this signal, if the States had given this signal in the Council, by completely closing this package of fund reform, we would be in a position today

stronger to face the three, four months. And, in part, we would have mitigated the effects of the crisis that my country, Portugal, is currently experiencing, and about which I also do not want to remain silent.

to say that, in the case of the PSD, which is fully integrated into the EPP, there is an absolute and total willingness to comply with the requirements and obligations of integration into the European area.
This is what we have been doing, even now, at this moment, when there are difficulties regarding short-term financing.
Unlike what the Socialist Government has been doing, the Social Democratic Party has shown its full willingness to provide the guarantees to Europe that are necessary in the context of this crisis.

And with this, I want to give this signal, without bringing internal politics into the European Parliament, of the commitment, of the total guarantee of the Social Democratic Party in the rigorous agenda that the country will have to follow after its elections on June 5.
Thank you very much, Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner Stefan Fuller. The historic moment we are living through calls for firm and determined action.
Like many of you, we are watching the events unfolding in the Mediterranean Basin with a mix of hope, concern, and anticipation.

I am, however, pleased with the proactive position that Parliament is preparing to adopt regarding the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy South, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this area, not only as a payer, but also as an engaged partner.
First of all, by affirming the absolute necessity of defending our founding values in relations with neighboring countries.
We can no longer compromise in the defense of democracy, nor in the defense of human rights, and even less so in the defense of social justice.

We can no longer prioritize short-term stability at the expense of the greater interests of citizens and their uncompromising defense, of their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to women's rights.
In the future, the Union must prioritize a bottom-up approach in its neighborhood policy.
It is imperative that this happens.
Only the greatest involvement of local communities and civil society will ensure maximum effectiveness in its implementation.

But I cannot help but express a frustration. I regret that this Parliament and the Commission do not want to take this opportunity to finally differentiate the Eastern neighborhood policy with countries that potentially could become our partners in the Union in the future, from the Southern neighborhood policy.
I also challenge the Commission to demonstrate, in its review process on April 20, the ambition that the current moment demands, a neighborhood policy.
tailor-made to each state, with clearer assets and a careful evaluation that allows for a future Mediterranean economic area with the new democracies of the South.

In conclusion, Mr Commissioner, we trust that the good atmosphere and cooperation that have characterised the work on this subject will lead to the European Parliament's permanent involvement in the planning and evaluation of this policy. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr President. The reports we have debated and which I congratulate the rapporteurs on today reinforce a set of initiatives that aim to relaunch the internal market.
I would like to highlight the commitment of the European Commission, in particular Commissioner Barnier, whom I welcome, and the positive reception of this Parliament through the
Committee on Consumer Protection and the Internal Market, to give priority to market competitiveness and dynamism, a fundamental pillar of the 2020 Strategy.
Citizens and businesses expect effective measures to get Europe growing economically again, they expect an increase in employment, they aspire to the creation of more prosperity.

And as the Commissioner pointed out, opening up markets to our companies, eliminating obstacles and difficulties, will provide a very special boost and a unique opportunity that will allow them to continue their mission as the driving force of our economy.

Measures aimed at reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden on SMEs and their access to credit and the service market, the European patent, and the recognition of qualifications are essential.
the relevance of the development of e-commerce to strengthen the confidence of consumers and businesses in this type of commerce, the focus on innovation
important for strong and lasting growth. Social entrepreneurship is indispensable for creating innovative business projects for social inclusion.
These are some measures that will ensure this ambitious project of completing, deepening and making full use of the single market for the benefit of European citizens.
Finally, the important recommendation that Member States redouble their efforts to improve the transposition and implementation of internal market rules. Thank you very much.
I also want to add my voice to all those who have expressed concerns here about the low incomes of fishermen, exacerbated by the historic prices reached by fuel, particularly in recent months.
As has been well stated here, fuel costs have a very high impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized shipowners, particularly aggravating the already fragile incomes of fishermen.
This vestigial rise in prices is also bringing us profound negative effects. Reduction in trips to sea, miserable incomes for fishermen, exacerbated by the low prices paid at the first sale.

increases in imports of aquaculture and fishery products from third countries to the European market and a consequent abandonment of the activity due to financial difficulties, such as the loss of jobs.
In this context, to prevent the crisis from continuing to worsen, it is necessary to act, and to act with solidarity and with a deep understanding of the problems of fishing.

The Commission must therefore provide positive responses with short- and long-term measures to address the adversities facing the sector and the serious income losses being experienced by our fishermen.
First of all, I would like to particularly congratulate the work of our PPE colleague, MÃ¡rio David, whom I represent here today because he is fully informed.
unable to attend this plenary and I wanted to say that we have always considered support for the victims of the floods in Pakistan an ethical and moral imperative.
And that is why we strongly support all the measures that have been taken towards traditional humanitarian aid.
We truly believe that work should continue to help stabilize the situation for so many millions of affected people.
What we cannot accept is that the European Union's trade policy is now considered a suitable instrument for humanitarian aid.

The truth is that this brings two disastrous consequences. One consequence within the European Union, especially for the southern countries and their textile-clothing industry, which is now highly weakened by an economic, social and financial crisis unparalleled since the

And secondly, at the global level, in the WTO negotiations, where this opening of the largest trading bloc in the world, which is the European Union, to these potential Pakistani exports, could completely upset the WTO negotiations.
And it is no coincidence that they find themselves at the impasse they are in.

It is therefore natural that, faced with a situation like this, we should say, regarding the history of this Regulation and the difficulties it encountered during these eight months of intense negotiations, that

with which we collaborated on the most constructive proposals, we will now, unfortunately, have to take a position that will be in the sense of supporting the amendment that, in essence, provides for the end of this proposed regulation as we know it.
We have to do it at this point, not out of any less solidarity with Pakistan, but because we believe that humanitarian aid should be given in the right place and in the right way.
Mr President, Commissioner, I wanted to start by saying that, of course, I believe that the agreement that has been reached for Portugal is a balanced agreement.
It is a very tough agreement for the populations, but it places its fundamental point on structural reforms to increase growth and competitiveness.
And I think that is very positive.

I do not adopt here the attitude of others who believe that countries like Greece, Ireland and Portugal did everything right, made no mistakes, did not exaggerate, did everything right and it was only the international crisis that caused problems.

No. Our governments made mistakes and had wrong policies. But that does not mean that there is not now an opportunity within the context of the Union to have the possibility to get back on the right track and the correct path.

And that is why it is important to remember here that, in fact, it is necessary to tell public opinion that is against supporting countries in difficulty that they are not giving money to these countries, they are only lending money to these countries.
but they are lending them at very high interest rates and therefore are making a deal that is positive for their budgets and for their populations.

But I also say here that perhaps it is time to have a comprehensive European response with the admission of Eurobonds, with the admission of the possibility of selling in the primary market to respond to international markets.

And perhaps it is time for the European Commission, the Fund, and the IMF themselves to review the interest rates, so as to make it possible, by lowering these rates, for there to be sustained growth in these countries that are currently in difficulties.

Thank you. I give the floor for one minute to Mr. Correia de Campos. Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner and Mrs. Rapporteur. This strategy is important for all European countries, especially for those whose economy lacks more competitiveness.
It is essential for the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises.
Today, the generation of new jobs is more active.
It is essential for universities and laboratories whose survival depends in part on their relationship with the productive sectors.
It is essential for the financial system, which will find a new market in innovation, as the classic manufacturing model is running out.

Innovation is at the top of the European agenda and, being a pillar of the EU 2020 strategy, it will need to be supported by new financial instruments so that it does not succumb to current budgetary constraints.
Finally, I would like to salute Judite Merckes for her important contribution to a more innovative Europe with a more knowledge-based economy. Thank you very much.
President, Madam President, Commissioner, I want to start by congratulating my colleague Odi on his excellent report.

The mid-term evaluation, although belated, highlighted the critical aspects of the seventh program. Its excessive bureaucracy, the lack of interest from industry, the number and complexity of the new instruments, the slow pace of disbursements,
There is also a greater risk of large transfers of funds from the current framework programme to large-scale programmes with questionable added value.
