but it also highlighted positive aspects, greater international collaboration and cooperation between scientific groups on joint projects, some success stories, including the European Research Council, and a greater gender balance.
There are priorities that need to be developed. First, simplification. Second, promoting scientific excellence, not in some countries, but throughout Europe. A greater connection of

framework programme with innovation, with instruments aimed at small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurship, of which the most successful is the Eurostar programme, which should be expanded. Thank you, sir.

Madam President, Commissioner, I am addressing the proposal you have come here to present to Parliament today, and I will say quite frankly that I think we have the right, some of us, to be disappointed with this proposal, because the proposal that is being presented is not only weak but has numerous gaps.
I think this is a European issue, it is not a matter of the states that have a nuclear industry and those that do not, it is about the whole of Europe and Europe desperately needs good news.
And I must sincerely tell you that one of those good news is to assure citizens that we are taking care of their safety.
Now, when these tests are carried out in the manner described by the Commissioner, that is, a first phase is carried out by the parties concerned, and a second phase is carried out by the States that

these stakeholders argue in favor of it, and a third phase is carried out by the peers who are truly interested, I wonder if the result will not ultimately be to say that all nuclear power plants are in very good health and are recommended.

We know that is not the case and so I very much hope there will be serious consequences and that we can tell our citizens that we are looking after their security and not just pretending that we are. Thank you very much.
I expect a highly responsible decision from this European Council, especially given the climate that has been developing in recent weeks.
And what could be more irresponsible than what happened at the last Council, where they tried to postpone a problem for just three months because of electoral calendars.

I essentially expect from this decision of responsibility that it will be understood that economic and financial issues are crucial and decisive for Europe, but that economic and financial issues are instrumental for what is Europe's main purpose, which is to maintain peace.
If an approach to the problems is taken that only and solely leads to the states beginning to distrust one another, to install distrust among the different states,
to create and fuel differences and rivalries between Southern and Northern States, between central and peripheral States. What we will be led to is the decline of the European Union.

I believe that what is at stake in this European Council, regardless of the technical solutions, regardless of the political disputes, is whether or not we want the European project to continue being a valid project for the peace strategy in Europe.
I swear that's what's at stake.
What I notice in many speeches by leaders, both from those in countries in difficulty and from those in countries that are economic payers,
contributors, it is an irresponsible discourse, which often even appeals to some characteristics of nationalities that are extremely negative.
This is what I call for, and only this, feeling a responsibility for the leaders of European governments to find solutions that lead Europe to an exit and a solution.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. My first words are to praise the work carried out by the rapporteur, my colleague Jorge Sravacakis, who has done an extraordinary job in identifying future synergies for enhanced effectiveness between the various structural funds.

Your report also fits into this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate that is of the utmost importance, not only because of the substance of the topic, but also and above all because of the timing of its discussion.
In fact, we are currently in the process of getting to know the Commission's proposal, not only regarding the new financial perspectives, but also regarding the future cohesion policy post-2013.
Cohesion policy is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its main instruments, the structural funds, finances projects and programmes in the Member States, seeking to reduce the disparity between the levels of development of the various regions.
Experience, however, has shown us the inefficiencies and lack of results that result from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

I believe that a single strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated and results-oriented approach, is the starting point for more and better synergies between the various instruments and for enhancing their effectiveness.
It is also essential for better coordination between the various sectoral policies and for greater efficiency in the application of resources.
We must take advantage of the danger of crisis to seek new alternatives.

And it is certain that all these reports that are being discussed here today will pose enormous challenges for us. And we know that to respond to these challenges we also need a good budget. But we must make a clear distinction between the budgetary aspects and the political objectives.
The political objectives are well known. And, in fact, only by affirming these political objectives can we offer a future to the regions.

And if that is the case, we must then put the budget at the service of the future of the regions and the citizens, and not the citizens and the regions at the service of the budget. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. The cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space, with an internal market and its own currency, requires a certain level of convergence among its member states and regions in order to function.
The current divergences in competitiveness and development asymmetries have inevitably led to the weakening of the European area and the crisis affecting the eurozone.
This is why there is a vital need for convergence that absolutely requires a powerful cohesion budget, which cannot be weakened to finance other policies.
The European Union, to do more, must have more. And this is achieved by increasing its budget, not by reducing, even if cleverly, the cohesion budget.

I ask the Commissioner whether the creation of the Fund for Infrastructure and New Innovation Policies, which will be linked to cohesion and regional development, which I support, without an increase in the Community budget, may not turn into the Trojan horse that is introduced into the cohesion budget.
The modernization and renewal of the energy infrastructure are essential factors for the sustainable and smart growth objectives we seek with the 2020 Strategy and for the energy security we need.
it is essential to involve all regions in this challenge.

To this end, the incentives provided for in the regulatory systems must be improved, particularly those that apply to higher-risk projects and more innovative projects, such as those being developed in the Azores islands in the field of renewable energy.

The regions must be involved in the design and implementation phases of projects, in setting priorities, in their development and execution, because this ensures better results and therefore better defense of European interests.
The current economic climate further accentuates the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, taking into account all economic, environmental, and social aspects.
It is essential not to lose sight of its medium and long-term effects, seeking to ensure that all European citizens have access to safe, sustainable and affordable energy.

The report we are debating is of particular importance given the influence that social services of general interest have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, job creation and economic growth.

The collaboration with rapporteur Proncias de RoÃ§a was very useful and enlightening, as the rapporteur himself has just said, allowing the adoption of several compromises in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.
For the result we have here today and which we have debated, I commend and congratulate the rapporteur.
In fact, from our point of view, the main concern was to make it clear that the competences in this matter fall to the Member States.
National authorities are the holders of the powers to define, organise and finance social services of general interest.
Thus, the creation of harmonizing legislation at the European level is unnecessary, given that the realities of these social services of general interest are very diverse across the 27 Member States.

Just look at health services, social security, employment, and social housing, which are examples where proximity and knowledge of the contexts are the cornerstone for the adequate and fairer provision of these services. Thank you very much.

Mr President, as rapporteur for the REG opinion on the future of social and international services, I would like to congratulate our colleague from RoÃ§a, highlighting the fact that we are dealing with an essential pillar of the social market economy model that we advocate for Europe, in which the SIG plays a fundamental role in its cohesion.

Social cohesion at the level of the European Union recommends not neglecting the existence of minimum protection levels in all member states, without prejudice to the respect for the competences of their national, regional and local authorities.

European regions play a very important role in providing these services to the population, and their opinion must be taken into account, given the specific nature of their constraints, to ensure that these services are provided to the population.

In a time of crisis like the one we are currently experiencing, the General Social and Intensive Service constitutes a social protection network for the most disadvantaged or for those whose income does not allow them access to private services.

It is therefore important to ensure that Member States which decentralise powers also provide the corresponding financial resources so that regional and local authorities can ensure that they provide good services to the population.
Ms Ashton, I will start by saying that it is obvious that we must continue to support the democratic revolutions that are taking place in these countries.
I don't have much time and so I just want to leave a few notes.
First of all, we must not forget that the conditions for negotiation, with a view to a democratic transition and not civil war, must be defined by the people in these countries.
The situation in Syria is serious. This applies to Syria, but it also applies to Yemen and Bahrain.

If we want to avoid civil war, the last thing these countries need is for Europe to meddle in their internal affairs, and especially, and very particularly, by presenting military or paramilitary solutions.
And if I say this, I say it because we must totally repudiate what is happening in Libya.
NATO and the United Nations have bypassed all resolutions, even those voted on by the UN Security Council.
It is this silence regarding the reprimand, this repudiation that we must make, and it is because it is not included in this resolution that I cannot endorse it. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr Prime Minister. First of all, I naturally wanted to congratulate the Polish presidency on the ambitious programme it has brought here and, in particular, to congratulate it on the...

neighborhood policy, not just to the east, but also on the southern border, where I think there is currently a challenge that is perhaps more demanding than the one we have to the east, which is more long-term and less short-term.

But having said that, I would like to ask the Prime Minister and the Polish Presidency to pay special attention to economic integration policies, economic governance, and the supervision of financial markets.

I believe that at this moment, however ambitious our goals may be in the area, let's say, of energy defense, food security, the environment, agriculture, and multiannual financial frameworks, if we do not

If we do not resolve the problem of the debt crisis in the European context in a clear and solid manner before the global markets, we will not have a strong enough Europe to deal with the challenges that the Polish presidency has set out to address.

And that is why I drew attention to the fact that it is essential to convince the remaining heads of state and heads of government that it is necessary to give more economic integration, more economic governance to the European Union.

Without this, what will happen is that we, instead of being the drivers or, at least, the representatives of our peoples, whether in the Council, Parliament, or the Commission of European Interest, instead of being that, we will only be...
Mr President, as President of the MASHREC Delegation, I would like to leave a sentence about each of my four countries, in quotation marks, of course.
Starting with Syria, and reiterating what some colleagues have already said, I regret that the international community appears, in the eyes of public opinion, to have two sets of standards.

It is necessary to denounce, if necessary, the countries that, in the Security Council, and I am obviously referring to Russia and China, and also Brazil, but with veto power, have prevented the international community from taking a more concerted stance on what should be the values we share.
Regarding Egypt, there is an urgent need to raise awareness among the Egyptian authorities about the postponement of the elections, as has already been done in Tunisia.
As for Lebanon, I believe that this debate must send a very clear message to the new Lebanese government.
so that they are aware that they will be judged based on their actions regarding the charges brought by the Special Tribunal for Lebanon.
Jordan is an example that a peaceful transition is possible and there is perhaps only a need, at this stage, to raise awareness and encourage the authorities to accelerate the reform process.
We cannot forget, obviously, in a debate of this nature, the peace process in the Middle East. And reiterate our hope that the Quartet meeting next Monday can
indeed be productive and reaffirm that this House would certainly like to see much greater involvement from the European Union in this whole process.

I have no doubt that there will be a new round of negotiations before the United Nations General Assembly in September. But I hope that this round of negotiations will be productive and conducted in good faith.
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating the rapporteur and all those who contributed to achieving this work.
There is no doubt that this report constitutes and will constitute a reference in terms of recommendations and solid, coordinated responses to the challenges of the crisis.
If there is one conclusion that can be drawn, it is that the crisis we are experiencing can only be overcome by deepening European integration.

In a time of serious financial, economic and social difficulties and painful austerity measures in some Member States, such as my country, Portugal, it is tempting to retreat into a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But that is a mistake.

The European response to the crisis involves a genuine European economic government that pursues sustainable growth, promotes job creation, and develops the social market economy, providing long-term solutions with defined objectives that the member states can identify with.
The exit strategy from the crisis needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious Community budget.
To avoid a new sovereign debt and euro crisis, closer coordination on fiscal policies is needed, as well as the creation of a system for issuing public debt securities and Eurobonds.
I conclude by emphasizing that in this difficult period it is also necessary to maintain levels of social protection, especially for the most vulnerable citizens. Thank you very much.
Mr President, Commissioner, Presidency-in-Office, it is customary to say that crises help to strengthen Europe.
Historically, that was the case, but today I am not so sure that this continues to be true.

The slow, improvised, reactive way in which the Union is reacting to the Greek crisis is exacerbating the situation every day and spreading contagion and lack of confidence in the Union and its currency in a frightening manner.
This is despite the problems in the eurozone resulting from obvious flaws in the construction of the single currency that are now concentrating on its weakest links.

For the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, a strategic vision is needed, as there was in the past, and unfortunately neither the Commission nor the Council have been able to impart to the European program and project.
This report from Parliament, however, gives us this view. More Europe, not less, is the solution.
Parliament recalls that the market and the single currency generate unbearable divergences between economies and that these must be countered by specific policies.

It recognizes that the functioning of the euro requires a European budget reinforced by its own resources, and requires a European agency for the issuance of solidarity debt capable of protecting the states from market speculation.

and provide them with credit at reasonable prices and terms. It also recognizes that diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
Parliament has come together to send clear messages. Let's hope the Commission and the Council listen to them.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear fellow rapporteur, I would first of all like to congratulate and commend the rapporteur for considering that this report is extremely useful and indeed allows us to take new steps in the area of mediation.
The report presents an overview, a range of solutions adopted by the various Member States in the implementation, in the application of the
Directive 2008-52-EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 May 2008, naturally concerning mediation in civil and commercial matters.
Now, we all know the advantages of mediation.
On the one hand, it is a judicial body for resolving conflicts, contributing to the decongestion of the courts, to the rationalization of the justice system, while also providing,
simultaneously providing the parties with the opportunity to obtain a friendly solution, which is faster and less costly than the litigation in which they are engaged.

This is why it is crucial to reaffirm the objective of Article 1 of the Directive when it calls for the adoption of measures to encourage the use of alternative dispute resolution methods, and in particular mediation.
Promoting access to and use of extrajudicial means of conflict resolution helps to improve, simplify, and make our justice system more accessible.

That is why it is a very important challenge for the European Union and for the establishment of the area of freedom, security and justice, I would say, for the idea of the rule of law within the European Union.
And that is why, in this context of crisis, I consider it very important that, as stated in the report, public opinion and operators can be made aware.
judicial systems for this issue and appeal here to the Commission and the Commissioner to quickly present a legislative proposal on alternative dispute resolution.
Thank you very much, Mr President, Commissioner. I also want to mention the fundamental importance of this report in terms of transparency of the European energy market.
And I just want to say that this is the central domain of cooperation in European terms if we safeguard some of the dimensions that are fundamental, among them avoiding that the
liberalisation turns into an increase in energy prices for citizens, ensuring equal access and taking care in terms of sanctions, as numerous colleagues have already mentioned.
And precisely because this is a central area of European cooperation, Mr President, Commissioner, I cannot help but mention it and question it and ask you eye to eye, Commissioner,
I would like to give you the opportunity to explain regarding the recent statements you made about Greece, Ireland and Portugal, because these are also matters of European cooperation.
Symbolic measures like lowering the flags, Mr. Commissioner, only reinforce the shame of citizens who are dignified and who fight for a Europe.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Mr Chief Commissioner of Covites, Gentlemen Representatives of the Council, Polish Presidency. First of all, I would like to clarify that I will be speaking here in a dual capacity. On the one hand, I am replacing the author of the opinion of the Committee on Affairs

constitutional, my colleague Messer Schmidt, a Dane who is absent because the election process is currently underway in Denmark, and therefore I am representing him as a member of Africa, but also as a member of the Jury, as shadow rapporteur on the Jury for this report.
The first point I wanted to make is that, in the crisis we are experiencing, the economic and financial crisis, the issue of smart regulation, better legislation, is a central issue.

There is no doubt that, in the so-called structural reforms that can boost the economic and financial takeoff of the European area, improvement in legislation and regulation is also absolutely essential.

It is evident that a Europe that aims to be, on the one hand, dynamic and competitive, must have regulations that are simple and accessible to businesses and, of course, to citizens. And therefore, it must be oriented towards their needs.
The truth is that, in this sense, it is essential today that, first and foremost, the program for reducing administrative burdens is achieved, and that every effort is made towards

promoting consultations with market agents, representative associations of citizens and businesses, and conducting impact assessments of the legislation itself, is also extremely important, so that the

the decision-making process can essentially be based, let's say, on the opinion of those who are the recipients of the legislation and can be done without administrative burdens and with fewer economic and financial costs.

It is important to say that, for the Committee on Constitutional Affairs in particular, the idea of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant, this idea that European intervention should be an appropriate intervention and not an intervention that promotes the complication of the legal system.

And for this reason, we have paid particular attention, in our opinion, to the enhanced role that National Parliaments have in this dynamic, precisely by virtue of the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

That is why it is essential that, in terms of Smart Regulation and improving legislation, we now involve the National Parliaments. So that, whether at the European level or at the national level, both legislation and regulation are

be more agile, more intelligent, more efficient. And therefore, this is a good time to put into practice what we announce every day, which is a more competitive Europe and a more agile Europe through more intelligent regulation.
Mr President, the number of homeless people, as well as those living below the poverty line, has been increasing in recent years in several Member States.
The economic, financial and social crisis and the increase in unemployment have exacerbated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We also all agree that this phenomenon is the negation of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity and respect for fundamental rights.
In my country, for example, which is subject to a strong austerity measure, the concept of homelessness, according to the National Plan, encompasses people who go to ask for help to have a meal.
And the number of people seeking help to eat has increased by more than 20% since 2008.
There is a noticeable increase in families and impoverished individuals whose living situation has been altered by unemployment and also by bank debt.
This is just one example that demonstrates the seriousness of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament adopted a written declaration on a European Union strategy for the homeless.

With this statement, this Parliament has highlighted the need for the European Union to develop a strategy supported by national and regional strategies, with the long-term goal of ending situations of people sleeping on the streets and long-term homelessness.
National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to the homeless and the availability of affordable housing.
It is also evident that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policy of the Member States.
We took good note of the Commissioner's words and recorded the state of affairs that he presented to us.
I conclude by urging the European Commission to give a strong push to coordinate the action of the Member States and regional authorities in order to combat this social injustice.
we debated the peace process in the Middle East. But is there a process underway that I missed?
Unfortunately, no.

The European Union, like the majority of the international community, repeatedly states that there are two peoples and two states sharing the space between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, who have the right to aspire to live in peace and security.
But without dialogue between the parties, in which they are in a cycle of hatred and misunderstandings that has been going on for 63 years, only extremism and frustration are fed.

It is essential that Europe and the Arab League become much more involved in the search for a negotiated solution to the borders, based on those existing in 1967, with exchanges that allow the majority of Jewish settlements to remain in Israel.

May the issue of Jerusalem, the holy city, future capital of the two states, be clarified and mutually accepted as a symbol of peaceful coexistence between two peoples who have the obligation to fulfill the prophecy of Isaiah that this is the land of milk and honey.

May all the countries of the Union participate in resolving the issue of Palestinian refugees and may the international community, and in particular the Arab nation, participate in the necessary financial compensation.

It is also absolutely essential that a military force under the auspices of the UN, with the participation of American and Islamic forces, among others, be deployed on the ground to guarantee the maintenance of peace.
Let there be courage and political will.
Mr President, Commissioner, tourism needs a clear and coordinated European approach, with a keen eye on the potential and challenges that different forms of tourism have to offer us.
The tourist diversity that the European Union presents is so rich that it allows for exponential growth of this sector and of the European Union's own competitiveness.

A bet on this key sector, which represents 10% of the GDP and about 12% of employment in the European Union, will allow not only to create European added value, but also to face the economic crisis we are in.
It comes from an outermost region of Madeira, where tourism is the main economic activity.

And for this reason, the creation of a specific heading for the sector in the 2014-2020 financial framework is indispensable for cohesive and sustainable growth of tourism, which is essentially composed of small and medium-sized enterprises.

The implementation of a genuine European tourism policy, sustainable and diversified, requires a concrete strategic plan with a well-defined timeline, actions, and funding, capable of enhancing the visibility and quality of the tourism sector in the European Union.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. The absence of an ongoing peace process is jeopardizing basic rights and has led to the adoption of unilateral measures by parties that are not in a position to do so.

has contributed in any way to a reduction of tensions in the region, and even less to the effective pursuit of a life for the two peoples who have the right to live harmoniously in peace, security, and with dignity.

The time has come for the international community to say enough is enough. The time has come for Europe and the Arab League to push for a lasting solution, with common sense, presenting viable solutions without delay and with deadlines.
It is evident that the United States and Russia are no longer part of the solution.
Let us begin with Jerusalem. Why not revive the original idea of a separatum corpus administered by the UN and functioning, of course, as the capital of both states?
Borders. Let's start with those of 67.
Exchange plots of land when possible and appropriate.
Take care of the defense of Israel, an issue obviously unavoidable for the Jewish people. For example, by placing blue helmets with American, European, and Islamic forces along the Jordan River.
There are approximately 4.8 million refugees, and they have the right to their dignity. To a future linked to a land of their preference.

But they are not exclusively an Israeli or Palestinian problem. It is also ours. It is a problem for the neighboring Arab countries, for the Arab community in general, but also for Europe and the rest of the international community.
Colonies must end their expansion and this is non-negotiable.
The announcement made today is shameful and reflects hypocrisy and bad faith in a statement of readiness for immediate negotiations.
Above all, we want good-faith negotiations, committed to a deadline for their conclusion, after which the international community, to maintain its credibility, will have to take a different approach.

Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, the disgraceful situation in the refugee camps in Tunisia has already been mentioned. We all share the concerns expressed by my fellow Members who spoke before me, and I share many of them.
I am not going to refer to that in particular, I am referring to another situation that is more omitted, that of citizens who were received in the homes of families in Tunisia.

And this is one of the situations that should make us even more ashamed, because let's look at Tunisia in a crisis situation regarding solidarity. Europe does not know how to be supportive and is not in a process of transition to democracy and did not know how to be supportive, did not know how to welcome.
I think it is actually shameful that we can count the number of refugees received in Europe in the hundreds.
Contrary to what has been said, many of these people cannot return to their homes.
And there were children who were enrolled in public schools, which has implications in terms of infrastructure, has implications in terms of what the reception is like in these countries.
That is why, Madam Commissioner, I am very moved by the appeal you are making, and I say this not in an ironic way, but seriously. But please, what about the Commission?
And in Europe,
What can you do?
How does Europe live so well with this double standard?
We are so quick to repatriate and so slow to help, Madam Commissioner.
It can't continue like this.

Mr President, I naturally wanted to congratulate you on this supplement of hope that you have given to all European Members of Parliament and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union that we represent here.
And, having said that, I would like to say that we now expect the Commission to take very, very decisive action with the Council so that this sovereign debt crisis can be resolved in the short term.
We know it's a marathon, but we need immediate signs.

And so, without prejudice to our already starting to think about amending the treaties to give political substance to the entire project we have brought here today, without prejudice to that, something must be done immediately.

This set of measures and possibly an agreement, an agreement between the states, what I have called a kind of parasocial agreement that goes beyond treaties and that can now put all these ideas into action.
Many congratulations on your courage and determination.
I believe we are on the right track and we will leave here today with another determination.
The crisis that the European Union is going through has had serious consequences in all member states, and thousands of workers are affected by the layoffs caused by globalization and the crisis.
We must affirm our solidarity with these workers who have lost their jobs and state that Europe must help Member States maintain an employment rate and combat unemployment.
A rapid reintegration of workers into the job market is a priority objective.

An example of the usefulness of this fund is my country, Portugal, which has drawn on it four times, although we are aware that access to this fund could be improved, especially in the countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this Globalisation Adjustment Fund, it has been possible to help thousands of workers through vocational training measures, support for business creation and incentives for recruitment.
This proposal is positive because it will allow member states to request intervention from this Fund to support workers made redundant as a direct consequence of the economic and financial crisis.
we support the extension of the deadline and believe that the Member States most affected by the crisis should have greater and easier access to this fund in support of globalisation and the crisis.
Thank you, Mr President. I greet the Polish Presidency and also Mr Ali Ren, just to say that I believe that...
Today, following on from and building upon what was done in the State of the Union address, a very, very significant step has been taken towards resolving the problems of the European zone crisis.
Because the Commission has taken a commitment here to use its power of initiative and to work with the Council to resolve this crisis.
I believe this is an extremely important step and it is the only way we have at the moment to resolve the eurozone crisis.
It is not possible to resolve this in the short term with just an intergovernmental approach. And that is why it is necessary for the states, the governments of the states,
commission the instruments and the mandate for her to lead this resolution process, for her to implement, execute, and develop this roadmap that she has presented here.
But I wanted to make it clear that this is not incompatible with doing so at the same time, with developing our ability to amend the treaties at the same time.

I am also convinced that in the medium term, we need to amend the treaties, but here too, we will have to do so in order to strengthen, in order to give more power and a stronger position to the Commission.

it is by strengthening the Community method, now in the short term and then with a change in the treaties in the long term, that we will achieve more integration and a solution for the 17 countries of the eurozone and for the 27 countries of the European Union.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Dr. DurÃ£o Barroso came here today to announce that as one of the measures, banks that do not have capital requirements must submit plans to obtain them, and if they cannot submit them, they must then suspend dividends and bonuses.
I could not help but agree with this presentation that was made by the President.
Just this week we saw what happened with Banco ZÃ©xia, and a few months ago, a director of this bank received a prize of 600 thousand euros for his wonderful administration, as we know.
But to be serious, Mr. President, the Commission has to leave the governments behind and present the complete package. And the complete package is what has the essentials.
The essential thing is that the taxpayers' money should be matched by a credit policy for growth.
The essential thing is that banks start paying taxes on their profits, which does not happen in many countries, including my country, Portugal.
In two years, or rather, in three years, it is the second time that we are asked to save the banks with taxpayers' money, the money of the unemployed.
the banks that also save the economy, helping to create jobs. Thank you very much.
Mr President, Mr High Representative, there are times when I think I need little and to take stock, and this seems to me to be one of those times.
And it seems to me that it is because we always go with the pace of events and respond to event after event, and we lose a bit of perspective on the whole.

It is true that each case is a case in itself and each country we are talking about here is a specific case, but, forgive me for saying so, Madam High Representative, it seems to me that it is difficult to scrutinise what criteria the European Union has used to act in each of these cases.
I fear that we are often held hostage by the interests of the countries of the European Union, by some of these countries of the European Union, not all of them.
And that is why we have used the expression "double standards" so many times in this House and continue to use it.

Sometimes it's sanctions yes, sometimes it's sanctions no. Sometimes the interference goes as far as the bomb, as was the case in Libya. Other times it's total silence, as was the case in the invasion of Bahrain by the forces of the

Saudi Arabia and, Baroness, let me tell you, I have been studying all the files carefully, I have not yet seen a single statement from European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by Saudi military forces.

Death sentences, it is endless violence, doctors and nurses are sentenced to up to 30 years in prison by a military court because they were allegedly against the regime and not helping the wounded who needed them.
Regarding the dictatorial monarchy of Bahrain, regarding the dictatorial regime of Yemen, the SalÃ© regime, we have had much more silence than action.

I am not in favor of interference, never have been. But I fear that we are putting ourselves in an uncomfortable position, the position seen from the outside, Mrs. Berenesa, which is, instead of helping with development, with aspirations.

Instead of helping the first Arab era, which is the democratic and revolutionary era of the peoples in the Arab countries, we prevent it from extending, either by excess or by defect, and I don't think we should be burdened with this sin.
I hope that the awarding of the Nobel Prize to a Yemeni activist can serve as a sign that our side is on the side of the peoples who are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, this is a good report by my colleague Mr Casa.
First of all, one must ask why revise VAT in the European Union.
First and foremost, there is a need to make it compatible with the single market.
The more regimes and VAT varieties, the less fluid the market will be.
A VAT reform favors e-commerce, centers competition on the value and base price of goods and services, and not on tax differences.
Combats fraud and ensures much-needed trust, especially in cross-border transactions. Improves the economy of SMEs and reduces administrative burdens.
What other accompanying measures are already in place in the single market that could be associated with the EII?
First and foremost, a simple, clear and transparent digital support mechanism, measure 7 of the single market.
Measure 5, on services, the need to review legislation on standardization and the implementation of the Safety Directive.
Measure 9 is intended to remove tax obstacles and explicitly review the VAT system and VAT equalisation in online and face-to-face commerce, which we all feel when we order books.
The pressures for VAT reform have two main reasons.
First of all, the economic crisis.
More revenue is needed, including, probably in some countries, reducing contributions on labor to promote economic development, shifting that burden to VAT.

Secondly, the second major source of pressure is population aging, demographic aging, and the trend of shifting from indirect to direct taxes, which, due to the reduction in the population base, has an impact.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between this direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, we must, in these reforms, reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the range of variation in the standard VAT rate, so that we can all understand better.
Greater transparency is needed in defining the reduced VAT rate and its scope, a clear and widely publicized list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemption thresholds for SMEs, knowing full well that each exemption brings with it a host of small or large-scale frauds.
Finally, welcome the Commission's recent proposal to create a European VAT.
Thank you, Madam President. I thank my colleague Rula for the excellent report she has prepared.

The advantages of public procurement are certainly well known, but the obstacles are also evident. Conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of the Member States harm competitiveness.
The dichotomy, the quality of prices and the complexity of laws and procedures are evident.
It is essential to look at existing best practices, particularly in Portugal, where electronic procurement has worked well and has facilitated public procurement.
Effective European public procurement represents a privileged means of controlling the public deficit and fostering growth.
To achieve this, it must have a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs, and defend social and environmental values.

That is why I welcome the intentions that Commissioner Barnier has presented to us here for the revision of public procurement, as one of the 12 priorities of the Single Market Act, still this year. Thank you.
I will congratulate my colleague Rula and all those who collaborated with her.
Important in the field of public contracts is the issue of public procurement and
unfortunately, the objectives set by the European Union, 50% of submissions by electronic procedure in 2010, failed, with average values of only 5%.
Only a few countries, such as my own, Portugal, have succeeded in this area.

The advantages of electronic public procurement are all too evident and have been outlined here. It allows for the replacement of costly access processes with simple consultation of the electronic platform, which means it reduces many costs for companies, especially for those

For small and medium-sized enterprises, internet dissemination and the ease of receiving procedural documents expand the number of suppliers, increasing competition and enabling better purchasing, making the public procurement award process more efficient.

easier and more flexible, simplifies access to European Union public contracts, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, thereby facilitating their participation in the public procurement market, which is crucial for these important drivers of the economy.
In this sense, we welcome and encourage the European Commission for strengthening the mechanisms to make public and electronic procurement an increasingly comprehensive reality. Thank you very much.

We are living through decisive hours for the fate of Europe. And while the situation has quickly passed, before everyone's eyes, from a problem of the Greeks or the Portuguese to a major European problem, the truth is that the inadequacy of the proposed solutions and their delay have not produced any effectiveness in the rapid deterioration of the situation.
The pursuit of solutions targeted at individual states, rather than truly European solutions, has allowed markets to continue speculating on sovereign debts and imposed deadlines and rhythms.
absolutely impossible that some states are trying to achieve with measures of a brutality previously unimaginable applied to people, companies and the public sector.

A common solution is absolutely essential, one that has already been found for the risk of European sovereign debt, which removes the pressure from the markets and speculation and gives time for the necessary adjustment to be made.
Without this, what we will end up with are countries that continue to lack the means to pay their creditors, destroyed economies, and a lot, lot of suffering.

I would like to thank the fellow shadow rapporteurs, with whom I have had fruitful collaboration, and also the rapporteurs of the partners from the four committees involved. These partners have made a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 47 compromises that were all approved.
This demonstrates the importance and interest generated by this topic of new skills and jobs.
It is, after all, about preparing Europe's human resources, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the next decade.
The key strategy for drafting the report was to reformulate common ideas to avoid repetition and ensure the report's coherence.
I think that objective has been achieved.
We all know that the crisis currently affecting us has highlighted the weaknesses of the European economic and social model, and has also negated many of the advances made in the past.
Since the first effects of the crisis began to be felt in the labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than 5 million jobs.
Today, there are nearly 23 million people without jobs.
Youth unemployment is even more frightening. The youth unemployment rate is close to 21% and is more than double the general unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all Member States unemployment rates vary with skill levels.
This means that people with higher qualifications find jobs more easily.
We also know that in the near future the need for skills, competences and qualifications will increase in all types and levels of profession.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges. First, job creation. Second, the need to remain competitive.
Then, the sustainability of social security systems. And finally, the difficulty in finding people with the right skills to fill job vacancies.
This report thus has a dual objective. First, to underline the need to act quickly to address skills gaps in Europe. Second, to better anticipate the needs of the labor market in terms of skills.

To achieve this, several measures stand out. First, to ensure the availability of skilled labor, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as skills in science, innovation, information and communication technologies, and foreign languages.
As I mentioned earlier, skill needs should be identified early, with a time frame of at least 10 years.
Today, we are aware of the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need for investment in ecological qualifications.
Then, participation in lifelong learning, professional requalification, and reducing school dropout rates must be increased.
Another important issue is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications and the urgency of moving forward with this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the link that must exist between educational establishments and the needs of the labour market.
Internships must be of high quality and supervised by tutors so that they can lead to employment and put an end to any abuses of the situation of interns.
Particular emphasis is also placed on the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote job demand and creation.
We have a future ahead of us and we have to create jobs.
And small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role in achieving this goal.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers, hence the need for coordination of social security systems so that workers can have their acquired rights guaranteed, especially the portability of pensions.

Finally, the issue of labour market flexibility. To improve the functioning of the labour market, the rules of flexicurity should be adapted to the socio-economic contexts of each Member State. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. I begin by thanking all my colleagues who have spoken in this lively debate.
All colleagues made very useful contributions and contributed to a very constructive discussion on an agenda that is ambitious at a time when we are experiencing a serious crisis.

Incidentally, this discussion is taking place on the eve of a European Council meeting that will show whether or not there is the political will to overcome the difficulties we are experiencing and whether there is a will

policy for a deepening of our coordination in economic terms and whether there is really a harmonized and unitary will to be able to carry forward the ambition that is in this agenda. In other words, to have

new jobs in the next decade, new jobs that will give hope to young people who are currently unemployed and to those who are currently studying, hope in a labor market that is inclusive, that responds to their needs.

ambition for dignity through work and who also have the opportunity to be in a permanent dynamic to keep up with the challenges of a globalized economy with a momentum that has no parallel in recent generations.

That is why our ambition is truly to create jobs, to have economic growth, not only to respond to those who are unemployed as a result of the crisis, but also to those who are entering the job market.

response to the major challenges that lie ahead with the green economy, with health services, with services in the area of transport, accommodation, which require all of us a different vision, an intelligent vision and an inclusive vision of the labor market.
Thank you very much to all.

Marisa Matias. Thank you very much, Madam President. What we were told here today in the Council's statement is that, for technical reasons, democracy would have to be sacrificed in terms of the European semester. But what we are talking about is a political issue. And the question I pose is whether there can be political coordination without democracy.
Where, then, is the scrutiny of the European Parliament?
Where is the scrutiny of National Parliaments on their major budgetary choices?

But if the issue were technical, as it was stated here, then we are talking about a variable technique. Because we know how the Council substantially eased the conditions for the four countries on the waiting list, France, Italy, Hungary, Spain. It did not do the same for the countries under bailout.
So what kind of intergovernmentalism is this that allows Germany to give opinions about Portugal, but does not allow Portugal to give opinions about Germany?
And, Mr. Spokesman, I ask you only to pay attention to this: no problem of democratic legitimacy is resolved by asking deputies to consult information on the internet.
This is a problem of infosclerosis, not a problem of democratic exclusion, that's what we're talking about here. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. A word of thanks first to the rapporteur from Ardenne for the quality and timeliness of this report, and also to Commissioner Andor for the initiatives announced.
Poverty is indeed a very serious problem that requires effective and rapid action to stem the rise of the phenomenon that currently affects more than 80 million Europeans.
The serious crisis we are already experiencing has exacerbated this situation and made the times we are living in dramatic, as Commissioner Andor said.
The number of unemployed people continues to rise, and we all know that a lack of employment is a passport to poverty and social exclusion.
This scenario requires resources, willingness and a great deal of effort from the European Commission and the Member States.
If this does not happen, the goal of lifting 20 million European citizens out of poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
That is why I warmly welcome the initiative of the Platform Against Poverty, which is a very important instrument for ensuring social justice.
But no one doubts that the best antidotes to poverty and social exclusion are job creation and the promotion of economic growth.
President, access to the internet should today be considered as a new fundamental right of citizens and not just as a mere object of commerce, because of this right
essential things such as freedom of expression, access to and sharing of information, access to and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism, depend on it.

And that is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or contracts that block free choice and the possibility of easily changing providers, particularly in the mobile telecommunications world, as we also know.
Active citizenship therefore requires that complete and transparent information be provided.
Internet shutdowns are not only exclusive to political regimes that are afraid of their own people.

It can also happen that choices are made, as a result of economic considerations, by offering privileges to police clients, and this is a less equitable treatment for clients who are not as profitable.
That is why I support Parliament in clearly standing up for net neutrality and defending its all-encompassing nature.
Let's speak the truth.
We have been taking the medication for three years to get out of the crisis and the situation is getting worse day by day.
Instead of healing, we have created two fatal vicious circles.
The first, between banks and states.
In Europe, it is now easier to discuss the bankruptcy of a state than that of a large bank, but it is still expected that banks will finance states and that states will save their banks.
This spiral must be broken.
The Commission must push forward with European legislation that protects taxpayers from bank crises.
But it is also vital to protect debt from speculators' attacks.

And for this, it is urgent to prepare, already in the afternoon, the coordinated emissions of sovereign debt, whether called Eurobonds or Stability Bonds, and to guarantee it through robust instruments of a Community nature and not an intergovernmental one.
In short, we also need to review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious circle results from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically wrong.

It ignores the essential fact that a single market and a single currency, built by political choice among unequals, necessarily exacerbates competitiveness imbalances between the center and the periphery.
And this is what needs to be anchored in economic governance.
No, Mr. RompÃ³i, through sanctions that promote the crushing of wages and incomes through one country's control over another.
Previously, through involvement, Mr. Commissioner, of both countries with surpluses and those with deficits, in order to converge productivity through investment, education, and science.
The sanctions have only generated unemployment, disillusionment, and a wave of poverty from which we cannot escape.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Commissioner, the integrated maritime policy advocates a coordinated approach to the management and governance of oceans, seas and coasts, in a global and coherent perspective of all European policies related to the sea.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach implies the interaction of European policies related to the sea and requires better governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy have been demonstrated over the past few years through various funded initiatives in the form of preparatory actions and pilot projects.
The integrated maritime policy must therefore continue to benefit from adequate funding during the remaining years of the current financial programming period.
In this sense, I advocate for adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects, and I support the definition of a stable framework regarding the objectives of this program.

Issues of policy, governance, sustainability, and maritime surveillance are, for obvious reasons, topics of particular interest to certain regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

The eruption regions, with the exception of French Guiana, are small and rare, and depend on a limited number of economic activities, in which sea-related and fishing activities assume special importance.
Furthermore, the outermost regions contribute to the European Union having the most extensive exclusive economic zone in the world.

The ORs represent more than half of the European Union's exclusive economic zone, approximately 15 out of 25 million square kilometers, and, together with coastal regions, are crucial for the economic growth of the European Union and its member states.

A programme such as the one provided for in the Integrated Maritime Policy should benefit these regions by giving priority to transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is therefore necessary to ensure continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also and above all for the next financial framework starting in 2014.
It would be a missed opportunity in the context of integrated maritime policy not to emphasize the enormous potential that the Atlantic and insular dimensions hold for the European Union.

The Atlantic, being the western maritime border of Europe, also establishes its connection to North and South America and Africa, conferring a strategic dimension to Europe that is indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy designed with an eye to the future.

And it is with the future in mind that the integrated maritime policy, in addition to promoting the coordination of maritime activities, should place the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension based on science and technology at the forefront of its priorities.

The investigation of the mid-Atlantic ridge, the deep sea, and the seabeds constitutes a new frontier whose potential exists in biotechnology and mineral resources and is of incalculable value for the knowledge economy.
The Union should therefore take advantage of the Azores' privileged position and the excellence of its oceanographic department to establish a deep-sea observatory there. Thank you.
Enough of this path.
When the diagnosis is wrong, the remedies don't work.
And in the case of the eurozone, excessive remedies have brought it to the brink of death.
The successive miraculous solutions that have been proposed have also been equally discredited by the markets.
the Financial Stability Fund, the successive austerity measures of the Stability and Growth Pact, the revenues of the Troika in the low-performing countries.
Blind discipline without growth generated a recessionary wave among fully interconnected economies that therefore contaminated each other with bankruptcies and unemployment.
And at the hands of the markets, that is, the rating agencies and speculators, governments are falling one after another and solvent countries are becoming insolvent.

Changing the treaties now is another step in this disastrous trajectory, with a major aggravating factor. We risk destroying what remains of national sovereignty by putting countries in the hands of the European Court of Justice.
No, there is no need to amend the treaties.
In this emergency we are in, we need to make two decisions.
First and foremost, a genuine agenda for sustainable growth and cohesion must be implemented.
Where is the 2020 Agenda?
Where is the relaunch budget?
Where are the project bonds for Europe's structural investments?
And secondly, it is necessary to protect sovereign debt.
Of course, the bailouts are necessary, but in this emergency we are in, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defends the sovereign debt against the speculators.
Not in a timid way, but with a definitive, determined stance, as befits any central bank that defends its currency and the economy that supports it.
To achieve this, there is no need to change the treaties; what is needed is political will and European conviction.
Let us amend the treaty when we have learned all the lessons from the present crisis. And there are many lessons to be learned, but this is certainly not the time. Thank you very much.
Mr President and Commissioner Dalli, the first Single Market Forum, an idea stemming from the Grech report, took place in Krakow.
It was rich in content and fruitful in the debate conducted by the Polish presidency with European, national, regional and local authorities and civil society.
We have a roadmap outlined in the Commission's communication of 12 April with the 12 levers
It needs to be passed into law, as does the strategy for the other 38 priorities identified in the Single Market Act.
For there to be a market, trust is necessary.
Now, the trust of citizens and consumers cannot be taken for granted; it needs to be stimulated, nurtured.
The single market is not just a buying and selling operation. It involves horizontal policies, such as health, social and consumer protection, labor law, the environment, and sustainable development.
The Single Market Forum should therefore become a flagship event of the European Union, held annually and attended by a diverse and increasingly participatory audience.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I think we are at a time of assessment regarding these crisis policies, austerity policies that have affected so many countries, and also the so-called structural reforms.
And it is in this context that I think we cannot help but see how they have generated so much social commotion.
And it has generated social commission not only in the most troubled countries, in the southern countries, not only in the so-called favelas and also in other contexts in Europe.
Just last week, Portugal experienced its largest general strike ever, involving both the public and private sectors. A strike that took to the streets.
But if we look at what happened today in the United Kingdom, we see that we witnessed the largest strike ever, especially if we consider that people took to the streets just as they did in Portugal.
And we expect a large demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this proves, Mr. President, and what the strikes prove when people take to the streets, is that the causes and problems we have been facing are common, and that is why the reaction is also common.
The crisis of the European Union is infecting all member states, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We have witnessed chaos in the financial markets and the growing inability to secure essential financing for the operations of our small and medium-sized enterprises, even those that are healthy, leading them to despair, bankruptcy, and unemployment.
It is a spiral that fuels the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the need for strict budgetary discipline, deep restructuring, and more economic governance. But these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counteract the ongoing degradation in the Union.

And if the truth is that we need precise policies to stimulate employment and growth, without which we will never be able to control sovereign debt, the central issue today is to ensure the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will collapse.
That is why, more than ever, more than a revision of the treaties, we need today a strong and secure intervention by the European Central Bank.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. We are all here today united around a resolution with a set of very important requests in terms of intervention.
We are speaking on World AIDS Day and this assessment of the 2009 resolution and communication is crucial.
It is precisely fundamental, things that have already been mentioned
We repeat ourselves because, unfortunately, there is still room for repetition, which means there is much to be done.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and the European economic area. A 2010 report speaks of more than 25,000 new cases.
If we consider neighboring countries, we are talking about more than 100,000 new cases.
And if we think that things can't get worse, they can always get worse.

And one of the issues I want to make very clear here has to do with the disinvestment that has been made in the health sector as a result of the economic and financial crisis we are currently experiencing.
And this disinvestment has seriously affected areas that are crucial for the fight against HIV-AIDS.
That is why, Commissioner, I believe that the Commission has a crucial role to play here in calling on the Member States to fulfil their obligations in these areas.

A second issue is also related to the increase in discrimination, which has also been highlighted by the economic and social crisis. Discrimination against workers who have lost their jobs because they are carriers of this virus.
And that is why prevention, treatment, and care should be equal for everyone, regardless of gender, age, or the region where they live.
I hope we can implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr Draghi.
We are living through special and dramatic circumstances and they require determined and urgent measures.

The spiral between state debt and bank debt must be broken, but at the moment the priority is to defend the states, to ensure that the eurozone countries and the euro itself are not destroyed by the rating agencies and speculators.
In the report that we will approve, Tremosa and Bacel, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the eurozone, create Eurobonds and a European treasury. But all of this takes time.
At the moment we are talking about an emergency and in that context the only solution is in the hands of the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Today you should not be inhibited in your intervention and action by limited interpretations of your mandate.
Its mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to deal with inflation.
In a moment like this, there is no doubt. Saving the euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and the citizens expect from the European Central Bank.
Good luck and courage, Mr. Tragui.
The European Neighbourhood Policy already included, in a very explicit way, the positions that the European Parliament has been adopting.

And it was with great satisfaction that we saw a large part of the principles and proposals that we have been defending in this House included in the subsequent communications from the Commission and the Council.

I would also like to express my gratitude for the excellent and ongoing collaboration and coordination we have maintained throughout this time with Vice-President Cathy Ashton and Commissioner Stefan FÃ¼le and their offices.
First and foremost, this is due to the upgrade achieved in our relationship with neighboring peoples.

By prioritizing relations with the general population and with civil society organizations in particular, we will be giving greater objectivity and greater effectiveness to our neighborhood policy, which is intended to be exclusively founded on the universal values that we defend and share.
However, I emphasize that the European Union does not intend to impose a predefined model or formula for political reforms in third countries.
But when it comes to our taxpayers' money, we should give more to those who are doing more to approach the values we believe in.
This principle means that the faster a country progresses with its internal reforms, the more support it will receive from the European Union.
The principle of more for more is therefore correct, fair and consistent.
Which obviously means that we also anticipate the possibility of there being cases or countries where we will have less for less.
The neighbourhood policy is now based on the defence of the pursuit of common values and a commitment to democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance.
But this pursuit implies greater accountability.

Our partners are called upon to take more responsibility in the process. That is why we advocate for the principles of greater differentiation, greater conditionality, and the concept of more for more.
By adopting a bottom-up approach and tailor-made policies when dealing with our partners, we make development and institutional capacity more effective.

The institutional building that we so want to defend and that lies at the foundation of the rule of law and the democratic process, which we want to see implemented as quickly as possible in the societies, economies, and communities of our neighbors.

The idea is to give a voice to citizens, as well as to all civil society movements that identify with our values, supporting organized movements that strive for positive and democratic change in their countries.
countries, improving the rights of women and children, building and deepening the principles of freedom, whether of expression, association, religious belief, press, choice, etc.
etc. With fair elections, the fight against corruption, a rule of law, greater social justice, respect for minorities, environmental protection and efficient use of resources.
The serious economic and social problems faced by our neighbors also require immediate action.
It is evident that without our concrete help, the ongoing democratic processes may fail.
These are the ideas we have always advocated for the future European neighbourhood policy.
These are the proposals contained in the report that we are putting to the vote.
Now is the time to act.
For our part, we will continue to be vigilant and to exercise the new monitoring and oversight powers now conferred upon the European Parliament.

Finally, I would like to thank my colleague, co-rapporteur and friend Marek Siwiec, to whom I extend a very special word of appreciation for his remarkable work on the eastern dimension of the neighbourhood policy.
Also to the Shadow and Opinion rapporteurs and to all of you for the countless suggestions proposed in the amendments you presented and which I believe have enriched our work.
And a final word to the Secretariat of the Commission and to the Political Advisors for the excellent support work I have benefited from.
In European neighborhood policy, not including the outermost regions, as active borders of Europe in different parts of the world.
As ultraperipheral regions, as external borders, convey our values of democracy, peace, and respect for human rights and fundamental rights to third countries in these regions.
Ultra-polycentric regions such as those in France absolutely need greater integration within their geographical areas.

Far removed from the Union's internal market, this integration is crucial for their development and represents a huge potential for deepening the neighbourhood policy with the countries of the surrounding regions.

The neighbourhood policy requires a new impetus. An impetus that also takes advantage of the privileged historical and cultural relations that the outermost regions of the Azores, Madeira and the Canary Islands maintain with North America and South America.
These regions can and should play a more active role in promoting the European Union as part of a new European policy of revitalization.

Thank you, Mr. President. It has been a year since last September, after a thorough debate, in which I also participated as the person responsible for this matter in the Socialist Group, promoting meetings and debates with European, national, and regional organizations, linked to the

Parliament approved the BouvÃª report, which is addressed to retailers, manufacturers and farmers, and contains an exhaustive set of recommendations to the European Commission aimed at achieving fair income for farmers and improving the functioning of the food supply chain.

Since 2008, the Commission and Parliament have been producing communications, reports, and recommendations, and establishing high-level forums and groups to address this serious problem, but in practice, nothing has changed beyond increased awareness.

We return to the subject and it must be said without hesitation: a significant part of the problems that farmers face stem from highly penalizing behaviors, imposed mainly by operators of modern distribution.
The problems have been more than identified.
What has been lacking from the Commission and the Member States is an effective political will to implement the solutions.
Until then, we will continue to see losses for farmers and consumers.
to say that this treaty is useless.
Unfortunately, it is above all dangerous.
First, because it reinforces with more punishments and rigid rules a recipe that does not work.
The downward spiral has begun.
Who can trust a doctor who cannot distinguish weight loss from anorexia?
A doctor who, the more the patient weakens, the more he insists on the medicine, while openly discussing the probability of his death.
How many more countries have to go into recession before the Commission and the Council realise that the diagnosis is wrong?
But it is also dangerous, because we here represent the citizens of Europe.
23 million and 700 thousand are unemployed.
Almost 6 million young people have no hope of finding a job.
Doesn't the Council and the Commission realize that ignoring this fact, not giving an adequate response, reveals an autism and insensitivity that are politically explosive?
Let us be clear.
The Great Recession is not a fatality, it is an ideological obsession.
There is an alternative agenda. It must be, however, not of words, but of action.
Where are the project bonds to finance European investment?
where is the reinforcement of the European Budget with the tax on speculative financial products.
Where is the barrier that should protect countries from the ruinous interest rates imposed on them by the markets, leading them to ruin?
Citizens demand options, not words, but competent options. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Madam President. The Commission and the Governments now promise to reprogram the structural funds to support SMEs and create jobs.

However, it is worth remembering that at the end of last year the Commission also decided to suspend the allocation of structural funds to countries that do not or did not meet the deficit or debt targets.
One does not need to be a genius to realize that either the promise is fulfilled or the punishment is exacted. But the two cannot happen at the same time.
And that is why, Mr. Commissioner, I want to ask you a very direct question. Has the decision to suspend the allocation of structural funds been maintained? Was it frozen or was it cancelled?
In other words, can Greece, Portugal, Ireland or other countries still access funds they are entitled to if they do not meet the targets being imposed by the Commission and by you?
Please respond, Mr. Commissioner. The fact is that in Portugal we are very tired of promises, you know?
Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, the proposal made by President Barroso to redirect the available structural funds to support our SMEs
and stimulate employment, especially youth employment, could not be more welcome, especially for economies that are subject to strong austerity measures, such as the Portuguese economy.

With the agreement on external intervention and the major difficulties in financing the economy, and in particular our small and medium-sized enterprises by the banking system, this proposal takes on special importance for regions like the Azores, which have a high absorption and good use of funds, but are in a recessive context.

they can here achieve a real possibility of stimulating their economy through small and medium-sized enterprises and the indispensable contribution of our generation of best-prepared young people ever in the best response to growth and employment with these funds
we could obtain.
What we need to know, Commissioner, is how in practice we will access these funds and how our regions will participate in their reprogramming.

President, Commissioner, the milk package that is being presented here as an instrument for organizing the sector contains both positive and important elements, such as the strengthening of the role of producer organizations and interprofessional organizations, and contractual aspects that, in some states, may even lead to disputes with workers.

However, this falls far short of the instruments that the sector needs to thrive in the coming years, within the framework of an agriculture that we want to have in Europe, with access to a fair distribution of value in the food chain, and that does not transform into an agriculture of large-scale intensive farms, concentrated in a few Member States.

If improving the condition of self-regulation in the relationship between industry players is desirable, thinking that this alone is sufficient is a serious mistake that could drive thousands of dairy farmers, dozens of regions, and even some countries away from dairy production.
The debate on the regulation of the dairy sector from the perspective of an economically, socially, environmentally, and territorially sustainable sector continues, and is therefore still ongoing.
And we cannot abandon the milk quota system without having ensured that there are genuine instruments for managing supply.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner. From May 2010 to today, we have seen how a problem that seemed manageable has escalated uncontrollably.
It is true that the fight against the crisis triggered by the financial markets has worsened the debt of the Eurozone countries and that the most vulnerable have become particularly susceptible.

However, is it possible that countries sharing the same currency are left to the mercy of attacks by financial operators and those who profit by betting on the probability of eurozone countries going bankrupt?
The dire consequences of the Council and Commission's failure to respond have generated problems that are now undeniable.
The speculative interest rates applied to individual countries have made any strategy for exiting the crisis unfeasible.
The consequent worsening of the country's economic problem justifies a new interest rate hike, until the total cutoff of credit kills a country's economy and contagion does the rest.
This Parliament has long been a form of common management of sovereign debt, subject to demanding but clear rules.
We welcome the fact that the Commission has finally produced a Green Paper on the subject, what has been called Brazil.

Today it is clear that without some kind of obligations of this type, properly articulated with the European stabilization mechanism, the so-called protective barriers, the so-called firewalls, for sovereign debt do not exist.
