And as long as they do not exist, the euro is in danger and Europe is also in danger.

In the resolution that this Parliament overwhelmingly approved regarding the new treaty, it was absolutely clear that it is not acceptable to continue imposing more fiscal stability rules, budgetary discipline, and sanctions on the euro countries without taking concrete and urgent steps towards the solidarity-based management of sovereign debt.
The two processes will have to evolve in parallel.
That is what we expect from the Commission, and it is too late now.

I would like to think that this House of European Democracy will unanimously repudiate the behavior of President Assad and the Syrian authorities in the massacre of their own people, which we helplessly witness daily.
Why it is important that Europe can speak with one voice about the significance of the values of respect for human life, make a indiscriminate and nobly orchestrated massacre.
The entire international community must maintain pressure on the Syrian regime by implementing new restrictive measures.
The killings have to stop and this is not negotiable.
Emphasize dialogue, without a doubt.

A democratic Syria needs a transition period and guarantees for all its minorities. However, the implementation of more restrictive measures against the Syrian regime will not work if all countries do not pull in the same direction. And this has not, unfortunately, been the case.
In addition to thousands of deaths and the two shamefully rejected resolutions in the United Nations Security Council,
We continue to disapprove of the position of China and Russia, increasingly isolated in their unbelievable support for the Syrian regime.
Everything else remains the same. A rotten, desperate, and cornered regime continues to govern a country. And we, the international community, remain powerless to stop the genocide of a people.
We are already behind schedule in toughening up the action of the European Union and the International Community.
We must provide more concrete support to the Arab League in its interventions and its intentions to send a peacekeeping force to Syria.
We must wholeheartedly support the work of the Red Crescent in its efforts to minimize the suffering of the population.
The International Criminal Court must immediately initiate proceedings to punish those responsible for the crimes being perpetrated against humanity.

and as a form of pressure on the countries that have maintained support for Assad, also immediately prohibit the European Union's trade with all Russian or Chinese companies that have commercial relations.
And start yesterday.
Thank you, Mr. President. Welcome, Madam Commissioner, to discuss this topic of such great importance.
In fact, we are talking about central issues related to data protection, especially in a context where there may be conflict between two different jurisdictions.

And data protection is, in fact, one of the sensitive areas that has generated so much controversy and, in my opinion, should continue to generate. Because we are talking about what could be the clash between the

rights and guarantees, the safeguarding of European citizens who are protected by European legislation and then find themselves overtaken when legislation from other countries supersedes European legislation.
It is sensitive for several reasons.
It is sensitive because there is a rupture and there is doubt in what is a contract that, for all intents and purposes, exists between European citizens and European institutions.
When you provide your personal data, you trust that it will be protected by European entities and institutions and that it will not be distributed for other purposes,

And therefore there is a breach of trust here and this is a fact that is complicated to manage and on the other hand it is also a serious and perilous situation because the European Union ends up transferring personal data to third countries thus breaking that bond of trust that is generated

between European citizens and European institutions. And therefore, if citizens accept that European institutions can be guardians of their personal data in so many different areas, from health issues to other issues, as mentioned, such as business ones,

that require the data, and I am specifically talking, for example, about the case of the United States, which systematically requires data from the European Union, which is what we are doing when citizens assume they are giving up, and as I said, for the European Union to be the guardian of their data, what is done is a breach of trust.
Therefore, I also want to tell you, Madam Commissioner, that these issues have often been problematic for different reasons, but I will always be on the side of the demonstrations of citizens.

who want to safeguard the protection of their personal data. And if there are demonstrations that they believe are necessary because the European institutions do not comply, I think we should be on the side of the citizens and not on the opposite side.

It is almost a kind of betrayal that is being carried out. And that is why we are asking you this question, these questions we are putting to you, Madam Commissioner, so that you can clarify for us once and for all, because no community is built with destruction as its basis or foundation.

weakening of the bonds of trust that exist between its citizens and its institutions. And in this regard, Madam Commissioner, please answer us, to what extent can we ensure that European legislation overrides the legislation of third countries?
Because it is true that European legislation overrides the legislation of the 27 member states of the European Union, and citizens abdicate.
In this space of sovereignty, why should we accept that other countries, such as the United States, then override European legislation that overrides national legislation?
This needs to be clarified because it is indeed very sensitive, it is serious, and it is an issue that we must take into consideration.

And finally, Madam Commissioner, I would like to ask you, please, to tell us what the Commission is doing to prevent this from happening, to ensure it does not recur, and to protect the personal data of all citizens and

from companies and various sectors that are referenced in these issues, are in fact data that people can trust that are protected under what we protect. And by this I mean that I don't even share the view that all the information that is stored should be stored, but that is another debate.

Regarding this, as it is a serious issue and a precarious one in terms of citizens' rights, I would like you to provide us with these clarifications so that we can all feel more at ease. Thank you very much.

President, I would essentially like to say that we expect a major economic decision from the next Council for the countries that are under aid, which is closely linked to the issue of structural funds.
Structural funds need to be made more flexible
There are many that are yet to be used, most of them have only been used for large infrastructure projects.
they must be geared towards competitiveness, towards small and medium-sized enterprises, towards relaunching the economy.
The only investment that countries like Greece, like Portugal, like Ireland and like others can have at the moment is the one that comes from these structural funds.
It also left a political note for all the politicians of the Union, those who are in good faith in the European process.
When discussing these topics, it is necessary to respect, to be very careful about respecting national identities and the Member States. And not everyone needs to
There are sometimes many of them with good intentions, but not all have been up to the challenge of strictly respecting the national identity of each member state.
Thank you, Mr President, Mr President, Commissioner. I compliment the rapporteurs, but I would like to say that enough is enough of pious speeches about employment and growth.

Today, with the first results on macroeconomic imbalances in Europe, the veil is beginning to lift on why, in the European Union, and particularly in the eurozone, some countries are growing while others are inevitably unraveling.
Europe is losing competitiveness in foreign markets, and this agenda needs to be revised because much of the insufficient internal growth depends on this. But, focused on the internal market,
Four countries, including Germany, have been accumulating surpluses year after year, while 20 other countries, I repeat, 20, have been accumulating deficits year after year.
As deficits accumulate, the external debt of these countries increases in an unsustainable manner.
Of course this process has to be controlled.
Of course, discipline is necessary.
But it is important to ask today, in this context, is the solution of crushing the more fragile ones with recessionary policies the only possible solution?
Is the tax competition of some winners within the internal market still tolerated?

Can the largest European economy continue to develop common policies that favor it and internal economic policies that, while appropriate for its economy, capture most of the gains from the internal market in its favor?
Can the Commission and the Council continue to impose recessionary policies that tighten the economy of the most fragile, discussing
openly discussing the possibility of bankruptcy of sovereign states in the eurozone, when they know that the firewalls have never left the folder of intentions?
Are the Commission and the Council fully aware of the explosive political-economic risk that this discourse brings to Europe?
Yes, it is necessary to radically revise the recipes.
But for that to happen, there needs to be political will.
Until this will exists, out of respect for the citizens, let us stop saying that we defend growth and employment, because it is not true.
And citizens cannot continue to be deceived.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I begin by greeting the rapporteurs.
It is now a commonplace to say that we are experiencing the most serious financial, economic, and social crisis since the creation of our modern international financial model.
It cannot be stressed enough that unemployment rates in the European Union have reached historic records, making the fight against unemployment the top priority.
Youth unemployment is dramatic. In my country, Portugal, more than one in three young people are looking for a job and have no prospects of finding one.
our citizens so disbelieving
It is urgent to restore their confidence.
After years of reckless management of public finances, it is time to adopt fiscal reconciliation reforms and put the accounts in order.
But we did not move. Austerity without economic growth is only a partial solution.
The creation of more jobs and better jobs is the great European design.
Measures to ensure that young people do not go more than four months without receiving a job or training offer, as well as reducing the risk of poverty and social exclusion, must become a reality.
A year ago we witnessed the tragic combination of an earthquake, a tsunami, and a nuclear industrial accident, all in sequence.
Today we pay a heartfelt tribute to the many thousands of victims of Fukushima.
Honoring the victims is a way of telling them that we have learned our lesson. We must learn to cope with natural disasters. With nuclear disasters, we have a duty to prevent them.
But unfortunately that doesn't seem to be the truth.
A year after Fukushima and new nuclear power plants continue to be built.
A year after Fukushima and new nuclear power plants continue to be planned.
Japan unfortunately has the memory of enduring tragedies, Hiroshima, Nagasaki, and we Europeans also have the memory of an enduring tragedy, Chernobyl.
Fukushima forces us to reopen a debate that should never have been closed, the debate on nuclear energy.
A year ago, nuclear energy was unquestionable for the Japanese. Today, two-thirds of the Japanese do not want it.
They know it costs lives, they know this cost is priceless. On the contrary, it is a cost that increases from generation to generation.
The stubborn policy in favor of nuclear power is the policy of arrogance.
Here in Europe too, we have a majority of public opinion against nuclear power, and despite this, nothing seems to change.
There are currently 320,000 refugees in Japan. Of these, 100,000 will never be able to return home.
What was once familiar is now dangerous. What was once comfort is now ruin.
It is the ruin of a building or a house with radioactive vegetation. It is the ruin of contaminated soil or water.

And Fukushima cannot be visited like other ruins, for example, a Mayan ruin or a Roman ruin. But nevertheless, like these, Fukushima also portrays a civilization. And the ruin of Fukushima portrays our civilization.
the one that chose to include a deadly technology in its development model.
An earthquake and a tsunami have no culprits, but a nuclear disaster has those responsible.
In Japan, as in Europe, many citizens have decided to create movements to say goodbye to nuclear power.
They know better than anyone that safe nuclear power is a myth. They know better than anyone that there are no stress tests.
they can simulate what happened in Fukushima. And that's why we know that energy policies are national, but in the sky they are not.
As previously mentioned, diabetes affects more than 30 million people in Europe.
These are indeed the numbers of an epidemic.
And that is why I believe it is also justified to make a specific resolution regarding diabetes, especially since this is the first time this Parliament has addressed this issue.
It is the result of collective work and it is a work that does not nullify the work done so far on chronic diseases; on the contrary, it reinforces this capacity we have to intervene together.
We have about 325,000 annual deaths associated with diabetes, because we know that diabetes is the leading cause of, for example, heart attacks, blindness, amputations, and failure of vital organs.
And in light of these data, I believe we have two options.
The first is to say that it's not that serious, that we can live well with this and that each government should take care of itself.
The second is to say that the absence of a European strategy in this area is part of the problem.
I understand that we have a lot to do on this side.
and we have much to do in early diagnosis, in coordination, in investment in research.
And that is why this resolution has the value of a beginning and of joint work in this direction. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. What I wanted to draw attention to, basically, was to congratulate you on the Council's results.
Not because the measures are ideal, but because they are the possible measures.
There is no doubt that today we have come much further and can be more optimistic than we were three months ago and six months ago.
Many states have been making a huge effort to stabilize and consolidate their public finances, and this effort has only been made in some states by induction of the European Union.
It is essential for them to recover their credibility in international markets and it is essential for them to be able to grow in the long term.
With these guarantees that the states have given, among which the Portuguese state stands out, in terms of fiscal consolidation and budget consolidation, I am
I am convinced, also with the new treaty signed between the 25, that we will be in a position to seriously relaunch growth in the next steps of the European Council.
But only with this confidence that is being generated little by little is that growth to be made.
And that is why I say, solidarity from the richest with the poorest is important, but from the poorest with the richest is also important, providing these guarantees.
Mr President, I basically wanted to say that it is with great joy that we note that steps have been taken to integrate Serbia into the European Union.

This is very important because the experience of countries like Portugal, like Spain or like Greece, which were countries that lived under dictatorships and had a set of very serious problems, is the experience that European integration was the way to consolidate democracy.
And that is why Serbia also deserves this opportunity.
I would, in any case, like to give a slightly different note here than the one that has been given by my colleagues.

I know and welcome the great concern for minorities, but we must not forget the Serbian majority. It is crucial that the Serbs themselves have a place in the European Union and a full right to be there.
This cannot be forgotten.

There will be no peace in the Balkans without Serbia. And so, much as we emphasize the rights of minorities and they must be respected, we cannot forget the Serbian majority, their identity and their full right to be European citizens, equal to all others, with their own state and national pride.
Thank you, Mr. President. Portugal voted last week on the budget ultimatum, which is not, incidentally, a European treaty, it's good to mention that.

The government parties' vote in favor reflects the accumulation of decades and decades of stupidity and a typical attitude of the good student, who is grateful, doesn't think and obeys the bad teachers.
The position of the PS and its leader was to move from a very dangerous violent abstention to a creeping vote in favor.

This alliance makes our Portuguese Assembly of the Republic the first Parliament to accept the humiliation of amputating itself from one of its most important functions, for which the people elected it: to decide annually on the country's budget.
This is yet another blow from the European Union, yet another one. It is a blow in which the power of money becomes increasingly out of reach of the citizens' vote.
And I ask, Mr. President, is it democratic for someone to vote so that one can no longer vote? Thank you.
Fiscal consolidation is imposing almost unbearable demands on some European citizens.
However, each day there are fewer people who have to bear a greater burden.
The tax burden falls on workers, small and medium-sized enterprises, and consumers, yet we are witnessing completely disproportionate tax evasion and avoidance.
The group of European socialists wanted to know how much this tax evasion and avoidance was worth in the 27 countries. And it amounts to one trillion euros.
This is more than the European Union countries spend on health.

This means such a volume that if we spent just a fifth of this amount on investment, investment in Europe would rise from 2.7% of GDP to 3.5%. We are therefore talking about an exceptionally high value.

And the purpose of the resolution we are going to approve, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear demand to the Commission and the Council to accelerate concrete action to combat tax evasion and fraud.

This means, in particular, concrete initiatives for tax cooperation within the European Union, tax cooperation with our neighboring countries, particularly Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not country by country in a bilateral manner.
This means reforming and harmonizing accounting rules, increasing transparency and reporting.
This clearly means reactivating the fundamental issue of combating tax fraud and evasion through tax havens.
Europe is not a minor partner.
Europe is a major partner in the international context
Europe has an obligation, within the framework of the G20, to clearly advocate for a common fight against tax fraud and evasion.

Without this, we lose credibility with our citizens, and therefore, my final words in this debate are a call for the Commission and the Council to begin an effective fight against tax fraud and evasion. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating my colleague Nibler for her excellent work and noting the coincidence that on the Day of Europe, which we celebrate today, we are debating and will approve measures tomorrow that meet the legitimate aspirations of our citizens.
What is at stake in this regulation is to impose limits on mobile phone tariffs charged to European consumers when roaming, with the ultimate goal of ending roaming in the European area by 2016.
Our citizens will now benefit from a sharp drop in prices for calls, texts, and data.
If nowadays there are operators that charge 3 euros per mega, from July onwards the maximum price they will be able to charge is 70 cents per mega, with this value dropping to 20 cents in 2014.
As for incoming calls, the maximum price that can be charged will be 8 cents this year and 5 cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile phone users will save, as the Commissioner said, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit, higher quality of information for consumers.
Starting in the summer, operators will be required to inform consumers of the prices charged when they travel outside the European Union.
Until now, the obligation was only within the European space.
Third advantage, the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means increased competition that will stimulate better services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer will be able, if they so choose, to have two contracts, one for services within the national territory and another for services abroad, while keeping the same mobile phone number and having only one bill.
the consumer, our citizen, will also be given the option to contract with any European operator that offers the best price.
This report is the perfect example of the Europe of citizens, the Europe of freedom of movement and freedom of establishment. Thank you very much.
In February 2009, this Parliament approved a report in which it supported the European Commission's proposal to relaunch the European economy.
There were projects on clean energy, transport, new technologies, innovation, and even then the role of the European Investment Bank and the structural funds was being considered.
More than three years later, we have been able to produce the Six-Pack, the Euro Plus Pact, the Fiscal Compact, the Two-Pack, all of which are full of reinforced discipline and sanctions.

But meanwhile, while unemployment, especially among the young, reaches frightening levels, the European economy is entering a recession and more than 7 of its member countries are experiencing negative growth.
And yet, while Greece is no more than a first stone threatening to bring down the castle, the relaunch agenda seems to have been forgotten.
At the moment, this agenda is clear.
What matters now is not to attribute a sense of urgency to it, but a sense of emergency in a situation that threatens to explode.
A set of pillars urgently needs intervention.
First and foremost, the European Marshall Plan must be composed of investments that promote growth, employment, and convergence.
Project bonds are one of the possible sources.
Secondly, it is necessary to stabilize the interest rates at which countries finance themselves.
Let us at least prepare to coordinate sovereign debt issuance and jointly manage the accumulated debt.
Thirdly, the European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank must prepare to actually function as true firewalls in defense of European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that was foolishly transferred by the European Central Bank to commercial banks must reach the companies.
It is one billion euros that is held back in the banking system while thousands of viable companies die every day due to lack of financing.
Fifth point, investment makes no sense without demand.
The most fragile economies are crushed by austerity plans.
It is the strongest economies that need to stimulate internal demand.

The fact is that almost 80% of trade today is done within Europe. And it is up to the Commission, Mr. Commissioner Olli Rehn, to make recommendations aimed not only at the most fragile economies, but also at the most dynamic ones.
And finally, I will conclude now, Mr. President, there must be a limit to the revenues imposed by the troikas.

We must put an end to the punitive style, without dialogue and without accountability, with which senior officials determine the fate of millions of European citizens and the democratic institutions of member countries. Thank you very much, Mr. President.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Commissioners. What I wanted to say is very clear. Of course, the Portuguese MEPs from the EPP fully support all measures that can contribute to growth. There is no possibility of

if we come out of this crisis without promoting growth, especially in those states that are most affected by the financial crisis. But sometimes, when I listen to some colleagues here, I get the feeling that they think growth can continue with excessive deficits and poor public accounts.

Now, we have to keep insisting on reducing spending and on structural reforms. We can do everything on the growth side, but we cannot abandon the path of containment and reduction of public spending and...

structural reforms. More growth cannot mean more relaxation, more rest. More growth and more growth policies must go hand in hand with great rigor in public accounts and great rigor in structural reforms.
If we only start talking about growth and think that there are magical solutions to growth, we will end up again with an unsustainable public debt and we will continue without structural reforms.

That said, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, at the morning summit, it will not only be a matter of this long-term or medium-term issue of growth. It will be a matter of the urgent issue of Greece. And here I think it is crucial that the European States somehow stand by Greece.
We are responsible for finding a solution to the Greek problem. And I would like to repudiate here the statement made by the British MP who spoke of the Portugalization of Europe.
The Portugalization of Europe, at least on the level of values, would not be a negative thing. And therefore, it rejects this idea of trying, in the end, to humiliate or try to reduce any peoples.
We are all Europe and we all have a place in it.

Thank you very much, Mr President. Commissioner, you came here to tell us that every extra euro spent on debt is a euro less for job creation. So explain to us why we should continue with this obsession.

he came here to tell us that one of the priorities of the Summit is to keep Greece in the Eurozone. And I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, do we believe you or do we believe Dr. DurÃ£o Barroso or Mr. Trichet, who were saying exactly the opposite a few days ago?
He spoke about maintaining the eurozone, I ask myself, which euro?

in the euro we currently live in, in this zone we currently live in, or in the euro that was announced yesterday by Deutsche Bank in a study that referred to a G-euro, a second-category euro, in case the left won the elections in June in Greece.
This is a trap, Mr. Commissioner, it is the trap of a Europe held hostage by governments and it is the trap of a Europe held hostage by financial interests.
Let us not let people live in fear, because that is not a way to live. Europe can be different. You know, it's not a lack of money, it's a lack of shame.

Mr President, Mr Vaman, the first thing I wanted to say is that it is regrettable that the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative, Mrs Ashton, is not present for a debate of this importance.
In any case, we are pleased to be working once again with Minister Vaman, who made a statement here that I fully endorse.

I would like, first of all, to offer a word of comfort and solidarity to the Guinean people, who have basically been the people of Guinea-Bissau, a people systematically massacred by democratic instability, political instability, and great insecurity.
It was not enough that he was surrounded by poverty; he has been systematically affected by these evils.

I wanted to say, on the other hand, that the EPP, under its presidency, has been following this issue from the beginning. And it is also regrettable that the European Parliament can only manage to have a debate on this matter after a month.
This has to do with the invisibility of the Guinean people and the Guinean question.

And this invisibility is due to the fact that, unlike other very serious matters, there are no large economic interests at stake here that would motivate the European, American, and world powers to discuss the situation of the Guinean people.
But I must say, if an external reason is needed, if the misery and political instability are not enough for us to have a global humanitarian and political action, there is a reason.
less so if the drug trafficking situation that is spreading in Guinea and directly affecting European and American peoples were a reason for us to engage in this.
And that is why I am calling on the European Union to be stronger.

There is no doubt that Resolution 2048, there is no doubt that the decisions of the European Union, the community of Portuguese-speaking countries, the African Union, but perhaps not yet of the West African States community, are moving in the right direction.
But resolutions are not enough, we need actions.
We need to be firmer, we need to be more effective with the states that have the capacity to intervene in Guinea-Bissau.
This is our obligation.

And I believe that the European Union, at this moment, is responding well in terms of principles, but it is not responding as it should in terms of practical instruments for operation on the ground. And that is what I ask of the Council and I ask of the Commission.

Mr President, President-in-Office, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, globalisation has brought with it a disproportionate growth in the financial sector, whose transactions are now, as we know, 70 times greater than global wealth.

Opacity, very frequent transactions, high compensation, and very high risk have not only come to characterize the world we live in today, but are also fundamental reasons for the crisis we are going through.
However, this crisis came to demand accountability and much more effort from ordinary citizens than from the sector that had caused it.
So today, this moment is important.

It is important and I would personally like to see a situation where the tax is generalized in all European Union countries and subsequently extended to the rest of the world, through active participation of the Commission and the European Union in general in the context of the G20.
I would like it to be covered, or to cover, all products without exception,
I would like it to serve as a basis for the necessary reinforcement of the European Union's own resources.
In the short term, compromises must be accepted, but we must not lose sight of the direction in which we need to move.
And this can only be achieved with a clear identification of these objectives by this Parliament, by the Commission, and with a great spirit of compromise on the part of the Council.

This is what European citizens expect from us today, and I can only thank here today not only the role of Anipolimata, who was tireless in this process, but also all those who managed to overcome their differences to reach a common position.

Thank you, Mr. President, thank you, colleague Podimata. Today we have discussed here for the first time the tax on financial transactions, and its approval is the first sign that speculation will not go completely unpunished in this crisis we are living through.
This House and the European institutions must answer to the people and not to the financial markets.
For decades, the financial market lobbies have managed to govern the world without opposition and without any problems.
It is obvious to us that during 2008 and 2012 the crisis of the speculative financial market was at the root of most of the problems we experienced.
And yet, these speculative financial markets managed not only to prevent any action being taken, but also to facilitate a direct transfer from the citizens' pockets to these same speculative markets.

We have been fighting for this for many years, Mr. President, but it was only when the people all over Europe began to say enough is enough that there was finally some initiative on the part of the institutions that govern the European Union.
And so this is the answer we have to give to the citizens. It is a first sign that we have to give them.
The citizens of Europe, who have paid for everything, do not deserve for us to lack respect for them.
And therefore, this proposal is not complete, it is not perfect, it will not solve the entire problem of financial speculation, but it is an important signal.
We have been walking, not us, European leaders have been apologizing to the financial markets
they should apologize to the people they have affected.
And to conclude, Mr. President, quoting a now famous politician, it is these markets we are talking about, these markets that govern us without ever having been elected.

I sincerely hope that governments will give a sign of trust to the people and I sincerely hope that with this approval and the positive vote of my colleagues we will start talking about justice and solidarity in Europe.
Colleagues, gather your courage, let's get this project passed.
Thank you, Mr. President. The financial transaction tax should serve as a way to control and discourage high-risk speculative activities in the financial sector.
It aims to reduce speculation and increase healthy competition, the foundation of the single market, and also generate revenue.

The Podimata report attempted to bring the European Commission's initial proposal closer to the UK's well-known Stamp Tax. In this way, we made this proposal more attractive to reluctant Member States.
The Council is also expected to understand the message.

If in the Commission's proposal the tax applied to transactions of financial institutions located within the territory of the European Union, it is now intended that transactions in European assets, even if carried out by non-Europeans, should also be taxed.
This measure will broaden the revenue base and reduce evasion.
It is expected that tax revenues will be considered as a source of own resources of the Union or of the States, reducing the taxes of the Member States, a matter still to be decided.
I conclude, Mr. President, by congratulating the rapporteur on the quality of her work and I hope that this symbolic text...
Madam President, this weekend we had another request to save the private banking sector.

they keep saying the same argument, which is to prevent contagion to the eurozone. And what I ask is whether we have learned nothing. Greece, Portugal, Ireland and now Spain, and yet the contagion continues.
But what kind of containment of contagion is this that is destroying us?

This policy does not work, we should already know that. It is the same rulers who say there is no money for culture, education, health, public goods, who, when the banks ask or the markets make it appear, do so almost miraculously.
This economic policy is not a remedy, it is a deadly poison for growth, for employment, for the European economy, for Social Europe.
The markets dictate and the governments obey and blackmail the peoples. And that is what the governments are doing with Greece at the moment during the election period.

I sincerely hope that it is in the best interest of all of us that the Greek people do not let themselves be blackmailed next Sunday and that they give us a lesson, because this recipe, Madam President, is a recipe for disaster. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, dear colleagues. Unfortunately, the proposals we are discussing here today confirm the prohibition of anti-crisis policies in the eurozone and also implement the logic of the fiscal treaty.

There are some statements of intent, but they are very timid. I refer, for example, to the roadmap for a day when one might begin to think about ways to define possible legislation for the hypothetical introduction of Eurobonds.
The problem is that this day will only come when all the problems of the eurozone have been resolved, and that day is taking a long time to arrive, a very long time indeed.
We supported some aspects of this proposal, but at this pace, everything will be too little, too late.
Placing a country under legal protection implies maintaining interest rates and amounts, as well as prioritizing new loans. In other words, it requires,
Member states that honor their debt are deprived of all and every instrument that could allow them to grow and find the resources to do so.

Let's be frank with each other. The only legal protection that exists in these proposals and is provided for is for the creators. But even those won't be resolved, because it's not effective for them either.

As we have seen in Greece, Ireland, Portugal and now in Spain, this means condemning countries to recession, unemployment and insolvency. And I conclude, Mr President, by saying that the worsening of these situations and their spread to other economies brings us closer to a point of no return.
Faced with the complete failure of austerity, the European Commission or the German Government are proposing the same policy, but in overdose. It is neoliberal fanaticism that is killing the euro.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Given the extremely limited time we have, I only want to say at this moment that the Commission can count on this Parliament, as it has always counted on it.
Parliament in effective work for the solidity of the eurozone and Europe, but this is only achieved when there are initiatives that focus on discipline, we

we managed to add the conditions for a balanced sharing of gains and sacrifices between the different member states and between the different citizens, and a hope, a hope that we will emerge from the crisis we are going through.
For this hope to exist, other initiatives are needed, and it is these that this Parliament is trying to implement. An initiative focused on investment, growth, and control.
the sovereign debt that has been the Achilles' heel of those, obviously, reflecting the fragility of the economic systems of some of the member countries.
Commissioner, you can count on us, Council, Madam President, you can count on us, but the agenda must be a comprehensive agenda, it cannot be an agenda that does...
discipline is the condition for everything else to follow, making discipline the alpha and omega of our European proposals.

Our citizens expect this of us, they can count on Parliament, and I want to thank my colleagues once again, the rapporteurs, Mr. GÃ³zesque, the other rapporteur, and all the colleagues who, as shadow rapporteurs or merely active participants in the construction of this project, were able to contribute.
for a more balanced, more solid Parliament project, which I hope will deserve the respect, the capacity for dialogue and the spirit of construction and compromise that it has had so far.
Thank you. Thank you very much, Mr. President. Thank you very much, Madam President. Thank you very much, Commissioner.

Thank you very much, Madam President. In addition to thanking everyone who contributed to this result, I would like to request that the final vote be postponed so that we can negotiate immediately at the trilogue level.
Today, we are confronted with three agendas: the growth agenda, the agenda concerning bank management, and the agenda concerning the management of sovereign debt.
And dealing with the European semester involves including these three dimensions.
On the issue of growth, I think it is important to emphasize at this point that the Commission's recommendations cannot only focus on
countries with deficits. They must also affect countries that have surpluses. And if some have to suppress their internal demand, others have to release it.

I also think that in terms of growth, it is essential that the Commission controls the recommendations of the so-called troika. Because when a country enters a recession, it cannot continue to crush its public investment, to crush public spending as if nothing had happened.
The troikas have to have their recipe reviewed and adjusted according to the results. And I want to tell you, Mr. Commissioner, that we approve here today in...
Parliament has called for the launch of a tool for growth and counter-cyclical activity in the order of 1% of the European Union's GDP over 10 years.

A second dimension that is fundamental is the dimension of what is now called the Banking Union. We requested in Parliament that this be done two years ago, in a report from June 2010. So far it has not been implemented.

A third dimension is the sovereign debt dimension. Without it, there is no stability in Europe. And I also want to tell you that today we approve the Tupac here, but we introduced in the Tupac, in addition to austerity,
something else has been missing, and that is the immediate establishment of a redemption fund, using German terminology, so that sovereign debt exceeding 60% can be managed collectively.

This is a legislative text and we expect the Commission's full support for this Parliament initiative in order to control the completely threatening spiral that is currently destroying the European Union. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. Now that we intend to discuss a growth pact, it is essential not to forget citizenship and consumers, in essence, the human and social dimension.

which gives it substance and which was the subject of one of the three reports on the Single Market Act of 2001. Why should any growth pact take into account the sacrifices and social benefits associated with it?

Just as important as a test of the internal market will be a test of the social impact of all measures taken to achieve the single market. A test, yes, an examination that allows us to measure the progress achieved for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union.
Since 2008, Europe has already lost more than 6 million jobs.
In my country, Portugal, the economy is suffering an unprecedented backlash and unemployment among men, women and young people is reaching historic records.
According to forecasts by the Bank of Portugal, the situation will worsen in the next two years.
It is in this context that we support and welcome the initiative of the new employment package and congratulate Commissioner Andor.
Now and always insisting on the basic premise of the need for economic growth, the Member States will really have to focus their efforts on job creation.

The means to achieve this should involve subsidies for hiring that create new jobs, reducing the tax burden on labor, and support for the creation of new businesses and entrepreneurship, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises that maintain jobs.
National employment policies must bear in mind that the areas with the greatest potential for job creation are health, information and communication technologies, and the green economy.
It is urgent, as stated in the communication, to reduce the gap between the qualifications provided by education and the skills demanded by the job market.
On the other hand, one of the solutions to combat unemployment involves worker mobility.
It is also crucial to highlight the use of structural funds for job creation and the practical importance of the Euros portal as the primary instrument for recruitment and job offers in Europe.
Finally, social governance must be on the agenda because our citizens are eagerly waiting for concrete results. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Commissioner, it is true that six months have passed since this scandal involving GDP occurred, and the most unbelievable thing is that a private company could have managed to do this for ten years.
operated in the market and introduced silicone implants that were intended for the construction and manufacture of mattresses and were used in women in 71 countries.
This has affected hundreds of thousands of women, as mentioned earlier. It is estimated that around 500,000.

Now, we are talking about estimates because there were failures and serious failures in this process. We know that what happened with this company is a criminal case, it is a fraud, it is a court case, but we also know...

that there is fraud here that must be controlled by the courts and the courts will deal with it. But there is a legal flaw, there is a legal vacuum and we must deal with that. We have responsibilities in this matter.

For 10 years we were unable to identify what the criminals were able to identify. Therefore, there was a void in terms of control, in terms of traceability, in terms of files, in terms of records, everything failed. But these gentlemen from this company were able to put into practice what we were unable to control.

This process is not only about the issue of lack of information, which is indeed very important, the lack of information on all issues related to breast implants, but also about the humiliation of thousands of women and the humiliation in particular of those women who had to undergo tests to find out whether or not they had been fitted with the correct implants.

We are talking about a public health issue and we cannot be lax on public health. We control so many unnecessary things. We even control the authenticity of car parts. We recently approved a directive on this.

We have to control what is fundamental to people's lives. The revision of the Medical Devices Directive is good news; it would have been better news if we didn't have to do it, but now that we are going to do it, let's apply it with

conditions with traceability, transparency, control, sanctions, because unfortunately the sanctions, even if they are applied, will not be applied to the women who have suffered from this problem and the states must assume full responsibility.

Thank you, Mr President. I would like to state very clearly that the Council meeting at the end of June is crucial for us and that what is essential is that a European solution to this crisis is sought.
From our point of view, the problem so far is that we have been dealing with each of the issues that arise in isolation and individually.

The time has come for us to have a global solution for Europe. A solution that involves, as President Douro has made very clear here, more integration, more cooperation, greater alignment of European policies, and a revaluation of the Community method.
It is essential that alongside stability there is growth, but that we do not abandon concerns about stability.
We therefore count on a global European response, not a response divided for each state or for each region in difficulty.
The productive and increased production possibilities led to considerable increases in milk production, creating critical situations, decreasing prices, and low prices in the milk and dairy market.

In many regions with strong productive potential, these surpluses were sold at bargain prices in the market of other countries, generating even greater downward pressure on the prices paid to producers in those countries.

This happened, for example, with French milk sold in France at double the price it was sold in Galicia. And producers, with the sharp increase in the cost of raw materials and production factors, now find their ability to withstand low prices extremely reduced.

This is a bad prognosis for many farms and many productive territories in Europe, and it also seems to be a clear indication of what the future may hold without quotas and without adequate supply regulation instruments.
There is, therefore, a need for a detailed audit of the territorial impacts on thousands of farms across the European Union of abolishing these instruments that we currently have to regulate supply.
Thank you, Mr President. I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on this report.
This is a matter of utmost importance for Europe.
At a time when we are experiencing a serious economic, financial and social crisis, protecting intellectual property rights by combating counterfeit products is crucial for the European economy.
This protection should enhance research performance and promote innovation. It should ensure scientific and technological knowledge, contributing to the development of new products and services.
All of this with the aim of generating growth and creating quality jobs.

Unfortunately, in recent years we have witnessed a significant increase in the violation of intellectual property rights in Europe, which represents annual losses, as mentioned here, of 250 million euros for companies and the destruction of 185,000 jobs in the European area.

But beyond these negative effects on the European economy, the violation of these rights also constitutes a serious threat to the health and safety of European consumers, since many counterfeit products, such as food, cosmetics, medicines, etc., are falsified,
are produced in unregulated environments.
That is why the customs authorities of the European Union play a crucial role in preventing counterfeit products from entering the internal market.
The revision of this regulation aims to strengthen the control of the application of the legislation in question, reinforce the legitimacy of its intervention, and increase the
legal clarity by adapting the provisions of the Regulation to new realities and developments, thereby contributing to better protection of the European economy and consumers.
Intellectual property rights are thus a crucial priority for achieving the objectives of the 2020 Strategy in order to achieve smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. In fact, the election of a new Egyptian President in the post-Mubarak era is good news. But we cannot delude ourselves, these presidential elections do not in any way close the transition process that is taking place in Egypt.

It was rightly pointed out that the dissolution of Parliament days before the presidential elections puts several risks on the table and, in this case, the power that is concentrated in the Superior Council of the

Armed Forces is at the very least exaggerated. They have legislative power, they have reduced the power of the President and, in addition, they still have in their hands the definition of changes to the Constitution.

Now, all of this raises some concerns for us and should raise some concerns for us because the Egyptians risk becoming hostages to military power and a return to the past, lacking a fundamental element: a democratically elected parliament.
It is not up to us to bring about change in Egypt, it is up to the Egyptians,
but I think that we Europeans will have to stand by all changes that propose the restoration of what is democratic legitimacy and a democratically elected Parliament. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Dear colleagues, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague, the rapporteur, Lara Comi, for the excellent work she has done on this report, which is of vital importance for the future of Europe.
In a rapidly changing world and society, Europe needs a comprehensive, integrative, effective and up-to-date standardization system.
A system that ensures the proper functioning of the internal market, that improves consumer protection and their lives, but also protects the environment, is essential.

As it is also very important to have more innovation and social inclusion, as well as interaction and communication between networks and systems, especially in the field, as has already been emphasized here, of new information and communication technologies.
As Professor Monti stated in his report A New Strategy for the Single Market, European standardisation is essential for the governance of the internal market, emphasising that
There is a need to review the European standardisation process, which should maintain the advantages of the current system and find the right balance between the European and national dimensions.

In this sense, the report we are now discussing follows and defends these objectives, which are correct and appropriate. To end the slowness and fragmentation that exists and causes companies to incur costs

transaction costs and higher unit costs, strengthen the participation of SMEs in standardisation activities, particularly at national level, and facilitate their access to these standards, also strengthen

On the other hand, the participation of parties representing the interests of society, such as consumers, environmentalists, workers, and people with disabilities, is maintained, along with financial support for European organizations created to represent public interests.

I conclude by saying that the approval of this report will contribute to the relaunch of the European project, to European innovation, to the strengthening and competitiveness of our companies. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr President, Commissioner. The future common fisheries policy must give priority to its environmental, economic and social sectors.
in a synergistic and non-hierarchical manner, in the interests of sustainable development and in line with the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth of the EU 2020 strategy.
As rapporteur for the third regime, I would like to highlight the particularity of some regions, such as the outermost regions, whose economies are heavily dependent on the sector.

In these regions, the reform of the common fisheries policy should seek to ensure the survival and future prosperity of their artisanal and small-scale fishing fleets, thereby safeguarding and defending the employment that depends on them.

I agree with the European Commission's position on the need for an adjustment of this policy and specific measures that must take into account the disparate realities of the fishing and aquaculture sector in various coastal regions.

I argue that this policy places the emphasis on regionalization as a form of governance, through a strengthening of the participation of various stakeholders, so that in the future, a more adequate response to the demands and sensitivities of each maritime basin will be possible.
We are reaching the decisive moments when we will shape the new fisheries policy in Europe. And we cannot fail.

The need and urgency to achieve sustainable balances in our fisheries resources, but also in the revitalization of our coastal fishing communities and the promotion of their socio-economic level, in the modernization of the sector and in the supply of quality food, require more than ever courage and bold measures.
We therefore have to make choices and prioritize objectives.

I proposed protection for the fragility of my region, suggesting that the exploitation of its resources be carried out taking into account scientific data, giving priority to our coastal communities in their exploitation, and restricting external access beyond 100 miles to the fishing banks there.
I proposed safeguarding the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities by rejecting the proposals for transferable quotas.

I proposed that our communities have better intervention in the management of their fishing affairs with the creation of a Regional Advisory Council of their own, more suitable for interperipheral regions. I hope that this way we can have a better future.

Considering what we know about the implementation of the third package, and part of this issue has already been discussed today, regarding the delay in transposing its directives, it seems that the latest information I have is from

that 18 Member States have been notified, this information is probably already outdated, due to lack of transposition. The question I put to you is how you view the possibility that, in the legislation being prepared, particularly regarding telephone networks,
trans-European networks, if it includes a device, an incentive that conditions a conditionality for the submission of PCIs, projects of common interest, or that is

condition compliance by Member States with the obligations arising from the third package. Or, on the contrary, it believes that this is an extravagant mechanism and that it should be left only to the regular competition mechanisms, Article 101.
and their successors all intervention in this matter. Thank you very much.
of the Commission and the tolerance, the spirit of tolerance that has existed on this matter. But the question is whether, with legislation in preparation that may
introducing an additional and much stronger conditionality, do you think that this conditionality is an abusive instrument or do you think that this conditionality would be acceptable?
I confess that I share much of the concern that was initially presented here about democratic legitimacy and democratic control that are related to this proposal.

Banking Union and Banking Supervision, because an essential issue remains to be clarified and resolved, which is the role of Parliament, the only institution directly democratically elected by citizens.

But there is another concern that I also have, which is a fundamental concern and has to do with the following: monetary policy instruments are controlled by the European Union. Monetary policy is the responsibility of the European Union.

Banking supervision also becomes the responsibility of the European Union. And yet, if everything goes wrong, if banks go bankrupt, the responsibility for paying for that bankruptcy continues to fall on the taxpayers of the National States. It continues to be a national responsibility.

This is not a problem of minor importance, it is a fundamental problem that does not get resolved. And finally, I just want to point out that it also does not get resolved the fact that we continue to tie monetary policy to what is a secondary issue in the context in which we live, which is inflation, and not to job creation and growth, as it should be. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. European leaders continue to exist in budgetary discipline, and I ask, budgetary discipline, so let's get to it. Because what exactly are we talking about when we talk about budgetary discipline?

In my view, budgetary discipline means respecting contracts with pensioners and not abandoning state commitments halfway through. In my view, budgetary discipline means respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cuts in subsidies.

Budgetary discipline means respecting commitments in health, education, and culture, and not closing services or cancelling projects halfway through. Discipline means putting banks in order and not taking from taxpayers to put money in the hands of speculators to save their banks.
This is the fiscal discipline I would like to see implemented in the European Union, rather than continuing with this market party.

If an example is needed, the budget being discussed in Portugal, at the behest of the Troika, is a perfect example. It violates all the commitments that any state must have with its citizens in order not to violate the agreements made behind closed doors that are bringing Europe and its countries together.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission. First of all, I naturally wanted to congratulate you on the results of the Council. Although it seems to me that it is a bit delayed in time, the final decision is coming a bit late.
The truth is that there is progress.
Now, precisely because I agree with everything my colleague CÃ¡ssio LÃ­dez said, I would like to ask just one question to the President of the Council. The countries that are under assistance...
countries that are in difficulties have fought hard to ensure that there can be a retroactive application of bank debts in their separation from state debt.
This apparently was not accepted.
But we heard statements yesterday from the highest German authorities and the highest French authorities saying that they would treat Ireland as a special case.
What I am asking is whether the Council has approved any decision to apply discriminatory treatment to Ireland different from that reserved for countries like Portugal, Greece, Spain and others.
Mr President, colleagues, Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the 20 concerns of citizens and businesses
regarding the functioning of the single market, precisely in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, which marks the twentieth anniversary of this market.

A first word to thank my colleagues from all the political groups and, in particular, the draftsmen of opinions and the shadow rapporteurs, for their very constructive contributions and their very positive attitude.
It was a pleasure to work with everyone and the report greatly benefited from our combined effort.

We are well aware of and proud that, over these 20 years, the single market has been the driving force behind major economic and employment opportunities in Europe, which have transformed the lives of European citizens and European businesses.
Travelling, residing and working within the Union's area are freedoms that are within reach of all citizens of the 27 Member States.
For European consumers, the single market means more freedom of choice and lower prices.
For our companies, the single market means more business opportunities, with access to 500 million consumers, which means more economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress that the single market has made in Europe since its creation in 1992 until the beginning of the crisis in 2009,
2008, just look at the 2.7 million jobs that were created and the additional 2.13% GDP growth.
Today, making or receiving a phone call while traveling in Europe is cheaper, 13%, than in 2005.
The freedom of movement of people is most eloquently expressed in the Erasmus program.
More than 2.5 million students have benefited from this European Programme for Education and Mobility Exchange.
In the past five years, companies have also benefited from a 25% cut in administrative positions due to single market legislation.
But one question arises. Is everything going well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis that affects us has had negative repercussions on the functioning of this market.
Our citizens, in some countries living with the drama of unemployment and facing austerity measures, have developed a skeptical view of Europe and a negative view of the internal market.
People still do not know or sufficiently understand their rights, nor do they know where to find information or help.
On the other hand, many Member States are unduly delaying the transposition of European directives and legislation on the single market, thereby undermining its full potential.

In certain areas of citizens' daily lives, such simple things as, for example, the reimbursement of medical expenses after a temporary stay in another EU country, the opening of a bank account by a student in the educational program,

Erasmus, changing energy supplier, transferring retirement pensions, having qualifications recognised and registering a vehicle in another Member State are still very complex, difficult or costly procedures.
it is important to address these problems.
That was my concern as rapporteur.
That is why the message written in the report is very clear: more political will is needed, much more political will from the member states and the European institutions.

Council, especially the Council and the Commission, to govern better and together. It is necessary to regain the trust of people and companies and it is necessary to facilitate the exercise of their rights.

Finally, I would like to commend the European Commission, represented by Commissioner Barnier, for presenting the Act for the Single Market 2, 12 priority actions for new growth, which I am sure marks a new stage for the future. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner Barnier and dear colleague Regina Bastos, my congratulations on your already very successful efforts.
When Jacques Delors chaired the European Commission, the Union's Single Market was created in 92.
Delors then summarized the three basic principles of the single market: competition that stimulates, cooperation that strengthens, and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years on, the economic and financial crisis has reignited the threat of national protectionism, and it has become clear that the internal market is not a finished work.

And the celebration of these 20 years must be used to relaunch the single market, with the concern of putting the market at the service of the citizen and not the citizen at the service of the market.
To achieve this, priorities must be set. And I would like to talk about one priority in particular.
A common policy is essential to produce and distribute energy at affordable prices for consumers, with a high level of energy efficiency.
through the European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructure with the potential for Community leverage of investment that represents added European value.
In energy too, Madam President, the common market will be put to the test.
One of the greatest achievements of the European Union, which certainly represents one of the strongest pillars of the development of the Union, its Member States and its regions.
However, in order to be effective and fair, it is necessary to emphasize its policies towards equal opportunities for citizens and all regions, promoting the internal cohesion of the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognize that we can only achieve greater development in our most remote regions, such as the outermost regions, through their greater integration into the single market.

Regions like the Azores need to continue to increase their competitiveness by improving their competitive conditions. But we will never achieve this if we do not better solve our accessibility problems in the area of transport.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that better address the problems raised by our separation.
We therefore expect the Commission to consider a specific programme, such as post-and-transport, as an essential instrument for the integration of these types of regions into the internal market.
Thank you very much, Madam President. I would like to begin by saying thank you very much for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate and it was a debate that demonstrated that the single market is truly a great achievement of the European project.

I welcome the presence of Mr. Minister Mavroianis and his participation in this debate. I thank all my colleagues for their constructive attitude, and some for their skeptical attitude, which is understandable.
and say a big thank you to Commissioner Barnier for the commitment and enthusiasm he puts into discussing these issues, these problems of the internal market and the political will to solve them.
We still have a lot to answer to the citizens.
Citizens are dissatisfied, disillusioned and expect more from us, expect more from the Council, expect more from the Commission, expect more from the Member States.
This balance sheet is very useful, this 20-year balance sheet is important, but as many have said here, it is important to open the door to the gaze of the future.
And the future outlook addresses many of the issues that have been raised here and many of the measures that have already been announced by the European Commission.
The digital single market, citizen mobility, the reform of the EurÃ©s portal, and the European energy market are examples
eloquent proof that we still have an important path to follow in the future and that this path is very important and vital to respond to this era of crisis that we are experiencing.
Citizens are suffering, citizens expect a lot from politicians and the answers that politicians can give to the adverse conditions they are experiencing.
That is why it is important that the single market is one of the answers to the major challenge of competitiveness, employment and economic growth.
I am certain that all of us, after this 20th anniversary celebration, are more eager to provide the answers our citizens need. Thank you very much.

The Gozes report, along with the report we will prepare on the Union's annual growth prospects at the end of this year and which will precede the Spring Council, are two essential pieces of the so-called European semester.
This report addresses the recommendations made to each of the member countries by the Council on the proposal of the Commission. And these recommendations, as was just mentioned, align with the...
The SIXPEC and the future TUPEC, an extraordinarily strong body that reinforces European control over the economic and budgetary policy of member countries.

The balance between this control and autonomy and legitimacy at the national level is not easy to find and it has fallen to a level of imposition, especially of discipline, and ultimately it can even result in a serious package of sanctions.

Regarding Tupac, I would like to briefly comment that it is important for the Council, which is absent today, to give a negotiating mandate to its negotiators, compatible with the ambition to quickly conclude this package, this Tupac.

But more European coordination, to return to the topic, means less control of countries over their own destiny, which requires a subtle balance, but also an increased demand for the quality of the recommendations made to countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure coherence between medium and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment and real convergence, and short-term recommendations focused primarily on discipline and nominal convergence. Second, there must be coherence

with the conclusions that should be drawn from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, particularly the asymmetric impact of common policies and negative externalities, the spillover effects of some national policies on other countries.

Thirdly, we need to agree that there is a minimum threshold of social, economic and labour rights that cannot be exceeded by these recommendations. And finally, it is important that the quality of the recommendations is measured by the results achieved, which is far from being the case so far.

I will finish now, Mr President. I just wanted to thank Mr Gozes for his spirit of collaboration and hope that he will take another step in this spirit, in order to broaden the consensus base around his report and that this spirit will also remain in relation to the next one.
It is true, and it has been mentioned here many times, that there are many things we do not know about shale oil extraction.
but there are also many that we already know and it is important not to forget them.

We know, for example, that each shale gas extraction operation uses more than 19 million litres of drinking water, which is enough to supply a thousand European citizens for a year, based on their needs.

We also know that for every shale gas extraction that is done, in each of the operations, 300 tons of chemicals are pumped into the ground, up to 300 tons of chemicals, about 80% of which remain in the ground and do not come out.

We also know that radioactive elements and heavy metals are released into the subsoil during each shale gas extraction, which, along with the evaporation of toxic waste resulting from the process, constitute an effective threat to public health.
This is a danger of contamination of drinking water resources and it is a contamination that is real and imminent.

Knowing this, we know that shale gas extraction is also a response that is apparently easy, that only thinks about the immediate, the industry and profit, ignoring the populations, the future and the environment.

But this is also the Europe that knows, in this House, that water is an essential, vital and important resource, that knows how to protect the health of citizens and must protect it, that seeks to make agreements to avoid emissions and to propose energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, environmental standards and health standards.
Therefore, when one does not know everything, being prudent is the minimum.
And they may even want to do so, but do not do it in our name or in the name of the citizens who are here for us to represent.

but also, as the rapporteur said, we are in a position of making political choices and that is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some problems and will not be able to support this report.

national systems are agglomerated, which means that we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separate when something goes wrong and therefore taxpayers will continue to pay.

So I want to conclude, Mr. President, by saying that despite all the efforts, I think we have here a very clear example that together we could still stand up, but divided, we will surely fall. And that is why it was important to have even more
Mrs. Ferreira, please. There is always room for progress, but for Portugal, the support of the European Union in recent years has been crucial.
Portugal has transformed from a country whose competitiveness was based on cheap labor into a country with highly trained, highly sophisticated labor.
But when the country exports, it is necessary to have conditions for where?

And that is why it is important that some countries with surpluses open their doors to the requalified exports of countries that started with a specialization profile that was absolutely unsustainable.

Thank you, Mr President. Small-scale fishing should be given special protection under the common fisheries policy, not only because it promotes socio-economic cohesion and ensures the livelihood of many families, but also because it is a factor in retaining these communities along the coastal areas.
Their economic and social sustainability must be an objective, ensuring us a differentiated fishing regime that gives priority of access to resources,
allow proximity management and protect the fishing rights that fishing professionals in these communities knew about against transferable fishing rights.
It is equally important for their sustainability to pay attention to the water access regime, especially in waters or regions with biogeographical basins.
marine areas with a reduced continental shelf and scarce resources concentrated in underwater mountains and fishing banks that must have protected access.

In a context of liberalisation and crisis, which weighs heavily on fragile regions, it must also be ensured that products from international trade meet the same requirements as those imported by the Union.
Thank you, Mr President, Mr President of the Executive Council, Commissioner. I will be very brief because I believe that what is at issue here is essentially a political point, it is not
It is a financial issue. And the question that arises is whether we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis or if we want to exacerbate the crisis.

Most European countries are currently making a huge effort, from the point of view of their public finances, in order to overcome the crisis in a competitive way, in a way that can put their European countries back on track.
The European Union has a high level of competitiveness and competition globally, but it is obvious that without investment, there can be no growth and this crisis cannot be overcome.
If the European Union insists on these radical cuts, particularly in cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy, what this will mean is that the countries that are making a huge
effort, they will not be able to grow and this plan that we have accepted in all countries for the European Union will fail. Good accounts with prospects for growth and competitiveness.

The only and great instrument for this is precisely this multiannual financial framework. And for this reason, if we want the European Union to succeed and for its policy to be an exemplary policy for other countries, we must bet on the budget for the financial perspectives.
